I tried this beer when it was released about a year ago and they aren't kidding about it aging well. Initially it was a pruny, boozy and overly sweet beer, but a year of storage has enhanced some smokey flavors and made it a well balanced and enjoyable brew.

2012 Vintage pours a deep red with a thin head that doesnt last long. Aroma is sweet maltiness and caramel with alcohol, not too much coming in the way of hops. Taste is much more sweet than bitter to balance out the booziness, was somewhat shocked to see the ABV was so high. Has a medium mouthfeel with average carbonation. Overall this is a solid (but pricey) english barleywine, would be great to lay down a few bottles of each years vintage to do occasional vertical tastings.

bottle. Pours clear brown amber with light tan minimal head. Maybe glassware related. Vinous aromas, wood, toffee, caramel and pitted fruits. Clean flavour profile, complex malt body, medium full body. Toast coming through on the finish with a light sweetness. Earthy hop character is evident with a touch of hotness on the finish.
2012 bottle. Pours a dark copper with no head. Aroma is a slightly fruity booze mixed joy. Flavor is syrupy caramel, booze and a little plum flavor. Very nice but the price isnt great.
Bottle 2008.  Big sweet, hoppy, and burly.  A behemouth of a beer.  Strictly for cold weather and evening drinking.

2012 bottle. It poured a clear copper color with a small off-white head. The aroma was malty, with caramel, fruit, a little hoppiness and some alcohol. The taste was sweet, a little spicy and bitter, with lots of alcohol. Good stuff.

2011 Bottle pours a slightly hazy amber hue in to my snifter, moderate off white head with ok retention that reduces to a small lacing cap. Nose is immediate plum and raisen, with toffee in the background. Taste starts sweet with plum, raisen, and toffee dancing on my tounge. Mild bitterness creeps in to keep things moving. The body is big and burly but silkey smooth. An excellent end to my day.

2012 vintage, 12 oz bottle, Whole Foods Columbus.  Deep red-brown; initially a 1-finger off-white frothy, rocky head that completely disappears fairly quickly.  Smells like a huge beer; big and malty, sweet, brown sugar, a little dark fruit, and noticeable alcohol.  Flavor is quite strong and heavy, malt, nut, and theres a serious level of alcohol in the finish and exhale.  Thick mouthfeel but the carbonation disappears fairly quickly which is a little bit of an issue because this is a sipping beer and will probably take some time to drink.  This is a nice beer, and while I only bought the single, I could definitely see picking up a 4-pack and hanging on to it for a few years because I would expect this to mellow very nicely.  This would probably be in my top 5 if I could get this oaked.

2012 Vintage in a bottle. Im an ale kind of guy. This ale is just wrong. It pours a very cloudy dark caramel color. The taste is mostly alcohol with a mild bread aftertaste. Its a beefy 11.7% and it aint playing. My only afterthought is at least it doesnt taste like a barley wine. Itll get you drunk but there are better high percentage ales out there. North Coast has become on of my favorite breweries, but they missed the mark on this one. Maybe I got a bad batch...
This beer was great. Aged two years, the sweetness of dark fruits (plums or raisins?) really came through. It was smooth and bourbon-like in flavor, and just a great beer in general.

This is the 2012 vintage, pours a medium to dark clear brown with heavy, lacy head. Mouthfeel is quite heavy and oily....aroma is peculiar. If this was under 10% I wouldnt finish it. Not horrible but nothing to write home about.

Bottle. Amber, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate to full, malty and caramel sweet aroma - some toffee, dark fruitiness and light alcohol. Body is medium to full, malty and caramel sweetish flavor, caramel - light toffee, dark fruitiness and light alcohol. Finish is average to long, malty and sweetish, caramel and some dark fruitiness, light hoppyness and some alcohol. Sweet BW with dark fruitiness - too sweet for me (despite of 11, 7 %).

Very stellar whiskey-type ale; super smooth, and a wee spicy to complement the malts. Yum!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
2012 Otsuchi - Medium brown colour. Some bready, yeasty notes. Flavour of malt loaf. Its fruity, malty and has a slightly warming spiciness. Reminds me of La Trappe Quad.
2012 vintage. Dark brown, brief beige head. Very sweet. Ripe fruits. Plums, raisins, sherry, christmas cookie dough, some bitterness. Not too alcoholic taste considering its 11,7% ABV. Very warming.
Bottle. Pours amber with thin white head. Aroma is brown sugar and caramel. Flavor is fig, raisins, and caramel. Nice.
Bottle at ÖÖWF 2012, vintage 2011. Aroma rich in caramel, toffee and fruits. Taste heavy with toffee, very nice. Sweet, yet fairly well balanced.

Pours clear, burgundy copper with a short head that drains down quickly. Moderate carbonation that only really appears at nucleation sites on the glass. Sweet, alcoholic nose with some candied fruit notes. Nice. Sugars and alcohol right up front on the first taste followed by some dried apple. Bit of acetic acid maybe, with some bitterness and dryness in the aftertaste. I agree with the other reviews - "Spicy" is a good descriptor. The alcohol is totally here to stay. It dominates the mouthfeel on this one. Carbonation is pleasant. That ethanol dryness and the numbness hits quickly, though. Overall, decent but the alcohol is way too up-front. They need to tone it down in the next iteration, or find a way to mitigate it - some beers work, this one doesnt. It tries, though.

Not your typical beer. First off I just wanna say this is such an awesome beer just because of how different it is. Its put in scotch wood barrels and it really tastes like your sipping a nice scotch Im surprised by the reviews I read that nobody has mentioned that yet.
      I poured a 2012 unaged 12 oz. bottle into a tulip glass. Its very dark amber, small head. Complex and strong. Tastes of raisin, plums, toast, wood and alcohol.  Made for aging, can only imagine how it would taste after a few years. Great beer.

2012 vintage. I did not age it, because the packaging did not mention that it should be aged - nor did it even say what style of beer this is. Aroma is reminiscent of raisins, figs, etc - almost like a quad, but more skunky and unpleasant. As for the flavor: my description would be the same as for the aroma. The palate is incredibly thick, sticky, and resinous. One of the most "rich" beers that Ive ever had. Lots of dense, powerful, unforgiving flavors all packed together. A good beer for the critics, I guess - but quite difficult to enjoy. Probably gets better with age.

2011 Vintage. Aroma is sweet, plenty of raisin and fig, and also ripe red fruit. Full bodied. Sweet with a heavy malt base, but surprisingly bright and not cloying. Vinous, cognac like, vanilla, berries, very smooth palate. Excellent barley wine now, and another year or two will mellow it out even further.

I had the 750 - tsunami relief bottle. Pretty stoked to drink this, I have been getting into bigger more barleywine type brews lately. Overall I wasnt blown away. The aroma is sweet with a sharpness I cant quite nail down, the palate is similar. There is this bite to it that I cant explain. It must just be the heat from the booze.

Pours dark copper with a quickly fading white head. Aroma of sweet malts, fruits, berries and spices. Taste is sweet and really strong and intense. Flavours of sweet malts, fruits, spices dominate and are balanced by strong hoppiness in the long finish. Full body, cant really get fuller than this. Sticky, slow to drink. Very rich and varied - a great, complex beer.

Bottle (12 oz) 2012. Clear amber with reddish reflects, medium off-white head and some lacing. Aroma of malt, caramel, fruits, pine and liquorice. Taste is piney with a huge malty body, spices, caramel, alcohol, floral/herbal notes and hints of fruits. Slight bitter finish. Warming alcohol. Not easily drinkable. Balance is, at most, average in the taste. This beer need way more time to mellow and get together but I see the potential of a good barley wine here.

Aroma has pine, candied molasses, alcohol and a little perfumed floral scent. Pours dark amber without head or lacing. Taste has bitterness and sweetness, very full on palate. Much stronger beer than the Smuttynose wheat wine I just had. Great stuff.

Bottle shared by jayhawk73. Thanks Jeff!

The beer is dark ruby hued, with a thin, wispy tan head that leaves faint lacing on the snifter. The aroma brings malt, toffee, alcohol. The flavor is sweet, with notes of toffee, caramel candies, malt. The feel is medium bodied on the palate. The sweetness is present throughout, but not cloying. The beer actually reminds me of Samichlaus. Good stuff. This will certainly age well. I would definitely have this again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-02-2011

355 ml bottle. Clear dark reddish amber colour, thin off-white head. The aroma is sweetish, with apples and dark fruits and a whiff of alcohol. Flavour of caramel and dark fruits, with spicy notes and warming alcohol, and a long warm moderatly bitter finish. Very tasty.
Good aroma ruined by alcohol. Sweetness and alcohol with bitter hops that stick to ur gums. Again ruined by the pushing alcohol. Not for me.
Bottle at home. Mahogany brown color. Aroma of alcohol, licorice and banana. Taste of sweetness, alcohol and licorice. Balanced.

Aroma:  Interesting, you can definitly smell the grapes, cherries and even a sort of cognac smell (barrell?), but there is also a bit of a metallic smell, could just be my glass though, but Ive never smelled it before.  Appearance:  A brownish/red color with a one finger head that dissipates quickly, but laces nicely on the glass.  Taste:  Granted Im particularly biased towards Barley Wines, they are my favorites, but this seems delicious.  Its like Im drinking decadence, cherries, grapes, other fruit, sugar, butterscotch, caramel, vanilla.  Excellent flavor.  Palate:  Smooth, with almost no carbonation but a nice silky feeling going down.  Overall:  Again, Im particularly biased towards barley wine, but this is really good, highly recommend.

Tap at Rattle N Hum. Clear chestnut-ruby colour with a tiny off-white head. Nose is massive apple and maple syrup. Mouth is sweet syrupy dustiness, chocolate, smooth and vanilla, tiny bit of barrel, bit of alcohol sting, slight biscuit, lasting shoe polish and liquorice domination. Nice beer. 

---via BeerBuddy

2012 bottle. Pour is deep ruby red with a smallish tan head.  Aroma is toffee malt, dark fruits, maple, very faint spicy alcohol notes, and some hints of Brachs caramel. Flavor is loaded with fruity toffee malt up front with a fair amount of sweetness. As the flavor evolves, spicy peppery notes come though along with a touch of dry grain. Not a huge hop presence here. In my mind, this is an example of a clssic barleywine. If some asked me "hey, whats barleywine like?", I would direct them to this beer

A dusty 2010 bottle. Its meant to age, only under what conditions has this one been? Aroma is sharp fruit bread and not too subtle booze. A mellow, slow punch to the mouth that a very sweet malt flavor and lagging bitterness. Comparable a brandy shot only in beer form. Rusty copper color, not much head at this point, if there ever was. Syrupy, in a carbonated cola sort of way. Easy going but carries a big stick.

Bottle. Pours a hazy and rather dark amber color with a fairly thin head. Some sweet and fruity notes to the nose, which were a but unexpected. Definite fruit notes in the taste, with some hints of raisin and just a bit of sourness underneath.
Pours deep ruby red with a cream colored head. Aroma is barley, caramel, floral and cherries. Flavor follows nose very sweet slightly bitter with a boozy finish. Alcohol is a little too prominent

Pours a cloudy ruby, amberish color with a half finger head that dissipates fairly quickly and leaves a nice sticky lacing. Aroma is sweet grapefruit, carmel, bready notes, some booze. As expected for a barleywine, malts overpower the smell. Taste starts with sweet plum, cherry, grapefruit notes. Middle of the mouth the malts show through with carmel and bready flavors. Nice smooth boozy, fruity finish. Nice mouthfeel with lively carbonation and an oily, slick texture. Heavy medium to full body. Complex barleywine. Cannot wait to try it after another year of aging.

Aroma is sweet and sticky, but not overpoweringly so. Color is a nice brown/caramel, with a nice off white head that slowly dissipates. Not too oily. Taste is full and sweet, with a nice candy sugar edge that makes it like drinking candy. Finish is frothy and smooth, adding to the nose.

Bottle at home, vintage 2012.
Clear copper, no head. Aroma heavy malty (caramel, fruit), hoppy, with some alcohol. Flavor heavy sweet, medium spicy and bitter, with alcohol warming. Full body, quite flat. To much alcohol.

2012 bottle
Pours reddish brown with medium off white head
Aromas of oak, cherries, berley malts, fudge
Nice almost creamy taste, low carbonation, full bodied, low bitterness

Clear copper with a really small head. A lot of dark fruit in the aroma and caramell. Very sweet and vinous. Some bitterness in the aftertaste as well. Pretty heavily carbonated.
Looking forward to opening the next 2012 bottle in a couple of years.

This is the commemorative release with proceeds going to tsunami relief for Ft Braggs sister city Otsuchi, Japan. Pours a rich clear red-brown in color. Thin head but persistent. Nice dark fruit flavors; raison, fig, date. Alcohol is evident on the finish. Drinks very much like a nice barleywine. This will be one of my favorite "big" beers.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2012 Bottle from SB, This was a pleasant surprise. A perfect desert beer pours daek copper, not nuch of a head but with nice aroma of pumpkins and tastes as a mix between a good barleywine  and sherry !!!!

I had this beer at 28 Springs in Siloam Springs, AR. 2012 vintage, served at 55 degrees, from a bottle in a tulip. This beer has an incredible aroma. Maybe a better aroma than taste, but the taste is fantastic as well. Bready and hints of caramel and fruits. Loved it!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma is sweet malts and dark fruits. A brown pour with a fleeting ivory head and no lacing. The taste is malt forward. There is s strong sweet  toasted caramel and fruit taste with an alcohol finish. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Overall, as vbrley wines go , enjoyable. (2011 vintage):

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2012 355 ml bottle. 2012 vintage.
Pours a copper brown colour with a small white head. Aroma of sweet caramel, fruit cake and bread. Flavour of sweet harsh malts, sweet caramel, grains, grassy hops and honey. Medium bodied, dry mouthfeel, low carbonation and a warming malty finish. Sweet malt juice, not my thing.

2011 vintage from bottle: Aroma of raisins, wet cardboard, cherries, spice and slight leather. Appearance is garnet with a minimal head and almost no lacing. Taste is sweet, spicy, then hot unsurprising for a nearly 12% beer. Palate is thick and syrupy with a bit of burn as it goes down. A nice beer, I was surprised at the slight oxidation considering its only a year old but it tastes good and will warm you up.
On tap at Jerrys Chicago. Pours dark. Good balanced flavor. Notes of roasted malt, raisins, dark caramel, and a tad of licorice. Very good, but missing a little tartness in my opinion.
A pretty decent barleywine.  Despite its high IBU, this remains a dominantly malty ale with elements of caramel, dark fruit, and vanilla.  Incredibly powerful taste, perhaps too much.

25.4 oz. Bottle. March 2012 Otsuchi Commemorative Release. Very tasty, but needs maybe a year or two aging. Buttery biscuit scent with caramel, and an astringent tinge. Deep bronze pour, mahogany, with a white frothy head to ring. Medium body, slight syrupy texture with a fizz finish. Buttery caramel flavor, hop, bitter, and a slightly hot finish.
Flaske delt med medbrygger Bråtveit da vi brygget Hulderøl i des-09, fritt etter hukommelsen: en av mange gode øl denne dagen, må absolutt prøves igjen ved første anledning.

The 2011 version. A clear red.brown colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of red fruits, some caramel and malt. The taste of sweet fruits, malts and hops. The aftertaste is sweet, a little bitter and alcohol notes.
Pours a clear reddish orange with an off white head. Nose is malty and almost stale smell. Taste is huge malt then finish with some hops. Can taste alcohol as would expect for an 11.7%

330ml bottle. A deep copper colour with red flecks throughout and a tidy beige head that settles quickly. Caramel, toffee and vanilla in the nose.  Port like flavour with a long strong finish. Fills the mouth.

2012 bottle Otsuchi commemorative release.  Copper pour with a nice but quickly fading head.  Toffee, caramel, raisin, bread.  A bit of vanila.  Silky and smooth despite the complexity and body.  Will be much better after several year but is still very good.  A beer to sip.  Cannot wait to have this in 3-5 years.

A beer to take your time with. Layered aromas and flavors of wheat bread, dried dark fruit, raisins, caramel, and vanilla. Not heavy, thick or syrupy, though it is powerful and full bodied. Alcohol sticks out occasionally, though overall a complex, interesting and enjoyable barely wine. A must try.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

Bottle - 2012 vintage. Slightly murky orange-brown pour with very minimal head. Nose of toffee, caramel, bread, and booze. Full syrupy palate. Taste is rich caramel, bread, toffee, and it doesnt taste boozy at all. Terrific brew.

12 oz [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Dark mahogny. Sweet caramel, heavy malts. Bready things. Thoroughly an excellent nose. Malts, sweetness, alc and all. Some syrupy flavors. Body is quite full. Sweetish. Full of flavour. I like it a lot. A really nice barley wine. Not too suffocating or overpowering. Sweet, strong. As it should be.-- bb/h

12 oz 2012 vintage. Sweet toffee and caramel on the nose. Almost no head, dark velvety beer. A sweet beer with hints of raisin and brown sugar. Quite a tasty beer if you like the strong sweet Belgian style, though I think it has nothing much at all in common with a stout (in contrast to the commercial descriptions claim).
A bottle from systembolaget. Dark red color, fruity aroma, very rich awesome taste with cherry notes.

dark deep red color, aroma of caramel, toffee, dark fruits, flavors of toffee, burnt caramel, dark fruits, citrus hops, and lots of booze, good but needed more age, to boozey but i look forward to trying again at a latter date

Pours dark garnet with a light white head and a nice wall of bubbly lacing. Aroma is a bit of french oak and malt. Taste is oak and caramel malt with a touch of hop resin. The 11.7% abv is hidden remarkably well. Light, crisp, and refreshing for such a strong beer.

2011 vintage, 12 oz bottle in snifter. Cloudy, rusty dark amber pour with just a thin ringer of slightly off-white head. Boozy, fruity aroma with a lot of caramel and toffee character. Notes of figs, prunes, strawberries, and bready malts. Flavor is still boozy, though less so than I remember from when I first bought it about 9 months ago. Slightly oxidized flavor that faded as it warmed. More fruity than I remember. Picking up a big strawberry note for some reason, along with the plum and toffee. Finish is sweet with a burnt sugar aftertaste. Still a little hot. Palate is thick and chewy. This one seems to have aged pretty well in its year in the basement. Much less alcohol burn, and more fruity esters have developed.

Aroma: The smell is ripe, sweet fruits, figs, dates and apples, some vinous notes, but also muffin batter, Marzipan and nuts.Appearance: The beer is clear brown with a hint of orange, the head is off-white leaving little lacing but very good curtains.Taste: The taste is sweet, very sweet, dried fruits, raisins, oranges, apricots, Marzipan, almonds, sherry, some grassy bitterness, cocoa beans and bitter orange peel.Palate: Low carbonation, soft and oily feeling, a big body finished of with an alcoholic warmth and a slight drynessOverall: This year was very promising as a young one, hope it will be even better in five, ten years.Note: Bottle 355 ml (Vintage 2012). Reviewed 2012-08-05.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2014 Rating 2014: Pours reddish brown without head, making the beer look like a glass of berry juice once it has settled. Not a stunning beer to look at. The aroma reminds me of fortfied wine, theres that touch of alcohol, but also of fruit cake and some smoke. In fact, the most similar beers I could think of are strong scottish ales where the yeast imparts a slightly smoky scent. The beer taste goes along with previous years, the yeast imposes itself with the alcohol, providing tastes of dried fruit, then comes the balancing bitterness. Its still quite a full beer. Not as good as previous years, IMHO - dont know why. I have saved a bottle of each year since 2009. I will give review of the years in a later review. Its a good beer.

2011 bottle poured in a snifter: Aroma initally yeast, but as warms a bit becomes nice brown sugar. Yet its not sweet to taste, well balanced and Much more carbonation than you would expect from such a big beer. Found the 2011 a little sharp yet, but bought more to cellar and expect it will grow much better over the years. Nice barley wine here.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2016 How: Bottle.
Where: Tasting 2016-05-28.
Appearance: Amber-red colour with a quickly fading off-white head.
Aroma: Dried fruit, raisin, alcohol, caramel, malt.
Body: Medium to full body, low carbonation.
Flavour: Caramel, dried fruit, alcohol, malt.
Original rating 5-4-7-3-15: 3.4
Bottle, 2012 vintage. Red colour with a quickly vanishing white head. Sweet aroma with some alcohol. Heavy flavour with sweet malt.
365mL bottle. Pours deep amber with a big caramel/hop/ethanol aroma. Huge caramel/toffee malt flavour to this beer with a nice grassy, herb like hop backing.

Bottle picked up at Premier Gourmet Niagara Falls New York. Pours a deep dark copper colour with about half a finger of white head, no lacing. Smells of sugar, candy, caramel and booze. Tastes smooth, boozy a little bit of a tongue number, bitter, caramel. Pretty awesome.

Vintage 2012 pours deep amber. Very nice toasted malt. Noticeable alcohol but a smooth finish. This one is good. Slow sipping complexity. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

75cl, Vintage 2012, at 11.7%Vol, as Old Stock Ale Otsuchi, new exclusive American brew, thx to Secret Santa!, complex brew, alcoholic/sweet and slightly spicy/bitter, heavy, yet balanced, clear, good head, good brew, yet expensive!

Strong aroma and reddish brown pour leads to a complex taste and warming mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from the local taphouse shop. Wow beer, exceptional. Aromas of caramel, anisette, and liquorice. Taste is sweet, with bitterness taking over for a very long finish. Palate is syrupy and full bodied. Brown, with a thin head.
2012 Portland International Beerfest. A big brew with a dark fruit sweetness. Complex. Finishes with a mild alcohol burn.

Vintage 2011 bottle. Pours a cloudy ruby, amberish color with a half finger head that dissipates fairly quickly and leaves a nice sticky lacing. Aroma is sweet grapefruit, carmel, bready notes, some booze. As expected for a barleywine, malts overpower the smell. Taste starts with sweet plum, cherry, grapefruit notes. Middle of the mouth the malts show through with carmel and bready flavors. Nice smooth boozy, fruity finish. Nice mouthfeel with lively carbonation and an oily, slick texture. Heavy medium to full body. Complex barleywine. Cannot wait to try it after another year of aging.

Bottle, 2011.  Lightly 0ff-white head on a murky deep copper brown.  Slight dusty citrus hops, toffee, dark fruits, bit of prune as well.  Fairly sweet, rich dark fruit flavors with a touch of brandy.  Medium to thicker body and warming, but felt it was a little watery.  Solid barleywine.

12oz 2010 vintage. Clear dark mahogany with a tannish hue - fades but can be resurrected with a small swirl of the glass. Strangely enough I dont think Ive had this before...but will have to remember to keep on buying a few six packs each year to enjoy over time. Mild to moderate sweet / overripe fruit aroma, raisins, plum and prunes, alcohol is very well hidden, oddly enough very light rust but not metallic at all (I know it makes no sense but so says my nose) along with some vanilla and light toffee. Smooth, sweet, mild to moderate carbonation, full body, alcohol remains hidden until the end when it becomes slightly hot but its a pleasant bite that cuts the sweetness a bit. Finish becomes dry, get some malt, vanilla and more fruit.

Vintage 2011, poured 7/12/2012. Beautiful Red/Amber color. Low carbonation. High alcohol taste and aroma. 

Aroma: alcohol
Appearance: amber/red, clear, minimal head
Taste: light sweetness, alcohol
Palate: full body, creamy, flat

2012 bottle.  Pours deep copper with a finger of carbonation head.  This isnt the most aromatic of barleywines but there is some caramel and alcohol on the nose.  The taste has a big boozy punch that is overpowering the flavors at this point.  This definitely needs some age on it to be enjoyable.  Right now, its a pretty intense alcohol forward beer.

2012 bottle.  Pours a mostly clear dark ruby color with no head.  Heavy aroma of raisins, berries, caramel malt, toffee, and booze.  Taste is slightly sweet, very boozy, berries and raisins come through well.  Fairly complex but I wish I had laid the bottle down for a bit for it to mellow.  Big alcohol burn on the finish is too much.  This is just ok to me.  Needs to age a couple years.

35,5 cl bottle vintage 2009 (11.5%) at Pikkulintu, no BBE info
Sweetish aroma with some raisins, berries and vanilla. Flavour has some harsh malt, raisins and alcohol in the finish that comes through even more when this warms up. Also a slight moldy feeling here.

355ml bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki
2009 vintage - Pours dark reddish brown with a smooth foamy head. Strong malty and hoppy aroma with notes of sweet caramel, syrup and hints of aniseed. Taste is malty and sweet with notes of syrupy sugar, dry ripe fruits and hops. Finish is sweet and slightly sticky with some malty caramel notes. Okay, quite sweet but tasty barley wine. Alcohol burns through a bit too much, though.

2011 vintage, fairly hard poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a snifter.

Pours a dark amber with golden hues and a two finger off-white head. Delicious aroma of caramel and toffee, perhaps a bit of brown sugar and booze. Opens with the smooth taste of caramel, honey, sherry joined by ripe, dark fruit and biscuity tones and finishes ultra-smooth. Pleasant boozy warmth is present throughout. On the lighter side of full-bodied, syrupy with enough carbonation to make itself known with an occasional tickle of the tongue, extremely smooth and silky. Highly enjoyable and a fantastic example of an American-brewed old ale.
Sampled at 2012 Indianapolis Brew Ha Ha. Heavy on the alcohol but still very smooth. Worth the try if you can find it.
Not much aroma.  Sugary alcohol taste.  Thick mouth.  Deep amber color.  Taste is full of caramel and sugar.  Big mouth.  I wasnt a huge fan of this one.
Didnt bother with sipping this one, it went down pretty well, notes of brown sugar in aroma and taste, a little burn there from the alcohol which was welcome.
Surprising be. Heaviest alcohol content in a beer Ive ever had. Great flavor, lots of personality for a domestic ale.

From the 2012 batch which comes in at 11.7% ABV according to the label. It pours a ruby hued brown color with a moderate tan head that lingers.  It almost seems to sparkle. The aroma brings out sweet barley malts and a kind of wooden sensation but overall it is mellower than many young barleywines.  The body is medium. The taste is pucker-up pungent with a higher alcohol note than on the nose and a slightly dry finish.
Not bad, but 99? I love the 11.4% though, does the trick.....................

Bottle.  Fruity and chocolate aroma. Tastes of burning alcohol, roasted malt and fruit.  Very smooth, the burn isnt so bad considering the high abv, and the finish is slightly bitter.  Very solid beer, pleasantly surprised! 11.7% abv.
UPDATED: JUL 4, 2012 The 11.7% ABV is a kicker, but the taste is very smooth, just a tad bitter, which is perfect. Great beer, bought it in a 4-Pack, great deal for this kind of beer.

Bottle. Pours a brilliant deep mahogany with smallish light tan coloured head. Aromas of dark fruits, rich caramel and plenty of alcohol. NIce. Falvours are super sweet with lots of rich caramel and sugar showing through. Plenty of alcohol on the finish to bring it back a little. Medium mouthfeel. Nice beer
Bottle from Brick Store Pub in Decatur, Ga. Mahoghany in color. Sweet, chocolate fruity aroma. Notes of caramel and dark forest fruits. Alcohol apparent but not overwhelming.

Biege head misty ruby red pour soft carbonation aromas fig alcohol dried fruit dark as well caramel yeast rich doughy brown sugar the flavours raisin sultana figs plum earthyness caramel warming alcohol like cognac yeast  molasses brown sugar soy medium bitter good balance fruit superb the finish tasty barleywine good aftertastes hops malts yeast sugar bitter sweet flavours good on the taste buds warming taste

2012 Bottle. Pours a clear deep ruby red with a small white head. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, brown sugar, touches of grape, alcohol and wood. Syrupy sweet caramel malt body with prune juice and very present alcohol. Finishes slightly dry and boozy. Maybe it gets better with time.

12oz bottle - pours clear cherry with quickly diminishing beige head.  Nose is caramel, alcohol, and prunes.  Flavor adds resin and grenadine (or cherry or currants).  Taste is sweet like grenadine syrup, a little sour and ends bitter.  Im guessing that this is what a Flaming Moe tasted like.  I cant get over the clarity and purity of the color.  Definitely a sipping beer.  burp (reminded me of how good the chicken curry I made for lunch was).  Im conflicted with this beer: the eyes, body and nose want to tell me this is a great beer, but my tongue is blackballing this assessment.

Bottle, 2011 vintage. Pours cloudy reddish amber with a small tan head and some lacing. Aroma is malty, caramel, some fruit and alcohol. Taste is malty, caramel, moderately sweet with a bitter finish. Alcohol notes are particularly strong in the warming finish.
2012 Otsuchi Bottle. Pours reddish chestnut brown. Off white head. Nose/taste of grapes, chestnuts, almonds, toffee and brown sugar. Heavily carbonated. A touch sweet on the palate. Medium body.

This bottle is one of two I purchased from the 2011 vintage. I drank this from a tulip glass.

The first pour results in a gorgeous deep amber with a light head that bubbles fast and dissipates quickly. Mild Lacing is observed and noticeable bubbling.

The Odor offers up smells of whiskey, apple and other fruits I cant put my finger on. The mild smell is surprising, maybe she needs to warm a bit. As I go back I smell cherries and figs. More smells reveal caramel and toffee, this is one complex beast.

That first sip is so smooth that I could swear this beer isnt 12% ABV I get tastes of whiskey, caramel, toffee, apple, cherries, fig. Everything comes together and lays so well.

Bold on the tongue, it chooses to stick to the back of the mouth rather than the front. The carbonation helps mask how thick the beer is.

Overall, this beer is great. Drinkable, smart, complex. The mouthfeel is a little lacking and this is definitely a beer you need to sip.
This is extremely sweet and overpowering. It didnt have hops at all. I thought it wasnt balanced enough to be so highly rated.

So... Im a day away from not being able to have a beer for three or more weeks as Ana and I are about to embark on macrobiotic diets.  As ludicrous as it may seem, I actually feel more sorrow for my loss of cheese more than my loss of beer.  As a last hoorah, I bought a block of white Stilton with cranberry and dates, figs, apple slices, sharp cheddar, and figs... and a few bottles of North Coast Old Stock Ale.  What a better way to enjoy Stilton, yeah?

No aging (2012 vintage): Its immediately noticeable that this beer is pretty immature right off the shelves.  The beer is a mostly clear, dark plum-like color with a healthy, yet fast-fading off-white head that leaves dense, fast-falling lace.  It looks incredibly clean.

North Coast Old Stock Ale
    North Coast Old Stock Ale

It smells a little dirty (as in dirt-like, not filthy), with an almost woody, earthy, hay-like intensity thats slightly softened by a light fruit aroma.  Theres no doubt that this harsh aroma will age incredibly well.

In the mouth, its pretty darned pungent.  Strong alcohol couples with bitter, flavorful hops to stoke this thin-bodied (yet full) brews fire.  This beer must be enjoyed at (Im guessing) about 60 degrees to allow all of its characteristics to fill the beer, as a cold glass of this will taste more like vodka than a barley wine.   Theres an almost stain-like darkness in the flavor that reminds me a little of a combination of molasses and ink.  As odd as that sounds, it tastes very nice.  Strong, but respectable.

This definitely needs to age at least two years (Im predicting three or four at this point) in order for it to fully shine.  Having had many vertical tastings in my life, Ive come to recognize aging potential in a beer... and this is showing all the signs of a good cellar candidate.

My advice: dont drink this fresh.  If you can find a vintage a couple years old or can hold yourself back from drinking a bottle of it for a few years, jump on it!

Drinking the 2011 vintage so maybe it's a little new to fully appreciate has a warm alcohol note and little nose it's the alcohol that is the dominating part of the beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2014 [5/ 12]  2012 bottle. Clear bronze with a beige head thats quickly gone. Aroma of raisins, prunes, dates, vanilla, sherry, sweet-shop spices. Lightly carbonated and only a little syrupy. Sweet and rich with mellow dried fruits before firm bitterness. Boozy, but fairly well-integrated. Some licorice at the end. For what it is, its very drinkable this fresh. Almost certainly some medium-term improvement in it, but theres not a huge amount of character there. [3.7][2/ 14] Another 2012 bottle. Dark amber with a coat of beige head that doesnt quite disappear. Boozy aroma with dried fruit, vanilla, sherry. Sweet with firm bitterness and some alcohol at the end. Gentle spices. Quite rich but not cloying. Maybe a little soy and plenty of sherry, but no cardboard. Has melded a bit. Powerful without being too sticky. Good and in no danger of going home.

From a 355ml bottle on 18/5/2012. 2012 edition, ABV 11.7%. Pours a clear amber with little head. Has a strong aroma of caramel, golden syrup, dark fruits and alcohol. In the mouth its very sweet and syrupy, with some likeness to a tokay. Theres more caramel and golden syrup in the flavour, with a good dose of brown sugar and some butterscotch. Finishes with a firm, slightly sour bitterness, with a good dash of warming alcohol. Consuming whilst young, its not overly complex but is none the less a big, flavoursome sipper, which is nicely suited to a chilly evening.

2011 version. Pours a sultry deep orange-ruby. A vigorous swirl produces a finger or so of a light toffee colored head that settles to absolutely nothing fairly quickly. Nose is sweet cherry, apples, some dried fruit, fresh citrus, and a little peppery spice with a touch of alcohol. Taste is very sweet, and moderately bitter. Palate is rich, chewy, not too thick though, sticky, with some alcohol warmth. Its heavy in the glass, which is awesome. Cellaring would probably do wonders for this, but fresh its quite enjoyable. Just a rich, flavorful, fine looking brew.

Cellar temperature and into a shallow chalice. Has a viscous, oily, liquified sugar look to it. Completely headless with little carbonation; a radiant deep copper in body. Nose had an initial release of Starburst fruit chews. This wanes to reveal rich, vinous fruit, fortifed white port spiciness, cough medicine, prunes, dates and bitter/sweet, tart orange citrus. Heady, spicy and oh, so, so boozy hot on the palate. Sugar sweet to the point of being clammy and actually drawing on the palate - the way a lollipop draws out the saliva. Lots of caramelised citrus in back, boozy, warming higher alcohols in the swallow dull all but the residual sugars. Medium body, but sticky and awkward in mouthfeel with a light spritz to it. The fruit does its best to shine but is weighed down with such force. This one needs a long cellaring. Oddly enjoyable the way a sharp white port is but lacking balance and poise. Definitely laying one down for a decade or two for a re-rate! (12fl.Oz, 2012 release, 11.7% ABV, Cellarbrations Carlisle
Light caramel and nut aromas.  Caramel, dark fruit and nut flavors. Overall a very good beer.

Great aroma with some toasted malt, raisin and tawny port. Pours deep red with small off-white head that disappears quickly with no lacing. Sweet, light flavor with a medium body and a very slightly alcoholic short finish.
Yum!  Malty, boozy, and thick... just the way I like it! Keep up the good work, North Coast.

Bottle. Clear reddish amber pour with a foamy tan head that slowly diminishes to surface cover. Aroma is quite sweet and malty with notes of toffee, lemon, vanilla, cinnamon and ginger. Flavour is very much like the aroma: sweet, malty, spicy and hoppy, with hints of oak, whisky, biscuit and nuts. Mouthfeel is slightly oily with lively carbonation and a long bittersweet, spicy finish. This is a very good barley wine, well-balanced and with the alcohol nicely integrated so that it doesnt detract from the flavour.

2012.   Sweet aroma, though not overpowering or cloying; maybe a hint of raisin or cherry.  Sweet, malty flavor, very much like the aroma with a bit of breadiness and some alcohol burn.  Flavor sticks nicely to your tongue.  I like this one.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours ruby to brown with a small off white head. Aroma is superb. Very floral with deep toffee and dark fruit notes. Reminiscent of a muscat. Taste is a little too boozy and prickly for my liking. Carbonation is a touch sharp but the flavours come together nicely. Deep caramel biscuit with floral undertones and a resinous grape-like note throughout. Loads of raisin in there. Solid brew

2010 bottle. Caramel malt, toast, raisin, and boozy aroma. Cloudy dark amber color with a small beige head. Tastes for all the world like the Risa Opal candy I used to eat in Iceland when I was a little kid. It was a strong anise flavored candy with a hint of menthol, and not very sweet. A sort of medicinal cough drop flavor that Icelanders loved, but Americans would probably hate. The flavor was such a blast from the past that it was a little freaky. Full smooth body.

Draft/snifter..
Faint but sweet malty aroma.. Noticeable booze hint..
Nice dark amber color..
Well carbonated, smooth and creamy..
Malt, Carmel, honey, raisin and a warming alcohol background on the taste. 
Balanced and finished nicely

This was the 2012 Otsuchi commemorative bomber.  Aroma of molasses, apples, raisins and a hint of cotton candy.  Gorgeous clear garnet beer with thin tan head.  Medium to heavy sweetness. Strong but well placed alcohol.  What a phenomenal collection of flavors in the finish.  Raisin, molasses, leather, pipe tobacco, brown bread.  Wow!  The very full body is balanced by a fairly effervescent carbonation.
Bottle of 2010. Pours a tan brownish smaller head. Smells tastes of alcohol caramel hard cider sweet turning tart nice tingle on tongue. Very awesome beer not hot nice mellow taste

2009 vintage opened 20120427. Man, this has improved greatly with age. When I tried this fresh it was sooo hot and just knocked me over. Now it has mellowed very nicely. Some sherry and oxidized notes, a little bit of cardboard, some heat follows as it warms up. Should have been a sipper but didnt last long

Old Stock Ale by North Coast Brewing
12 oz bottle 4-24-12
Pours reddish brown with big off white to tan head and medium retention.
 Rich sweet malt smell with hints of caramel and light hops alcohol is noticeable but not bad at 11.9%.  I love this beer and thank North coast brewing for doing a great job with this Ale, I have had this beer many times and always stock up when released hope to do a 3 yaer veridical some day if I can save some LOL.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2012 Pours a deep amber-chestnut brown with some off-white head.  Aroma and taste is rich and sweet...syrupy and walnut.  Some slight off flavor, likely due to handling/temp over the last 2 years, but not detracting from the overall beer.  FLavor is deep and really coats the mouth and lingers.  A great beer, I love this style.

Notes: 2010 bottle opened Apr 12

Update:  2012 bottle fresh in Apr 12...same great beer without any off flavors and slightly boozy finish.

2012: Clear dark ruby red short head with a ring/some lacing
Perfect carbonation,initially had some bannana ripe fruit carmel,vanilla cherries.
Flavor is similar with complexity with more cherry noticable but mostly fruit carmel hops on the complex mild  light refined citrus side some earth,very slight funk, light floral slightly peppery like white pepper maybe.Tastes strong and lacks much boozy alcohol.Has some woody dryness towards the end but all works out pretty nicely.Overall:Cherry/Carmel.Sweetness with floral refined citrus/fruit.

pours copper with a thin white head that is dissapates quickly.aroma is boozey with dark fruits,caramel and malt with a touch of wood.sweet malty flavor thats boozey and metallic and finishes a little hoppy.medium bodied with an oily mouthfeel.this was a 2012 and i feel a little age will make this quite solid.give a rerating on this in another year.

Bottle, 2009 vintage. Pours a dark maroon, with an ever so small head. Aroma has a nice malty sweetness, with some notes of caramel. Flavour is dark and dried fruits, with candi sugar, toffee and notes of coffee, all nicely balanced.

Bottle. Amber color with tan minimal head. Smells like a fruity liquor. Taste very alcoholic. Have a bit of an alcoholic burn aftertaste. Medium body with a sticky texture. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle poured into a standard pint glass.  2012 Vintage so this will be a young tasting.  Pours clear dark ruby red mahogany with a one finger off white head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma of fruits pear, a little apple, fresh baked bread, alcohol, caramel, a little grassy and a little woody.  Nice complex flavor profile.  Starts with your usual prune and raisin combo, moves through to fresh ripe green fruit, some caramel sweetness and some breadiness.  The alcohol is very apparent but not necessarily in a bad way.  The finish lingers for ages and coats your mouth like a syrup.  It doesnt feel overly syrupy when drinking but it is apparent in the aftertaste.  Theres a bitterness to balance it all out.  Seems less hoppy than a young Bigfoot, at least on the nose, and seems more true to the style to me.  Very tasty beer.  Now I need to cellar some!
On tap at Brouwers, Hard Liver. Pours dark ruby with no head, good lacing. Smell is cherry, deep red fruit, strong, pear. Taste is fruity/juicy, citrus, and very little alcohol present. Solid.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2015 2010 bottle, five years old. Pours no head on a cloudy brown body. The aroma is dry hay, grain, dirt, and super ripe plums. The taste is super sweet: fruits, caramel and candy with a little alcohol heat at the end. The texture is soft and still fizzy. 

Four years old now. Almost no head on a dark and cloudy straw colored body. The aroma is mostly grain, just a hint of fruit. The taste is quite sweet but no more alcohol heat. I didnt change the rating but I liked the 2010 bottle better in 2012.----

Over a year of sitting in the cellar. Lets see the change.
2010 Bottling

Poured into a tulip glass. Hazy copper, half finger of head, quickly gone though.

Still smells like lots of ripe fruit: apple, orange, pear. Theres more malt to smell, dry grains.

Tastes sweet, malty, a pear and cider. Ends as a bitter sweet combo. Alcohol hidden.

Heavy body, sticky texture, low carbonation. Lasting heat but not "alcoholy".

It tastes better than a year ago. Very complex and drinkable for a high ABV.

---
2010 Bottling

Poured from bottle into 200 mL tulip glass. 1/4 inch dirty white head developed and quickly faded. Rust/amber color, not quite transparent. Noticeable carbonation.

Smells bright, new fruit with pear and apple most apparent. Under that is malt. Quite pleasant. 

Taste like alcohol, caramel and malty sweetness. The taste lingers in the mouth for awhile afterward. Almost like the beer version of port.

Syrupy and fairly carbonated. It is heavy on the tongue.

For its style it is good. One bottle is plenty to enjoy for awhile. I have a few more of these that are going to sit in storage for a few years, maybe even a decade. Im excited to see how time changes it.

On tap at Square Burger McKinney.  Pours a deep copper with a thin tan head.  The aromas are dough, closet aromas, musk.  The mouthfeel is doughy, sticky and has a heavy body and medium carbonation.  Cheers!

On tap at the Stags Head I had towards end of night and this is probably the culprit of putting me over the edge into drunk town.  anyways i deciphered my notes and this was a pretty sweet brew.  its fruity and sticky tasting of raisins, caramel, molasses, chocolate, plums, and coffee.  there is nice amount of hopping and malt.  a sipper that i pounded.

2011 Vintage. Pours bright mahogany red with a very quick fizzling tan head. Smells like caramel with a strong bready backbone and hints of woody hops. Taste is caramel and hints of toffee with some warming alcohol notes at the end. Full-bodied with a smooth texture and soft mouth-carbonation, North Coast Old Stock Ale (2011) finishes with a touch of woodiness coupled with some sweetness and alcohol burn. Perfect for aging; I have another bottle for that purpose.
Hasselnötsbrun öl med ett gulvitt skum. Doft av plommon, sirap och lite för mycket alkohol. Alkoholen döljs något bättre i smaken som är mycket torkad frukt och lätt kryddighet. En kraftfull öl.

A copper brown beer with an almost disappearing, beige head. Aroma is full of overcooked fruits, plums, syrup, bananas and berries. Taste is strong, raisins, dark dried fruits, some bananas and drying herbs, alcohol is there, but it doesnt taste. Full bodied, but not sticky. Very intensive, slightly heavy, overcooked fruity beer.
Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm reminds me of Thomas Hardys ale.  Beautiful malt profile hides the high alcohol content

Thanks James McBrewer! Tasted from bottle into standard pint glass. Poured a mostly clear dark reddish-brown color with weak off-white foam and some nice Belgian lace. Aromas of caramelized malts, brown bread, very faint hops, some fruity ale yeast esters, smooth alcohol. Malty sweet flavor, notes of toffee, some burnt toast melanoidins, subdued tangy hops bitterness, warming but well-concealed alcohol. Medium body, low carbonation, sticky and syrupy mouthfeel. True-to-style, well-crafted and tasty barleywine.

(Bottle, 0.335 l - 2009 vintage, at Pikkulintu, 20120316) The beer poured deep reddish brown and hazy. Its head was small and white. Aroma had malts, raisin, dried plum and caramell. Palate was full bodied and sticky with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, raisin, sugary sweetness, treacle and bitterness. Aftertaste was sweet, raisiny and bitter. Too sweet for my taste but otherwise decent brew.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2012 Sweet, fruity aroma with berries, bananas, raisins and other dark fruits, molasses, caramel, and hops. It is quite stunning. The mouthfeel is slick, with a medium body and a syrupy texture. The taste is sweet and also bitter, with the banana esters and some eggnog notes becoming more prominent as the beer warms up. It is heavily malted and almost feels like a meal, but I absolutely loved it.
2006- A complex beer with a high viscosity that makes for a slow drink and contemplation of the various ingredients.  Has a lot to offer.

Sweet caramel nose with a hint of alcohol. The taste strts with more of the same. Sweet caramel malt, with some roasted notes in there. Next comes chocolate, plum and coffee. The warmer this one gets the more complex it becomes. Well balanced, the alcohol is well hidden.

08 vintage!, aroma, basement malty esters, some brown sugarys too.
color, meduim amber hue small white head, glass lacing
taste, Alcohol burn somewhat at first, then the malty profile takes over the age, adds a old funk taste I cant put my finger on it exactly, but its good.
overall, found a 4 pack dating 08 was 12.5 alc by vol., a rich intersting brew!
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text:
Color: Dark Amber
Aroma:Alcohol sweetness, plums
Body:Caramel malt, bready and a hint of bitter hops
Finish:Slightly dry and warming alchol feeling
Over-all/Mouth-feel:Rich medium, over all a big beer.

2009 vintage (11.5%) poured from a 12oz bottle to a brandy snifter.  Smell bursts from the bottle.  Lots of sweet darkness - toffee, caramel, milk chocolate.  Theres some other subtle nuances that Im struggling to pin down.  Touch of booze.  It pours a murky dark burgundy with a slim tan cap that fades quickly.  The taste is roughly 95% malts at this point.  Big burnt caramel and a tiny touch of oxidation that keeps things interesting.  Finishes off a bit nutty, no real detectable booze in the aftertaste.  Carbonation and body have held up remarkable well.  Overall, a big beer that can stand the test of time.

Red, dark amber with a thin off-white head that melts away quickly. The aroma is quite strong - nuttiness, sweet fruit, alcohol, and even an extremely sweet red licorice aroma are all present. Flavor is a bit strong on the alcohol, maltiness present but somewhat overtaken. There is little bitterness - just a hint of hops - very nicely balan
Clear ruby copper pour, lacing head. Cream and vanilla malt aroma and flavor. Strong ale with cinnamon, caramel and maple. Hot alcohol and a strong boozy finish. Good stuff.

Long Island, NY - 12 oz. bottle 2011 vintage. This was my first barley wine an it was interesting. It poured a deep cloudy burgundy color with moderate white head. Aroma was of wine, dried fruits and some malts. Taste was along the same lines, but wine/alcohol taste was overwhelming for me and my preference. It is a good brew but a style I would stay away from.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle. Pours a translucent roan brown color with a small beige head that fizzes and rapidly dissipates. The aroma is moderate in strength with toffee, malts and dark breads. The taste is malts forward with toffee, caramel, colas and lots of nutty sensations; walnuts, pecans and filberts. Additionally, in the tasting, there is a lightly spicy hop presence, much brown sugar sweetness and a good dose of hot alcohol. The palate is silky smooth with carbonation that is lively and prickly. Finishes long with lingering heath bar. Overall: A very tasty complex brew, but a bit hot. I bought a four-pack to cellar, lets see how long this can make it.

From a bottle (2011): Dark copper color with a one finger off white head. No lacing. Moderate carbonation. Smells interesting, like plum, malts, and funky  white cheese. Taste different, like sweet malts, brown sugar and a hint of vanilla. Texture is a little oily, and the after taste is drawn out with warming from the alcohol and a touch of sweetness. This is not overly sweet, and the alcohol is not overly present for my taste. Although, those two things are what seem to define this ale. I would like to try old vintages of this ale to see what flavors come out, I am sure it will not disappoint.

12 oz. bottle from Julios Liquors. $4.75 with a Wild Six discount. 2010 vintage. Snifter used. Muddy water color into a snifter. Average CO2. Small ring of head that left nearly no lace at all. Nose is prune, plum and dates. Barley Wines get better with age and I know this is no exception. Flavor is REAL sweet with dark fruit, molasses, brown sugar, caramel malt, toffee, honey and some faint alcohol notes. Full body, thick, oily texture, soft carbonation. Have to admit BWs arent my favorite style, this one is still good.

Deep ruddy brown pour. 
Aroma is caramel, chocolate, dried fruit, raisins, spice, pepper, yeast, esters. Flavor is very sweet; caramel, dried fruits, yeast, metallic and smoke hints. large bodied, sticky sweet finish.

(Bottle 2011 vintage)  Pours a murky dark amber with a full finger tan head that fell fast.  The nose is very subtle for a barleywine, but had hints of earth and some prune/plum that was very pleasant.  Its very rich in the mouth with a pleasant caramel malt flavor up front, and a very nice warming from the alcohol at the finish.  The flavor sticks around for a while, but thats not a bad thing.  An excellent choice on a very cold night!

On tap. Pour is fairly murky dark golden Amber with a modest off white head in this glass. The nose is dark fruits, caramel, toffee, Brown sugar, and booze. The flavor profile is sweet, bitter from the hops, caramel, toffee, sticky, boozy, but a little on the simple side.

Bottle 355ml vintage 2009 @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours murky brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel and toffee. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Bottle (2010 vintage).  Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a small beige head.  Boozy aroma with caramel and toffee malts.  Flavor is quite sweet with bitterness in the finish.

2011 Version

Aroma: Hints of earthiness, basement aromas and vegetation, but with elements of bread, too.
Appearance: Cloudy dark amber with minimal head.
Taste: Heavy sweetness tempered by a light sourness in the finish.
Palate: Full body, thick, oily texture, soft carbonation, long finish.
Overall: I know its supposed to taste like this, but its much too malty for my taste. I assume aging it would help, but the maltiness is cut with hoppiness, but not enough to be a good balance for me. The alcohol is readily apparent, too, which tends to be a downer for me.

Pours a fairly dark reddish-amber with a quick off-white head and nearly no lacing. Nose is fairly weak for a barley wine, with soft coffee, milk chocolate, and light hops making for an interesting introductory note to this ale. Flavor blossoms beautifully, with refined chocolate and caramel jumping out on the front and fading to toffee on the back. Hops are relatively subdued but balance the malt very well. Alcohol is very well hidden for 11.9%+. This is a supurb example of the style and of what fine beer can be.

Bottle, 2009 vintage. Pours a deep red with an offwhite head. Smells of citrus, prune, and hops -- but all rather subtle. Tastes of cherry, vanilla, prune, wood and indescribable bliss. A medium bitterness tempered with a heavy syrupy sweetness producing a barleywine to be savoured. Perhaps slightly too sweet at this age.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2011 2009 vintage bottle enjoyed at home
Pours redly brown, no head. Very nice lacings though. Smells of caramel, prunes, toffee and malts. Taste is super malty, tons of sweetness. Some heavy dry fruits and caramel too. Smooth oily palate and a nice bitter finish. Totally a nice beer, but for me its a bit too much on the caramel side and pretty heavy to finish alone.
2011. Pours a red-brown with a thin, dissapearing head and aroma with notes of alcohol and malts. Flavor is sweet and of alcohol, malts, and dried fruits with a long lasting, bitter finish.

2011, bought in Whole Foods, Monterey, Calf. Pours reddish brown
with little to no head. Aroma is sweet and fruity with hints of
strawberries. Initial taste is sweet with some bitterness, alcohol well
masqueraded ! Finish is crisp and dry and very 
pleasing. Expected more flavor, and that was disappointing. Cheers !

2011 from a bottle to a pint glass.  Pours a rich amber, almost orange.  Limited, and quickly disipating head.  Little fruit on the nose, with a rich, warm sweet taste.  Very easy drinking for the abv.
Very dark amber pour, almost no head. Fruity nose, great sweet barleywine taste. Not too boozy tasting, especially for the abv.  Light mouthfeel, dark fruit on the back end.

Bottle 2009 , thanks to meilby. Pours amber with a small off white head. Aroma of malt, hay, yeast and oksidized malt. Flavor is sweet and warming with some fruitiness, yeast, malt, caramel and malt. Nice barlet wine.

Pours a brilliant ruby red color with no head to speak of. Aroma is of dark cherries, dark fruits, and alcohol. Taste is phenomenal!!!! Delicious notes of caramel, vanilla, cherries, and alcohol heat. The palate is so smooth with great carbonation. And absolute must have!! Cheers
From a bottle. Pours dark brown with cream head. Not a huge aroma, some toffee and caramel. Taste is incredible, chocolate toffee cake, so rich and tasty. Pretty big alcohol burn. A real treat

I drank this at 6:25 am with a breakfast platter with steak from Popeyes. North Coast Old Stock Ale 2011 edition has a rather thin, beige head (in the hi-ball glass I used) and a hazy, orange-amber appearance with a few bubbles and some lacing. The aroma is of prunes, alcohol, and brandy. Taste is of plums or prunes even, alcohol, brandy bitterness, and cream sherry sweetness, with an overall strong alcohol presence across the sip. The mouthfeel is thick, dense, and heavy, and North Coast Old Stock Ale finishes semi-dry, alcohilic, and challenging. I really enjoyed sipping this with an early-morning breakfast, and I recommend it, although not necessarily with breakfast.  RJT

Bottle.  A clear reddish golden beer with a very thin, disappearing head.  Aroma is very sweet, lots of citrus, cherries, malts.  Taste is heavy sweet, almost cloying but not really unpleasant.  The alcohol is well hidden.  Has a honey-sweet finish, with maybe the smallest bit of dryness on the end.  Medium-full bodied, syrupy, with moderate carbonation.

2009 vintage.  12 ounce bottle purchased over a year ago at Sun Devil Liquors in Phoenix ($3.19).  Pours a muddy reddish-brown hue with only a half-finger of beige foam that soon disappears altogether.  Aroma of sweet creamy toffee, dark fruits (raisin and cherry), butterscotch, and bubblegum.  Complex flavor of very rich caramel, lots of dark fruit, port wine, and hints of creamy chocolate and booze.  Sweet but still far from cloying.  Surprisingly soft mouthfeel and lighter body considering the very high ABV (which is actually well hidden).  A nicely complex and readily drinkable barley wine.  (1533, 644)

12oz bottle. 08 vintage courtesy of wavers1.
Pours hazy light brown, with a few bubbles, and a thin ring around the outside edge. Aroma is toffee, and caramel. Body is full, and smotth. very easy drinking. flavor is again toffee, caramel, with hints of chocolate. Incredibly smooth, no alcohol heat whatsoever. Clean, malty finish. Wish I had a few more of these around!

Bottle  (2011) -  Where do I start?  While I loved the smell, appearance, and mouthfeel of this beer, the powerful taste of sweet syrup just couldnt be ignored.  It is possible that I got a batch that hadnt been handled properly.  Oh, certainly I know that Im in the minority here, but I know barley wine.  I absolutely love Old Foghorn and Bigfoot, but this was freakin ridiculously sweet....at the moment of tasting it.  Maybe similiar to someone on a salad diet drinking a coke for the first time in months, .... and it tastes so SWEET.  I may store this and re-rate after some time.  Merci beaucoup.

Taste is caramelly sweet, but not overwhelming, in the finish an alcoholic sweetness enters as well. Aroma of prunes and other dried fruits. Colour is dark brown with a reddish hue, head formation is modest, but what little there is, is off an off-white colour. (Bottle, 2009 vintage)

Vintage 2007. Shared bottle @ Cardinal. medum/dark amber in color with smooth carbonation. Aroma full of malts and caramel. Smooth carbonation, and smooth malt richness. Great vintage, and one of the best barley wines Ive ever tried!
2011 bottle. Deep mahogany amber in color with a thin tannish color head. Nice balance of maltiness with a bitter hint in the finish. Notes of dried fruit (cherry, fig, date, raisin).
2009 - Hazy brown with light brown head - malt and some alcohol in the aroma - a very nice malt taste, with hints of alcohol in the back - very nice
Reddish brown color with a thin head. Smells great, raisiny sweet and some alcohol. Taste some sweetness first and alcohol at the end.

12oz  2011 bottle, pours a clear dark amber/copper with a nice off white head, aroma is sweet with a hint of booze and malt, the flavor had a nice malty front end with dark fruit and booze in the finish, some chocolate as well comes through, pretty darn good stuff.

Pour is a darker brown not much head. smell is kinda sweaty salty and figgy.
Taste is figgy a little ripe pear little hay good mouthfeel. lots of alcohol though.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2012 A -  pours deep reddish amber with light head and some lacing. 

S - Aromas off light floral hops, subtle dry grapes, light roasted notes, and quiet dark fruits raisins dates

M - . Low carbonation with great  mouth feel. Smooth transitions in the tastes. Slightly oily.

T - Nose has slight orange and a smokey oak cask and dry white wine. Strong molassas and dates, very sweet. Some toasted malts and caramel and light floral hops. Good barley wine. 

O - Great beer, very  complex with nice light hops, grapes and white wine, dark dried fruits and mild earthy oak notes. Boos well handled.  

My Score - 7/7+

Pours a cristal clear, reddish-brown.  Looks beautiful.  Aroma is fantastic, lots of dark, dried fruits, caramel, slight alcohol...  The flavor is much of the same.  Sweet caramel tones are well balanced with the sharpness of the alcohol and raisin flavors.  Very good beer.

2010 bottle.  Tannish brown pour with very little head.  Nose has some toffee, dark fruit but really is dominated by the alcohol.  Taste is even more.  Not well hidden.  I had a 2011 first and was hopping the 2010 mellowed out but it really didnt.  Some lingering bitterness as well.  Wouldnt mind tying one from 2008 or earlier.
Nice deep amber color. Thin dense head that laces all the way down. Great Carmel nose. Warm and yummy all the way down. Yumm.
UPDATED: OCT 23, 2011 2011 version, Bottle, pours brown clear with tan head. Aroma is figs, alcohol. Sweet taste. Good
Bottle from WOB.  I hope this gets better with age, because I love barley wines and this is not a good one.  Caramel, booze, and fizzy evervescent notes......

2011 version.  Pours a clear brown.  Aroma of dates, molasses, almonds and malt.  Taste is a little spicy with generous sweetness and a pretty smooth palate.  Pretty good, but its a bit heavy on the date flavor and sweetness for me.
Draft at CAH, Pours a medium brown with some head and lacing, nose is big malt with slight vanilla caramel and brown sugar. Finish is mild hops with little bitterness.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2012 Bottle bought @ Systembolaget and consumed on October 13. 2011 vintage. Pours chestnut brown with a brownish head that quickly dissipates without leaving any trace on the glass. Smell is very subtle with some rubber, alcohol and metal. Taste is very sweet and intense with lots of prunes, figs, dates, alcohol and brown sugar. Its quite vinous. Finish is sweet and slightly bitter and lingers in the mouth for quite some time. Nice barley wine but nothing too fancy.Re-rate! 2012 vintage. Strong sweet malty and fruity smell with caramel, dried fruits and alcohol. Sweet malty taste with dark bread, golden syrup, alcohol, dried fruits and hints of citrus zest. Round slightly sticky sweet mouthfeel. Sweet and tiny bitter finish with bread, caramel, dried fruits and alcohol. Have had this twice now and finding it too intense to be great both times Im starting to think I should age this a couple of years to see if it calms down a little. Will re-rate if trying a cellared bottle in the future

2011 Bottle. Aroma of raisins and brown sugar.  Pours a woody brown color with thin tan head.  Taste is rich.  Some raisin, molasses, and pine resin. Overall a nice deep flavor, without being over the top.

12oz bottle 2010 edition. dark amber/brownish color with off white almost coffee colored head. the aroms is of a strong ale with dark fruit possibly plums and a hint of cherry. sweet flavor of malt and the dark fruit but that initial alcohol burn was amazing..great snifter drink.  has somewhat of a bready yeast kick to it enhanced by the fruit and alochol. great beer.

Smells bready, raisionous cherry, with a good alcohol note in there.  Nice sized head.  Color is a hazy brown/red color.  Exceptionally smooth.  Some hops, but not a whole lot of hop bite.  Has the lively hints of an American brewer.  Quite a bit of sweet notes, which melt away the initial shock of alcohol.  Tasty and clean aftertaste.  I would have preferred less alcohol burn, but that seems to be the only qualm here.  Thanks North Coast for making my 200th rate totally worth it.  I couldnt have done it without you.  Enjoyability 5/5.

Bottle.  Aroma of sweet caramel malts.  Really has a strong flavor that resembles teriyaki sauce with a lot of soy sauce in it.  This would make a good marinade.  Light body.  Medium light carbonation.  Alcohol is masked very well.

8/18/11. Pours dark mahogany color with a thick khaki head. Huge malt aroma, roasted nuttiness and something else that I cant seem to put my finger on. Sweet malty taste slight fig and raisin aftertaste left in my mouth, no hop presence in this barleywine that I can tell of. The Abv is somewhat noticed but isnt overwhelming. Nice thick mouthfeel, going to sit two bottles back for a while and see how they develop.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2013 Finally a barley wine that doesnt blow you away with something thats over the top and out of balance. Pour a mahogany brown with a very light head, although carbonation is just right. Aroma is fairy average. The primary flavor is malt. Had this previously and liked it a whole lot more, but this time around is leaves me unimpressed. Update: sampled at 18 months and this ages well. Developing subtle complex flavors that work well. Alcohol burn is there, but it works with the beer fine.

Bottle from Great Spirits. 2010. Pours rubyish with 2 fingers of khaki head. Kind of a sweet note on the nose. Taste is sugary and boozy. This one will knock you on your ass if youre not careful. Barley Wine is not a fave style but this pretty solid.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Glowing reddish-brown with thin off-white head and very little lacing.

Aroma: Toffee, plum, cherry and light English hops.

Taste: Very sweet malts with toffee, butterscotch, plum and cherry. Light spicy and floral hops on the the finish that do nothing to cut the sweetness, along with more medicinal cherry. There are some nice flavors to be found here, but just too sweet.

Palate: Thick and chewy body with low carbonation. Nicely warming but with a cloyingly sweet finish.

Overall: Sweet and boozy. Maybe I would like this better with a couple of years on it. As is, I will pass in the future.

Aroma of rum cake, raisins, caramel apple and almonds. Appearance is bruin with light tan head. Flavor really emphasizes the almond/vanilla character with some muted fruits. The palate is bubbly. Very good,

Bottle 12 fl. oz. A clear dark red-brown colour with a small beige head. An aroma of caramel, alcohol, raisin,  dates and wood. The taste is sweet. A medium to full body, oily texture, soft carbonation and a long duration. A really nice barley wine already. Should be even better with time. I will put some aside.

Aroma of dark fruits, cherries and alcohol.  Pours murky and bright reddish-brown with a lot of carbonation but no head after the initial pour.  Tastes of champagne, dark fruits, and alcohol.  Its hard to taste because the fumes get up my nose.

an above average Old Ale. This falls in line with North Coasts nack for providing solid "everyday big beers" This beer does get better with age, and I personal like it best with 3 plus years. I rated the palate a bit low because I find until it hits about 3 years I find this beer "feels" over carbonated although it really isnt. Its just a mouth feel issue for me I suppose. Its a great find on the shelves if you happen across a couple year old bottles wearing a nice coating of dust. This beer ages just fine on a stockroom shelf. If your new to the style and find it fresh, do yourself a favor and split the 4 pack, 2 fresh 2 saved in a dark cool place for a rainy day a couple years down the road. You might find just find that you like it fresh and love it aged!

Clear Ruby pour with 1 finger tan head. Not much nose just a little subtle sweetness. Honey maple malt front. Medium body.  Semisweet grapey finish. Not too sticky not too Boozy.

On tap at Beer Revolution. either the 2010 or the 2011 release. Id like to try one that been aged for a year or two.

2009 Version from bottle.  Aroma:  Heavy malt, roasted caramel, light grassy hop
Palate:  Viscous, smooth
Flavor:  Rich caramel malt attack with overripe orange and peach, and orange rind on the mid-palate.  Finishes with yeast, caramel and a dash of pepper-like spice (orange rind?).
Comment:  Not as good as the earlier vintages (or possibly my palate is moving away from this style).  It was pretty simple when first opened but 24 hours in the fridge brought out the fruit character.  This has enough weight that giving it a bit of air and time may benefit it.

355 ml bottle @ Craft Beer Co., London. 2009 vintage.
Rated on 20110720.
Pours hazy dark brown colour with minimal head. Aroma is strong with plum, some malts and hoppy ripe fruits and notes of caramel at the end. Flavour is is pretty much the same. A bit sour palate with a bitter finish.
5215

2010 vintage. Smells and looks a little like stale Coca Cola only browner. OK, that might be a bit harsh, theres also notes of liquorice and chocolate, in fact it reminds me a lot of a milk chocolate coated sweet liquorice candy that is somewhat of a personal favourite. The taste is wondrously complex registering all over the tongue. Compared to when I had it a year ago, Id say some of the alcohol sweetness has worn of leaving more space for the other flavours to shine through. And although I liked it a lot then I like it even more now.

010 version. Deep mahogany color with loads of roasted butterscotch and some wood in the nose. That butterscotch flavor absolutely coats the mouth with a bit of sour tang in the finish. Hops add a welcome kick and some bitterness, but dont get in the way of anything. Picking up some grapes and late chocolate as it warms. Its a heavy hitter at more than 11% ABV, but the alcohol is just a pleasant warmth.

(Version 2011.  Thanks John!)  La robe rouge se coiffe dune belle tête.  Le nez est classique : le malt est dégoulinant de caramel et dorge sucré avec des parfums secondaires de fruits confits.  Une touche de sirop dérable pique les narines.  Le goût est très doux, fait de malts gras et de fruits en confiture et en bonbons.  Lalcool signale sa présence avec parcimonie.  La bouche est luxuriante, le pétillement bas et la texture veloutée.  La finale se fait sur de confortables notes maltées tendrement chauffées par un alcool fruité.  Vivement une autre bouteille pour la chambre froide.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2012 Superbe avec sa couleur presque rouge sang teinté de bourgogne. Se boit comme un porto, très sirupeux et sucré. Je décèle dans le fini la cerise noire. La version 2011 est à 11.9% et jai très hâte de la boire dans 5 ans. Aujourdhui, ça reste un excellent barley wine.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2013 2011 vintage. A great barley wine, indeed. Pours a beautiful slightly hazy reddish brown with a minimal tan head. Moving it around in front of a lamp shows a multitude of different nuances to the color. Great stuff. Aroma is rich - bready malts, dark fruits, caramel, cherry (which subsides a bit the warmer it gets), port-like alcohol. Taste is incredible complex, starting off with a  slight malty sweetness that then turns into a very nicely balanced bitterness - the only time the hops really come through - before ending in a very long sweet and round finish. It lasts forever! Body is surprisingly light yet still rich and full with a low but clearly present level of carbonation. This is a winner. Im picking up a few more for aging, for sure!

EDIT: I have since done 2012 and now 2013. 2013 in particular is sweeter both in aroma (butterscotch) and taste (butterscotch, maple syrup). Body is also fuller and richer, incredibly creamy. I wish there was an option to rate this per year as it does change quite dramatically. Rating reflects my opinion of the 2013 vintage.

Petite bouteille. Merci Patrick. Bière ambrée foncée peu de mousse, normale avec cet alcool. Le nez est classique avec des notes fruitées, sucrées et du caramel. La bouche est ronde, soyeuse, légère (faut le dire vite) elle descend bien, elle enrobe la bouche dun doux caramel.

Som med 3d-bilder tar det ett tag innan hela härligheten uppenbarar sig, innan man står inför fullbordat faktum: att Old Stock Ale är en fantastiskt detaljerad öl, med perfekt avrundade smaker och ett gyllene snitt mellan beska, sötma och fyllighet. För god för att inte överjäsas.
Pours cherry brown. No head. Sweet malty aroma patricks fruity. Thick bold well developed. This is a great. Brew a nice barley wine.

Bottle, thanks to hobbersr. Pours clear tawny brown, thin tan head, no real lacing. Nose is smoky lollipops, brandy, toffee, Nibs, and caramel. Flavours of tobacco, prunes, figs, a bit tarry. Lovely barleywine.
cloudy, amber, orange, brown, alcohol, caramel, medium body,.. worth a try.

Pours clear amber red with a eggshell coloured head. Aroma is rich and big, a sweet fruity smell almost like strawberry jam is dominant, but also a lot of candied sugar, toffee, raisins, vanilla and nuts. Certainly an interesting nose on this one! Follows up as a full bodied beer, thats both velvety and creamy. Taste is clean and filled with sweet flavours. Its boozy and warming but not alcoholic which is great!
Amber with little head. Nose massive sweetness from dark fruits, caramel malt. Taste sweet dark fruits and caramel malt and warming alcohol. Body full text thick, Finsih of with bittersweetness.

Draught sample pours reddish brown with minimal off white head.  Aromas are cherry, vanilla, raisin.  Taste is malty, cherry, and apricot. Body is full with a nice well rounded finish.  I expected this to be harsh, but it was not, and the alcohol was well hidden.  A very nice barley wine, to be sure.

2011 Vintage.  Notes from the 2011 BarleyBlind tasting:  Pours a reddish brown with no head.  Aroma is cherry, overripe fruit, sugar.  Taste is cherries, pine.  Quite smooth.  Alcohol is well hidden for a barley.  This finished a solid 4th behind Hog Heaven, Behemoth and Old Numbskull - surprisingly ahead of some strong candidates such as Third Coast, SNs Jack & Kens, and Stone Old Guardian.  Hog was the biggest surprise of the night, however this was in the running - very nice!

Tasted on 7/30/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Archer Liquors a while ago, 2008 vintage.  Pours a muddy, murky burnt orange with a thin tan head that leaves nothing more than a very thin collar.  The nose is sweet with tons of nearly burnt caramel, caramelized raisin and fig, with some of the burnt notes coming through as bitter.  The flavor is quite sweet with tons of caramel, the same caramelized raisin and fig from the nose, a hint of burnt bitterness, and some alcohol burn, but overall, nicely balanced.  The body is full, and almost creamy, with light carbonation and a long burnt caramel and candied fig finish with nice alcohol burn in my belly.

Ar: Raisins, prunes, butterscotch, clean alcohol.
Ap: Crystal clear tawny red - medium beige head with low retention, leaves a nice lacing.
T: Brandy alcohol quality - dark fruit, caramel, some spicy and earthy hoppiness - sweet, then clean finish - very warming, a bit spicy.
P: Full bodied, chewy, finish is dry.
O: A sipper - full malt and fruit flavors, nice hop profile - a real bruiser.

2003 bottle.   Pours murky brown with thin off white head.  Thin head dissipates quickly.  Looks like lake water.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, and dark fruits.  Taste of the same.  Thick mouthfeel.  Lots of booze in this one.  Nice alcohol burn in the finish.  Definitely a sipper.  Would be a good cigar brew.
Bottle shared with Deanso.  Brown pour with small tan head.  aroma is sweet dark fruits, Leather and toffee.  Flavour is strong dark fruit and raisins with a sweet alcohol finish.

2011 bottle, 11.9% ABV. Copper colored brew, with a muddy looking head. Smells of toffee, cream, and butterscotch. Tastes strongly of caramel, toffee, and some light bittersweet chocolate. Some notes of bourbon, or whiskey. That was a nice touch. Some baked wheat hints. Very tasty brew, smooth.

Aroma: very subtle, lots of alcohol in that smell
Appearance: rich red color, small head
Taste: very port; strong
Palate: holds its character; malty
Overall: wonderful, strong, classy beer

2010: Aroma is fruity, boozy, some notes of leather. Pours a dark brown. Taste is malty and sweet with a strong alcohol finish. Not too bitter. Fruity yeast notes and malty sweetness dominate this one. Taste that leathery-tobacco leaf. 
2011: Barely no nose. Faint fruit notes. Pours a transparent dark brown. Taste is much sweeter, much more intense. Lots of booze and heat. Notes of leather again. Much more bitter this time around. Really strong alcohol finish. Not the same roundness as the 2010, malt backbone isnt as strongly supported.

2010 vintage poured into a DFH signature glass. This is my first old ale! 
A - Dark copper/brown body, with a nice mocha head. Awesome lacing and retention. S - Im actually a bit puzzled by the smell. It reminds me of a tamed version of a scotch ale, with the caramel and toffee aromas. Very sweet malts, and candied dried fruits. I almost get a hint of raspberries in there as well. Alcohol is detectable. T - Caramel, toffee, raspberries, plums, figs, bittersweet chocolate, malt and booze.
