Those are all flavors I also use to describe barley wines, yet this taste so different from that style. Its very sweet, and the flavors are so well balanced yet complex. The taste really is a solid 5. O - Ive heard a lot about this beer and seen it on the shelves many times...but I always passed. There was one bottle placed on the mix a six rack at the local beer shop so I bit. This beer went beyond my expectations. Its a big, meaty beer but it also remains drinkable at such a high abv. I get so many different flavors, but I never get the impression that theyre being thrown at me. This is a world class beer. Exceptional stuff, I cant wait to see what age does to these.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2012 2011 bottle.  hard to deny the quality in this one.  nice mahogany pour, not too big of a head.  flavor has tons of toffee, caramel, pale malt, chocolate malt, dark red wine, and assertive but not huge hops.  finishes hoppy and alcoholy but very satisfying and warming.  i had this with food and the flavors came out more so than any other beer ive ever had basically, toffee and smokey overtones. this is one of the most "delicious" beers ive ever had.  sort of made bigfoot seem simple and wimpy.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2015 Bottle, 2010. Dark, clear red color with small head. Lovely look to this one! Caramel sweetness and bready malt in the nose. Some dried fruit and wooden touch as well. The taste is well balanced sweet malt with hints of vanilla, some raisins, plums and distant rumbling bitterness. Medium and oily body with light carbonation. Light bitterness in a long finish. A cracker beer for cold nights in front of a fire. Good stuff!

Re-rate, bottle 2011, May 2015: Muddy red color with almost no head at all. Less of a looker at this age. Bread and malt in the nose, with some background sweetness. The wooden touch is still there but the dried fruits have, er... dried out. The taste is sweet raisins, with some roasted hints and some bitterness. Medium body with light carbonation. I believe this is actually showing its age, it is slightly flatter than I remember it.

Poured a slightly brown reddish amber.  Caramel and cotton candy in the aroma.  Some alcohol was present.  Taste is quite complex with carmel, brown sugar, and some hops.  Balance is very good too.  Aftertaste is sweet with some butterscotch.

Color is brown.  Off white head.  Smells like a barleywine.  Weird that it is one.  I actually like this beer quite a bit.  Bit of brown sugar with some molasses.  Alcohol is well hidden for a 11.7 percent beer.  Shared this one with my boy Scotty.  Good stuff.

malt bomb, looks and tastes like a barley wine. I thought it was supposed to be an old ale. Its got a complex malt profile however, and hop flavors which you probably can never balance are present. One of the better barley wines out there. Alcohol is not well hidden however and may be masking some of the subtleties in this barleywine.

Bottle. 2007 vintage. Pours a dark copper reddish color with a light tan head. Swirling generates a nice darker tan head. Head settles and collars around the glass nicely. Caramel, toffee, biscuit, and slight booze round out the nose. This things smells sweet. Caramel sweet upfront. Some dark fruit flavors as well. Overall, rather sweet but easily drinkable for the abv.

355ml bottle from my beer cellar vintage 2008.
Not much head at all.  Almost no carbonation.  Amber colour.  Alcohol taste.  A good barley wine.  Worth aging

Poured a pretty dark amber color, decent head formation.  Aroma of fruits like grapes and peaches, with some caramel.  Taste is medium sweetness followed by alchohol with a touch of hop bittnerness.  Fuller bodied a lively carbonation.  A sipper for sure with a alchohol sort of scotch like finish.  Complex.  Like this.  But couldnt buy a case of this.  Aroma was a plus.

2011 vintage poured into an Old Stock snifter

Appearance- Dark reddish brown in color, almost merlot-like. Poured with about a centimeter of thin head, which dissapated quickly, didnt even leave a bubble after a few minutes.

Smell- Aroma of some caramel and chocolate, with a little bit of alcohol on the nose.

Taste- Caramel malt and alcchol heat in the flavor. a hint of licorice, maybe?

Mouthfeel- A little thin on the body, with a little bit of an alcohol burn on the way down. Not much in the way of carbonation.

Overall- A quality, old ale. Not a beer that Im going to want to drink another of, but a good beer to spend an hour with.

2010 bottle, pours dark reddish brown with white head.  Aroma has notes of caramel, toffee, dark fruit, some slight citrusy hops, with a nice full brown sugar note.  Taste is smooth with sweet caramel and toffee, bitter pine and slightly fruity, some earth, tasting pretty full with a nice slightly bitter finish that goes down way too smooth for 12%.

12 fl oz bottle from BOTW (Rochester), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 2010 Vintage.
App.:  Clear deep copper with a decent orange-tan head.
  
Aroma:  Strong caramel, booze, dark dried fruits, a touch of minty herbals, brown sugar, more alcohol, dark bread crust, molasses, and booze.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, fine, velvety effervescence with a few prickly bubbles.
  
Flav.:  Brown sugar, toffee, treacle, a little molasses, all big malt, warm, almost stinging alcohol, vanilla, a touch nutty, chocolate; sweet with good bitterness and an alcoholic wallop, with a fairly long, warm, sweet malt finish.

Way too boozy for my palate.  I dont think Im a fan of Barley Wines.

Crazy interesting, but probably does need to age a bit for the flavors to mellow. Pours reddish brown with thin head, really no lacing. Aroma is cinnamon raisin bread with a tinge of alcohol. Full-bodied, coats the mouth with caramel/molasses flavors. Intense malt, maybe a touch of spice and again a bit of alcohol once it warms. I enjoyed it, but am interested to see what it does with time.
Delicious taste considering alcohol content. Minimal head. Carmel raisin taste.

12oz 2010 bottle. I didnt realize this was a barleywine before I opened it, otherwise I would have let it sit around for a while. Burgundy color, minimal head. Very much a wine taste and smell, its nearly too harsh. Raisin aroma. Sweet taste, but after awhile the alcohol is noticeable for sure. Very malty in the aftertaste. It might be very quiet in this room, but the bubbles in the carbonation are loud! I cant help but feel like I should have hid this beer in the cellar and forgotten about it, Im sure Id have enjoyed it more.

Malzig-würzig-süßer Geruch. So gestaltet sich auch der Antrunk, dabei wenig hopfig, harmonisch, das Malz schließt alle aufkommenden Aromen ein. So auch die leichte Herbe, die im Mittelteil aufkommt und zum Abgang hin bitterer wird. Süffig-malzig-würziger Abgang. Danke an den Doppelbock! 9/10/11/13/9/11

Bottle pour into tulip. Sweet nose that didnt have too many discernible aromas to me. Maybe brown sugar or dark fruits. Pour was nice and dark brown, almost like a molasses color. The head was small and the lacing reminded me of the nesting pool for a Chinese fighting fish. The taste was nice but changed quite drastically as it warmed up. The taste to me was like an artificial raspberry with a slight bitter at the end. Alcohol was ever present as well as a nice brown sugar or caramelized sweet potato. Would pair well with any hearty fall meal.

Pour ruby brown slightly murky  creamy beige head decent lace. Aroma quite metallic, dark fruit, spice caramel, butterscotch. Taste abv very well hidden, dark fruit, raisins, caramel, butterscotch, spices, nice bitter balance, MF full sticky body mild carb. Very good stuff easy to drink for such a big beer.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2013 This one caught me by surprise. The first impression is the beautiful dark amber pour, the head being as delightful with a hint of brown. Aroma was rather sweet, consisting of what I would describe as a heath bar and a strong coffee with a dark caramel untertones. NOW, the taste wasnt as strong as coffee, but rather a light caramel followed by a bitter coffee-ness (new word?) and just a hint of the 11.7% abv. Only when it warmed down did the flavors intensify and become even more apparent, especially the caramel that was hidden in there with the warmth of the alcohol. I would most definitely buy this one again - though its a shame this is a limited release! Might I add this is strikingly similar to the Lagunitas Brown Shugga.

This is my first "Old Ale" style.

A: Head-What was there goes away fast. Color-Looks like well preserved antique cherry furniture.
S: Sweet, real sweet, like your first girlfriend. Caramello is JEALOUS! I sense a little spicey but I wouldnt call it sassy.
T: I dont taste two scoops of raisens, but maybe store-brand dosage. Not a lot of bite from the alcohol. A tad bitter, not like your mother in law but possibly your friends.
MF: Medium of the road on all accounts. Kind of slid down like an upside-down go-kart.
Overall: Ive had this style before Im pretty sure, but I dont remember when since I dont review EVERY beer I drink. I dont find it overly complicated, but Im new to this style. I like it for sure, however its just too new to make a strong statement about it.

Serving type: bottle
2007 vintage.  Cloudy brown with a light head. Caramel, tobacco, and raisin aromas; raisin and port like; nice big ale. On the sweeter side with less pronounced hops than an american barley wine.

No knowledge of this one, just bought it on a whim at VE.

Poured into a pint glass. Medium pour achieves a thick, one finger head that dissipates rather quickly leaving drapey lacing behind. Medium reddish amber.

Smell is unimpressive. Musty, formaldehydish.

Taste. First sip is nothing but sweet booze and caramel. Malty goodness. Hints of vanilla, toffee, burnt sugar etc. VERY boozy. Hot and spicy, with a peppery finish. Great example of the style from an American brewery no less.

SIPPER. Take heed.

This one should be laid down for a few years to lose the extreme spikes and blend into something much more balanced.

I bet this one turns out to be a star in a few years.

2010 vintage. 12 oz bottle courtesy of Chris, served in a snifter head-to-head with the 2009 Cellar Reserve Bourbon Barrel. Pours clear reddish brown with a small off-white head. The head fades instantly, leaving a tiny remnant and no lace. The nose has huge caramel and big hops, along with molasses and flowers. The flavour is quite sweet, but hops provide adequate balance, along with herbs and a hint of brandy. The finish is long and malty. On the palate, it is medium in body with a syrupy texture and minimal carbonation. Overall, a nice barley wine but nothing compared to its barrel-aged cousin. 2011-04-08

Bottle of 2009 Vintage @ Cask Pub and Kitchen in London. Pours a dark reddish color with a frothy beige head. Aroma is alot of dark fruit like rainsin and figs, along with brown sugar, caramel and honey like notes. Flavor is really rich with alot of dark fruit like the raisins, molasses, brown sugar, caramel malt, toffee, honey and some faint alcohol notes. The body is full with a nice creamy mouthfeel. Overall a really nice Barley Wine, that is more in the English Style of very sweet Barley Wines.

Hazy dirty brown body, light brown head. Aroma has lots of raisins, chocolate and alcohol, some dark hops and cookies. Flavour adds sweet malt. Smooth and oily, really well balanced. Perfect mouthfeel.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2011 Bottle, 2010. Very unique beer, complex flavor, but good balance. Noticeable alcohol burn, a bit syrupy. Bitterness is well balanced with a sweet flavor. Hard to describe this beer, certainly worth trying.

Poured with a dark amber color and a small, beige head. Oak cask, caramel, honey, hint of fruits like white grapes, peach, hints of vanilla. Dense, oily body. Sweet finish. Alcohol is present, but overall not intrusive. Good one.

This beer is perfect.  It pours a beautiful reddish brown with a foamy, lively reddish tan head.  Aroma is sweet sugars, malts, dark fruit, citrus... it smells like a damn bakery at 5:00am.  The taste is reminiscent of a good dessert wine in its complexity.  There are the usual yeasty, malty notes, but there are also bunches of dark ripe fruits, caramels, brown sugar, even pecan like flavors.  There are smokey oak notes, and even a very hidden but certainly present citrusy hop note on the finish.  There is a hint of booze at the end, along with a long warming effect.  This beer is so enjoyable is almost pisses me off.  I love it so much...

Pours a medium brown with lots of red showing though, light tan head, good retention and great lacing...The aroma is what really stands out here, balanced and strong, I get a whiff from several feet away. There is vanilla, dark brown sugar, bourbon, light cherries, really similar to a barleywine but sweetet and without a hoppy finish...The taste is equally as nice, bourbon, lots of vanilla, cherries, and a sligth alcohol finish. 

All around a super nice Old Ale that should be tried.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2014 2010 and 2013 vintages. Pours a cloudy dark orange, with a thin tannish white head. Aroma is weakly of malt and dark fruits. Taste is richer and lingers well, dark fruits and alcohol. Tasty with a kick. Overall, a thumbs up. Both vintages are very similar.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2011 12 oz bottle. Poured a clear dark amber color with a medium sized off-white head. Aroma was dried fruits, roasted malts, toffee. Flavor is quite similar, in that the dark dried fruits dominates, sweetness permeates. Alcohol, vanilla, mild oaked notes. Not a bad one.

Re-rated with a 2003 bottle (11/27/2011). So smooth, so good.

Original rating: 3/26/2011

0.33l 2009-bottle. Pours a deep red body with a thin bubbly side-sticking almost yellow-beige head. Aroma is lovely caramel sweet, hops, smoke and brown sugar. Medium-bodied and medium+ carbonated. Quite boozy at first, caramel- and brown sugar-sweet with a slight floral note. There is something about barlywines that normally is too sweet for me, and this was sweet, just not as sweet as i first would have thought. It also had a strong bitterness that equalized the sweetness. That combined with the warming alcohol made this a pleasant experience.

12 oz bottle, 2010 vintage.

It pours a beautiful, dark, deep red with a big white head that quickly dissipates with no lacing.

It is fruity in the aroma with a predominance of raisins. There is some caramel and sugar scents as well.

The flavor is pretty sweet. It tastes like raisins and oxidized fruits. It isnt the most pleasant flavor, it is rather pungent and cloying.

Despite being a year old it still seems hot with alcohol.

I have had a lot of great barleywines/old ales lately and this one fell on its face in comparison.

Serving type: bottle
Can really smell the alcohol, dark amber in color.  Can taste the alcohol, but it is rather smooth.

Pours a cloudy brown-red with minimal off-white head. Aroma is champagne-like fruitiness, herbs, orange peel. Taste is sweet, spicy and delicious. Strong but not as strong as the alcohol content. Suprisingly drinkable. I highly recommend this beer.

02-MAR-2011, botte in Orlando from Whole Foods.
Dark amber, clear with rreally low beige head.
Wow, wooden cigar nose with loads of bitter hops and sweet malts.
Dried fruits and orange peel.
Really hoppy with huge amounts of bitterness.
Long long bitter sweet liqor-like aftertaste.
I guess this is an american strong ale? But very close to a barley wine. I now see close enough to actually be caterogized as one.
One of the best of its kind:-)
Slightly boozy, but hey, its 11,7%. I can live with that.
Wonderfull brew. My kind of beer.

2010 Bottle picked up at StateLine... Poured into a snifter, not much head. Dark murky brown color. Aroma of some dark fruits, raisons, brown sugar. Taste is close to the nose... lots of dark fruits, raisons, figs, brown sugar, toasty but the alcohol stands out in the after taste. Probably would benefit from some age.. Medium body a little sticky. Overall: Nice barleywine.

Bottle to snifter. Copper red pour with a tight off white head which fades to a collar. Aroma is burnt sugars and malty with a warming booze scent. Taste is more burnt sugars and malt little pitted fruit and some caramel with again a warming booze finish. Palate is creamy and fizzy carbonation with a warm dry finish. This is very good, really want to sit on a bottle or two for awhile!

Slightly sweet, sticky plum aroma.  Pours an amber copper color with very foamy off-white head.  Dark plum and jam-like flavors meld wiht faint spicy hops in the background and an alcoholic warmth on the finish.  Thich, chewy body with a good amount of carbonation.  A fine sipping barleywine that commands respect but finishes clean.

Dark red colored with cloudy appearance, little vanishing yellow head. Sweet caramelly aroma with raisins, licorice, medicine, smooth dark fruits, vanilla and fruity-banana, rich one indeed. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is smooth as well with licorice, same herbal medicine here as well, thin grass and raisins with warming alcohol come up nicely. Excellent and complex brew.
Just drink this! Could use a few months to mellow but you probably wont  be able to wait. Complex,sweet and biting. the alcohol is up front and in control like a barleywine should be.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2012 2012 Rating
Appearance is not its strong suit.  Muddy water with very little head.  Aroma seems to have improved from what I remember, vanilla and bourbon - yum.  A little lighter in body than I expected, but a solid performer in this category.

2011 Rating Below
Not very complex.  I got typical barley wine here.. neutral aroma.  Pass on this one. 5/4/7/4/12
Formerly Rated in 2011: 3.2

2010 vintage. Ruby brown with a bit of head. Aroma is booze, dark fruit, brown sugar, candy, some hops. Full bodied, alcohol heat, a bit intense, some butterscotch. Definitely could benefit from some aging, but still pretty solid young.

12 oz bottle (2010 vintage). This is a boozy, syrupy English style barley wine that could really use some rounding and mellowing out. The pour was exceptionally fizzy with a small bubbled blank white head, and a very translucent body for such a strong beer. However, its mysterious honey-crimson color make it fairly intriguing. In fact, honey and oat, English cereal malts make the biggest impact in the nose aside from the thick mixed mild fruit esters. Also, molasses, dates, and maple syrup sweetness. All of this is fairly muddled, which for a hazy, whiskey-like nose in actuality. The body is hot, highly carbonated, and syrupy at the same time. This is not exactly to my liking. Fruit, molasses, honey, and oatmeal clump together in the beginning. This only makes way for more mild fruits, grainy whiskey malts, and potpourri hops which balance but do little to bring everything together. The finish is also balanced, yet hot. Some uniqueness and complexity save this one to an extent, but the truth is that youd be better served letting this one sit for a long while. Not quite there for me.

2010 Bottle.  Dark amber brown pour, little lasting head and a wonderful aroma of sweet prunes/plums.  Flavor is rich slick caramel, more prunes, slightly boozy and a great warming aftertaste that slowly sneaks up on you.  Great beer, may have to pick up a few to cellar.

2010 Bottle.  Aroma is very malty, caramel, roasty, molasses, raisin, woody.... can smell the alcohol too.  Appearance is a nice deep reddish brown with minimal head that thins quickly.  Taste is of heavy caramel/molasses, alcohol, sweet malts.... fairly full.  Had a bottle right away and one a year after... aged nicely after 1st year.

2009 Old Stock, drinking 2/22/11

Beautiful looking beer.  Deep mahogany with a three-finger, off-white, thick head.  Excellent lacing.  

Smells super sweet.  Definite alcohol presence but also some overripe apples and pears.  Interesting but the booze drowns out the nicer aromas.

Tastes very sweet as well.  Almost too sweet in that theres no offsetting balance in hops or weight.  Definitely high alcohol.  Caramel and the overripe apples and pears again.  

Drinks well but slowly.  Overall, a good strong ale but nothing to rave about.

Bottle @ home. Burgundy body with a small white head that quickly disappears. Very candy sweet malty nose with hints of raisins and cherries, also with mild hops. Very sweet, red fruity and malty body. Quite strong flavor thats initially fruity with the hops and bitterness following through on the finish along with a lot of booze. Definitely a sipper. [2010 Vintage]

im a little intimidated by the style, i usually dont really enjoy beers over 6-7%, just because they are usually way over the top in flavor, mouthfeel, weight, etc, but this was a pleasant surprise, was very easy to drink, had the usual barleywine color and aroma, like a west coast version its very hoppy but not as much as say, stones old gaurdian or victorys the flying mouflan, very smooth and malty but very balanced. One of the better barleywines.

Bottle 2001.  Pours a murky brown into the glass with no head.  Aroma is rich dark fruit and molasses.  Flavor is similar.  Luscious burnt caramel flavor with a very slight bitterness.  Almost zero carbonation, most likely from the long aging.  Really nice beer.

The aroma is of a roasted nut. Light caramel coloring when placed under the light. Has a sweet taste with a medium body. An almost creamy texture, you can tell this beer has 11.7% abv, this coming from the 2010 batch. Nice beer overall.

On tap - Holy Grail Pub. 
Amber brown pour with some white head. Aromas of dates and raisins - more of the same flavor with some warmth and sweetness. This is a damn good barley wine.
Not my favorite style of beer, but can appreciate the over the top of everything but still all in balance in it.

Good stuff here.  Pours a raisin brown with a nose to match.  Head is white and fleeting.  The aroma is rich with brown sugar, dates, and bourbon.  Complex with aged fruit, oak, and strong currant.  Alcohol present but not overbearing.  Excellent.

Nice dark pour, good amount of foam subsides quickly, smells a bit fruity.

Taste is sweet and fruity as well, almost like wine, with a nice hop kick to it.  Very smooth, something to sip on, but also very drinkable, abv is well hidden.  Definitely something I would get again, look forward to aging the rest of the 4 pack.

North Coast is rising on my list of favorite breweries, I expect nothing short of excellence and they deliver.

2010 vintage.

This beer appeared a gorgeous deep, dark maroon/brown, but had the most fizzy, soda-pop like head I have seen in a long time - that just didnt do it for me. Smells of raisin, sweet wheat and dark fruit, specifically dates. The taste follows, with a nice raisin sweet start, a malty dark fruit/date middle, and some booze heat to finish. The heat is well done, with just enough to get the job done. I also got a hint of vanilla near the end which was quite pleasant; it wasnt much, but it was there. Mouthfeel is good, with the carbonation helping to bring out the vanilla in particular. Syrupy coating after a swallow nice as well, to go with the sticky texture. Drinkability is pretty good for an 11% abv beer, but the tastes can become a jumble after a bit. One single of this guy is the right amount.

This is for the 2010 vintage. Pours a lovely ruby shade, with a small amount of dense light tan foam. Aroma is sweet and malty, caramel and some fruit (raisins, dates, figs), very inviting. Taste is very malty, with a noticeable alcohol burn partway through, more fruit like dates and figs, and just a bit bitter on the finish. Great stuff, possibly the best barley wine Ive had save perhaps for the 2006 Bigfoot.

Pours a deep mahagony with a nice tan head. Aroma is distinctly scotch/port-esque. Butterscotch and maple are highlighted in the malty nose. It almost burns if you inhale deeply. Smooth and creamy. Thus beer is not as sweet as I expected. You can definitely feel all 11.7% of the abv. The hop presence is enough to actually give this strong ale a rather crisp finish. In the end though you are left with a pleasent roasted malt residual flavor.
yeh, this is a great beer, just right for winter sipping, rather sweet but it takes that to get 11.7ABV.  Smooth, with plenty of caramel and malt.  No head and no lacing, slightly cloudy bronze color

This review is for the 2010 run. The aroma is chalky and malty, medium in body, but not overly enticing. The head is off-white and disappears as if afraid of its own shadow. The brew itself is a gorgeously deep brown. The taste malty and pleasant, but like a bomb going off, I received the most harsh sourness just after the first swig. I was certain that I had happened upon a bad bottle, but taking another, the sourness was not there. It did not appear again until much further into the bottle, and then much less severe. At the bottom of the bottle, the sourness was not to be found. I am certain that the sourness was an anomaly. Silky smooth on the palate, the carbonization is not strong. Overall, an enjoyable ale save for the random attack of sourness that I hope will not be in the next bottle I am sure to have.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2011 2010 vin 12oz bottle.  Pencil-thin, fresh, sandy head soon dissolves to a speck or two of foam.  Its an inviting amber color, though murky, but prettily translucent: a lot like looking though a gem, actually.  The taste surprised me because it is a pale blend, but it is a perfect one for my preference of stout.  While the ABV 11.7% - 30% more than the same brewers Imperial Russian Stout, Old Rasputin - subdues the nose to almost nothing (no - no boozy knee-jerk), the most prevalent aroma is coffee / toffee.  This beer forgoes the oil of Old Rasputin for alcohol but sacrifices nothing to satisfying the palate.  At this proof, this beer is made for sipping.  But each sip is for savoring.  
The glass empties to the last, most sensual sip - port notes.  The well-nursed "dregs" of a glass of  this barleywine are the most satisfying.  Exquisite!
Kind of lost on me.  Very sweet and malty with very little hops.  Maybe it needs to age a bit (2010 vintage).  Not terrible, but not particularly good either.

2010 bottle.  Pours a dark reddish-brown color.  Thin off-white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is toffee, raisins, cherry and mild grassy hops.  Flavor is similar, with slightly more pronounced caramel sweetness.  Warming, but not a significant alcohol burn.  Not as hoppy as most American barleywines--it really drinks more like a quad.  But very tasty.

2010 year.  Yes I know I pulled the trigger way to early on this one but really I was extremely happy with it.
The aroma is fantastic butterscotch, dried pineapple, a bit of booze.
The appearance great color, minimal carbonation reddish copper hue no head virtually at all
Taste malt sweetness followed with a nice brushing of hops to chase it and then back to the lingering malt and slight boozy warmth. This beer hides its ABV VERY well. 
The mouth feel is right on with what I expect of an English style Barley Wine right down to the slightly sticky lips after.

Loved this version. Still not sure I would shell out the crazy $26 a 500ml bottle for the Anniversary but this will be sought after by me from now on!

Review from notes, sampled 3/7/2008
This beer pours a dark copper with ruby highlights, and has a big fluffy mostly white head that impales itself to the glass on the way down. The Aroma is wonderful, caramel, raisins, dried fruits, slight bit of citrus hops, but mostly sweet smelling malt. Taste hits with the sweet malt and caramel up front, some hop twang in the middle, giving way to an alcohol burn at the end. Mouthfeel is sweet and sticky, ample carbonation. Great sipping beer. Tastes a little sweet, but that just made me drink it quicker.

2008 vintage purchased off the shelf just today for $5. pours a deep orange to mahogony body with a minimal light colored head, no lacing or spotting.  the aroma is nice, lots of sweet vanilla and caramel. the tasteis to match, with a lil bit of dusty age coming out there in the finish, nice and complex. good stuff, drinks amazingly easy considering its the 12.5% version. light but present carbonation, very sweet but not cloying at all, this is a great aged bw. cant belive i have passed this stuff by for so many years now.

Bottle at Jerrys.  Wow.  This is one for the books.  Opened up an 08 last night.  Pours amber with beige head.  Nose is lots of oak up front followed by malt, vanilla, dark fruits.  Tastes toffee, raisins, vanilla.  Much mellowed out over a couple years.  Finish pleasantly sticks around reminding first to take another drink, then to lament the loss.  Amazing.  Bought the last one to take home and stick in the closet for another year....if I can wait.

12 oz bottle: Vintages 07 and 09. Both pour a caramel brown with a nice head and great CO2 release. 07 is much more mellow with an aroma of dried fruit such as figs and raisins. 09 is more of a vanilla aroma. Big difference on the palate as the 07 was smooth while the 09 was more sharp and reactive. Overall 07 gets a 17 with 09 a 16 due to a higher alcohol flavor. Incredibly complex and interesting beer.

2010 12oz btl. Pours a deep mahogany with a decent white head. A sweet aroma of candied dark fruit, caramel, and alcohol. Slightly hot but palate overall is tasty. Lots of candied fruit, sweet caramel, and a hint of nuttiness. Spice of the alcohol is pleasant and warming. Pretty delicious overall.

2010 vintage:  Pours a very nice cloudy mahogany.  Aroma is nice, with dark fruits, caramel, chocolate, coffee, alcohol-the flavor doesnt quite meet my expectations set forth by my nose, yet as it warms, the flavor ever so slightly more-but not much.  Initially it tasted a bit bitter with herbs such as lavender and dark coffee.  I was surprised at the lack of sweetness, since most of the aroma contained some kind of sweet scent.  As it warmed it strengthened in its robust coffee flavor and alcohol.  Overall, not a bad beer.  Quite palatable and would not mind having another.
Tap @ blind tiger. Smells of raisins , cherry and oak. Pours a dark black purple color. Taste is sweet with a cherry chocolate bailys cream aftertaste. Easy to drink. Very good

WOW This is a beer. It made me realize what a light weight I am. Beer pour a beautiful clear caramel color. with a thick off cream head. Beer smelled great, it had strong hints of caramel, very robust. Beer Tasted great kind of like a golden ale. A good Beer with dinner

2010 bottle. Pours cranberry with small head that quickly fades leaving little lace. Nose of candy apple, oak, cherry and caramel. Taste of bourbon, caramel, and a hint of lime on the finish. I will pick up a few more to cellar for this can only improve as it mellowa with age. A very full mouthfeel and a long hot finish.

2010 vintage. Pours a clear dark orange color with a medium tan head. The lacing runs down the glass, but very slowly. The aroma is a great mix of vanilla, molasses, oak, dark fruits, cloves, and a mellow biscuit dough smell. The flavor is very well balanced, leaning on the sticky-sweet side. The bitterness and present, assertive, but not overwhelming. This is a very heavy beer, but goes down surprisingly smooth. The mouthfeel is creamy with a slightly tart undercurrent. The finish is faintly bitter. Overall, this an excellent brew.

2010 version appearance is a medium brown with a bubbly off white head aroma is raisin/ grape like and similiar to a quadrupel with a little bit of coffee slight alcohol aroma and some plum as well first taste is coffee then goes to a almost tart flavor then sweet raisin/grape and finishes pretty dry alcohol flavor reminding you of the eleven percent it is, a complex beer full of flavor, im really going to try my hardest to hold on to one of these for a year and see how it is, but right now that is looking grimm haha

2009: pours a dark amber with ruby highlights.  small off-white head that does not linger.  no lacing, no legs.  The aroma is of rich sweet alts, dark fruit, some chocolate, and caramel.  In the mouth it has a medium body, good carbonation and an alcohol afterburn.  The taste is like the aroma, dark fruits, rich sweet malts, caramel and chocolate.  Not a bad beer but one will be more than enough for me.

Pours nearly an exact shade of mahogany. Thin head with fantastic lacing. Aroma is of a multitude of dark fruits, taste is of the same with a boozy feel. Overall rather complex on the palate and very enjoyable.

Pours mahogany brown with a thin white head and fantastic lacing. Aroma is of white grapes, plums, raisins, Flavor is mostly of boozy fruit, but it is very complex. There are notes of raisins, grapes, plums, figs, and other dark fruits.

I just don´t get it. 2010 bottle. Pours brown-amber with big tan foam. Aroma is earthy, caramel, chocolate, eggy and alcohol. Taste is quite high sweetness, dark fruit, butterscotch and alcohol. Body isn´t as full as one could expect. Or is it just the alcohol that comes threw and makes it feel thiner. Palate is sticky and have some slickness to it if you get pass the alcoholic finish that overpowers any hoppiness. Soft carbonation. OVERALL: Too alcoholic tasting, the alcohol totally dominates the flavorprofile in this Barley Wine. And I´m not one to shy away from high alcohol beers but it should be masked by, first malt or even hops. And any low flavor of alcohol should only add to other flavors. This might be a beer for strickly cellering but how much better can it get when it´s crap somewhat fresh.
A hint of caramel with a smooth finish the alcohol is masked on finish by the slightly fruity flavor.  Overall, a very good beer.

09 bottle: dark brown ale with beige head. sweet toffee malts, smooth caramel candies with some butterscotch, raisins, musty mushrooms, tingly carbonation. sweet sugars stick to the lips, but actually fairly mellow some burnt coco notes, caramelized fruits, raspberries, boozey tartness. Booze is pretty well masked.

In short: A raisin pie dipped in caramel.  Nice big beer.
How: Bottle 12oz.  Consumed when about 2 year of age to compare with the two the Bas version of similar age
The look: Cloudy light purple-brown body topped by a beige ring of foam.  Lighter in color than both BA versions I had side-by-side with this one.
In long: The sweet nose is really a raisin pie.  I dont know if Ive ever had a beer that smelled so much like a raisin pie.  Taste is purely and simply a crusty raisin pie covered with caramel and butterscotch.  I dont know what else I can add to this simple description.  Finish has a strong alcohol bite with some fusel/metallic notes that prevented it from being more than just an excellent beer.  I was surprised to prefer the two different barrel aged versions over the regular Old Stock.  It was fun to site down and drink a bottle of all three versions side-by-side by myself.  And dont call me a drunk.  I prefer beer lover overachiever.

Deep ruby body.  Some mild hops, sherry, merlot, roasted malts.  Dark fruit, sweet red wine, relatively mild hop bitterness. Finishes with a mild warmth.  Medium palate.  Would have enjoyed it a bit more with dialed-up hops.
First Barleywine I tried. Very good. I am excited to try a few other Barleywines.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2010 Vintage 2010. Clear, dark mahogany with an off-white head that rapidly dissipates. Aroma of sweet berries, hops, and dark malts. Taste is sweet, but not too sweet, candy, caramel and fruit. The alcohol isnt really evident in the taste, but something about this lets you know its a heavy beer. Body is pretty thick. It does remind me more of a red wine than a beer. This stuff is quite good right off the shelf, but two bottles of the four-pack are in the closet aging, so well see how it is after sitting a while.

2007 Vintage pours a murky amber with a few white bubbles in a ring at the edges. Aroma is sweet caramel, dark fruit, raisin, with hops still present. Flavor is rich malt, caramel, light roasty chocolate, raisin, lots of hoppy bitterness still showing, and a little alcohol. Seems like it should continue to mellow.

I look forward to the release of old Stock every year and the 2010 release did not dissapoint.  Caramel and toffee and toasty notes dominate this beer and it seems more refined and smoother than previous releases.  
This beer is excellent now and I expect it will only get better with some time.

12oz bottle from Total Wine, Las vegas. 2010 vintage- when its -8c out, its time to bring out the big boys. Pours ruby with copper edges and a surprising beige collar falling away to.the edges of the glass. Sweet, inviting aroma of milk chocolate-coated raisins, figs draped with caramel sauce, leather and green olive. Fine and luxurious with an interplay of milk chocolate, creamy fig and tobacco notes that make it very easy to forget you are not drinking a cask-conditoned English brown ale of 5%, but an 11.7% Californian barley wine. Theres a droplet of sherry, but not a hint of jarring hop or alcohol here, just a steady, suffusing fireside warmth. Why bother aging when its this rounded and mellow already? A brew of  considerable flavour and finesse, easily a match for any English barley wine Ive tasted.

2006 vintage bottle at the 5th Annual Epic Beer Tasting in Richmond, VA, November 28, 2010.  Pours a clear copper color with a medium head. Fair head retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel, toffee, leafy hops and burnt sugar. The taste is caramel, toffee, leafy hops. Medium-full bodied. Rich, malty and smooth. Nice beer. I must get some of this to age.

2008 Vintage

G: Poured into a snifter.

A: Pours a dark caramel/toffee with a thin light cream-colored head. Almost entirely opaque with some carbonation.

S: Smells of toffee and caramel. Rich malt base. Still fairly hot in terms of alcohol. 

T: Definitely still fairly hot. This is my first of these, and even with a year on it you can definitely taste the 12.5 abv. 

M: Medium to full body with a smooth creaminess. Definitely large alcohol notes; this is still quite hot, although still good. This is a beer that could definitely use quite a bit of time more in the cellar. 

D: Again, still a little hot. Still, quite nice. Im hoping that some time in the cellar will help the complexities in this one come out a little bit more.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-13-2009

Aroma is plum, caramel, raisin, cherry, wood. Appearance is flat dark brown, small head. Flavor is sweet raisin, plum, cherry. Hops bitterness slightly present. Palate is full and syrupy. Overall its not bad, probably should be aged.

2010, Dégustée le 14-11-10: Couleur brun-ambrée avec reflets rougeatre, légère mousse et moyenne effervescence. Délicieux aromes de cassonade, de caramel ,de miel, de fruits rouge, de sucre candi et de gelée de fraises. Les premieres saveurs percues sont celles du sucre brun, du caramel et vient par la suite des notes de fruits, avec une amertume au palais et une chaleur dalcool. Asser bien balancé, elle gagne a se faire vieillir pour gagner en complexité et en richesse.

A 2006 / 13.25% bottle.  Pours thick and flat.  The aroma was jumping out of the bottle as I poured.  Aroma is of coffee and cherries.  Alcohol warmth very obvious.  Extremely sweet but a unique sweetness instead of a cloying stickiness.  (Had a 2008 bottle in 2008 and was disappointed.)  The alcohol dominates even though so much else is going on.  Based off the 2008 I tasted, this needs to sit for a long time (and could even have sat for longer).  Put one somewhere dark and cool and forget about it.

Bottle pours a murky dark amber with a spare off-white head. Aroma is all over the place, lots of caramel, raisin, plum notes mixed with wood notes, some brown sugar and vanilla. Flavor is boozy, again caramel and brown sugar sweetness with some mild spicing and a vanilla bean and alcohol finish with some wood elements.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2010 2010 Bottle, consumed 11/8/2010.  I didnt want to drink it super-fresh, but Ive been dying to try it and finally picked up a second bottle so I wouldnt feel so guilty about drinking this one.

Immidiately struck by the contrast with the Great Divide Hibernation Ale I had last night; this one smells much more like Id expect an old ale/barleywine to smell.  Deeply copper/ruby, moderate head and very active carbonation, but light on the lacing.  Nose bursts with dark fruits, dates, raisins, LOTS of cherry, sweet rich malts and only a hint of alcohol.  Solid sweetness is followed by nice palate-cleansing bittering mixed with a significant hotness.  This thing is quite a warm sucker, but its not horribly so.  It doesnt drink as smooth as a Fourth Dementia, but what does?  I guess this is technically more towards the barley wine side of things, so with that in mind comparing it to Fourth Dementia might not be appropriate. This is a solid beer fresh and I can see this getting really great with a couple years on it.  Time to build a vertical...

On draught in Columbia, SC. Poured a rich mahogany and had an aroma laden with toffee and caramel. Very sweet and malty but with just enough hop bitterness to take the edge off and prevent it being cloying. Deceptively easy to drink for such a big hitting beer. Possibly my beer of choice for the winter.

strong smell of cherries, caramel, alcohol.  a slow sipping ale, tasted better as it warmed.  alcohol taste was potent, but well complemented by the cherry/caramel flavors.  bought a four pack, will save a couple for aging.  i think it will be smoother over time.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2011 2010 batch. Hazy dark reddish almost brown. Smells like sweet dark fruit. Taste is hugely malty and quite sweet with the alcohol burn at the end. Would be interesting to see what age would do to this.

Fin röd färg, men doften är nästan helt borta.
Smaken är lite källaraktig med svaga toner av malt. Aningen oljig och jag får en liten trappist-känsla
Lite besk och torr känns eftersmaken.
2008 Vintage.  Color is brown and dirty like the Mississippi River.  Sweet taste, which I like.

2009 Vintage. Pours with a three-finger tan head that fades quickly to a ring leaving some lace. Murky brown color. Good carbonation and medium-heavy bodied. Nose is dark fruit and alcohol. Flavor is raisins and some alcohol. Nice old ale. $5.99 for a 12oz bottle from Beverage Warehouse Winooski, VT.

Unlike any ale Ive ever had, with a delicious malt presence. One of the few beers Ive had that has successfully used the taste of alcohol in a way that works with the flavor of the beer, rather than against it. Not quite as strong of an alcoholic bite as what Stone might have, but more of a delectable undertone. I drank it without aging, and based on the quality of drinking experience right off the bat, Im seriously inclined to acquire more and let it mature.

Poured into a large snifter. Appearance is a hazy amber with a thin, quickly dissipating, khaki colored head. Aroma is of dried fruits and malts. Taste is quite good. I notice a breadiness unlike Ive come across in any other beer. There is significant alcohol burn but it is not unpleasant. This is an interesting take on the style of beer.

Rich aroma with am excellent balance of hops, red fruit and alcohol.  Taste is very bitter but as it warms it opens up into some very nice fruity notes.  The finish is largely alcohol.  Nice Barely Wine.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2012 2010 vintage. Lovely dark red color. Big chocolate and caramel aroma with raisin and other dried fruits. Rich malt flavor, chocolate, caramel, raisins, slight roasting, and some hops at the finish. Big fruit, big caramel. Alcohol noticeable but extremely well hidden. This is a lovely drink, though far too young, in my opinion. Needs a few years aging.

Bottle from Systembolaget, 2010 vintage. Opaque dark brown colour, small off-white head. Caramel malts and some alcohol on the nose. Strong malty taste with alcoholic punch. Full bodied and well balanced. My first barley wine. Quite good but maybe not my favourite style.

2010 thanks to Treborwhip for the bottle, pours hazy dark ruby caramel with a medium light tan/yellow head.  Aroma is all over the place, lots of caramel, raisin, plum notes mixed with vinous wood notes, some brown sugar and vanilla.  Flavor is boozy, again caramel and brown sugar sweetness with some mild spicing and a vanilla bean and alcohol finish with some wood elements.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2011 Bottle 33 cl, SB. Pours deep clear ruby mahogany with a small bubbly off white head leaving small laces. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, vanilla pudding, raisins and fidges. Flavor is fullbodied; velvety lean, fruity, a bit phenolic in a good way, alcohol, raisins, port wine, spicy and bitter. Finishes sweet malty, fruity and bitter.

2010 vintage. 12 oz. bottle poured into a snifter. Appearance is an opaque amber-brown color with a foamy tan head that dissipates quickly to a thin ring. Minimal to no lacing. Big, malty aroma. Sweet, caramel, molasses, raisins, and slight alcohol. Taste is a bold, malty sweetness of caramel, molasses, and dark fruits. Nice grassy hop flavor in the finish. Mildly warming. Medium-full body. Low carbonation. Short, sweet finish.

2010 bottle.Pours a dark amber. Aroma of caramel, dark rich plums,brown sugar notes,butterscotch and alcohol. Palate follows the nose with a medium bodied mouthfeel that finishes with sugar and alcohol. Just a hint of bitter to finish.
2010 vintage. Lots of flavor, complemented by the gratuitis amount of alcohol. Sweet but bitter, oaky but powerful.

2008 batch.  Picked this up from Archer Liquors in Chicago, IL, enjoyed on a Sunday afternoon while watching football.  Aroma very rich in caramel, butterscotch, alcohol, and other forms of dark candy.  Appearance is pure brown with a thin brown head.  Taste is very smooth considering the ABV (12+%), also relatively sweet.  Definite caramel / butterscotch characteristics, cant notice any hops in the mixture and mostly malt with a small yeast backing.  This is pretty good stuff, glad I found it!
Color and clarity not bad, aroma is malty backed by massive alcohol.  Looking at label its 11.7% so not surprising.  Taste is malt and alcohol, with an alcohol finish.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2012 Re-rating 2012-01-06. 2011 vs 2010 vertical. Both have a deep amber liquid with a small, fast dissipating off-white head. 2010 is a bit hazy while 2011 is clear. Aroma wise they both have notes of dried fruit, whereas the 2011 is more caramely and somewhat boozy and the 2010 is more complex, deeper and also feels a bit oxidated (notes of port). Taste wise both are light to medium sweet (2011 is a bit sweeter) and light to medium bitter. 2010 is deeper and more complex, less booze. Once again, 2011 shows more caramel and 2010 a bit port and more dried fruit. 2010 is has a fuller body than 2011, both about medium to full bodied. 2011 has higher carbonation (about medium level), 2010 isnt flat but not spritzy at all. Overall, the 2010 wins. A lot more complex and balanced. 2010 gets a 4.2, 2011 3.9. Gives the score +0.1 from last rating since the beer has proven to be ageable.

Original rating, 2010 vintage in September 2010. 12 fl.oz./355 ml bottle from Systembolaget. Hazy, amber appearance with brown head that settles fast due to carbonation that dies out quickly. Some lacing. The aroma is sweet, caramel malts, raisins, toffee and some chocolate. Also a bit of alcohol, which isnt really surprising. Taste is complex and sweet. Some hops and sourness as well. Its got a full body  with a little carboration and a bitter finish, but most of all it tastes alcohol and feels dry. Complex and interesting. Good stuff! 8/4/7/3/17

Deep amber pour hazy with beige head ... light lacing ...  taste of caramel malts slightly bready, nutty and grainy with a bitter warming alcohol finish ... one of the better barley wines good balance

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, toffee, & some hops; Flavor of sweet malt, spicy hops, dark fruit, caramel, raisons, and chocolate; Some alcohol at the finish; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, very good brew.

355 ml bottle. 2010 vintage. From Sweden. Courtesy of Brandman.
Dark reddish brown colour with small tan head.
Aroma is dark fruits, chocolate, caramel and could it be touch of alcohol.
Chocolate, dark fruits, raisins, malt, caramel, bitter hops and sugar in flavour. Warming nicely. Balanced and rich. Surprisingly easy to drink.

2010 Vintage.  Poured from a 12 ozer into a snifter.  Pours with an inch of fuzzy head which disappears quickly.  No lacing.... hmmm?  Nice hoppy aroma with lots of dark fruit such as plums, figs, cherries, etc.  Plenty of alcohol in there too.  Very pretty, dark red/crimson appearance.  Taste is very, very, very, very hot.... between the hops and the alcohol, this sucker burns.  To quote the great philosopher, Ralph Wiggum "It tastes like burning."  A good amount of vanilla and even some oak.  Tastes like it could have been barrel aged.  In short, this is not a beer to be tasted fresh.  A good year plus would be a good time to set this sucker down.  It might taste better then, but there are plenty of barleywines that taste good now.
08 vintage.  very significant alcohol taste.  rotten figs, dried parsley, caramel, maybe banana?
Bottle. found some 2007 at the store and decided to give it a try.  Oak and vanilla flavors are extremely balanced, seems to be almost perfect. Very surprised to how well this is drinking.

12oz bottle from Winooski.
Appearance : Deep amber tiny head that goes away fast.

Aroma : Liquorice, some raisins. Lots of molasses. Very sweet. There is something else that I cant put the word on. Lots of toffee. Smells more like a scotch ale so far. Some alcohol.

Taste : Slightly bitter with some hops. Lots of sweetness. Caramel and liquorice. Finish sweet and quite bitter. Rather dry. Some alcohol as well. Carbonation is very soft.

Overall : Reminds me a bit of Brother Thelonious which I didnt cared for too much. This one is better though. Too much spicy/liquorice with a bit too much alcohol. I think this one need to age a couple years before it gets really interesting. Interesting warm finish. This is not drinkable at all. I need a glass of water to keep me going. Interesting but not really my thing and far too young it seems.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2015 Bottle, vintage 2010. Pours a dark red/brown with a light brown head that disappears quickly. Lots of alcohol in the aroma, as well as candy, licorice allsorts. The taste is very sweet, with licorice and a lot of alcohol. The alcohol also gives it a long, warming finish. I like this a lot, but I think it will be more balanced after a year or two in the cellar.7/4/8/4/17=4.0
Update November 2011:  Aroma: sweet maltiness, toffee, vanilla. Taste: toffee, malty, vanilla, earthy. 8/4/8+/4/17=4.1
Bottle, vintage 2011. 
Dark ruby, tan head that disappears quickly.
Aroma: very malty, toffee, raisins.
Taste: sweet and malty, sourish candy, vinous, some alcohol, earthy, medium high bitterness.
Full-bodied, almost moussy.
Interesting to see how this develops with aging. 8/5/8/4/15=4.0.
Bottle, vintage 2012.
Aroma: floral, jasmine, heather and similar, garden, yellow pears, also some drink (pineapple + coconut + rum).
Taste repeats the aroma, but notable: malty, fruity (+dried f.) same jasmine or whatever as in the aroma, brown sugar.
This years recipe was quite different from earlier years, much more floral.
7/4/8/4/15=3.8.
2014 bottle: malty, dark fruit, berries, marzipan, fruit in liqueur, licorice.

2008. The aroma is clove?, vomit.  The color is amber brown, cloudy, the head is light brown, mostly diminishing with excellent laving. The taste is bitter and sour. doesnt remind me of other barleywines! The body is medium, the texture creamy, the carboantion average, the finish abrupt, alcohol. Leaves too much to be disered.

2010 bottle, poured a murky brown with no head, just a collar of white foam around the glass.  Aroma was sweet malts, almost like candied figs or raisins.  Not much booze in the aroma, just some sweetness, malty.  Flavors are much more complex.  Some big malt flavors up front, sweet but not overly sweet, somewhat fruity like raisins, a bit of heat in the finish, decent bitterness.  Big malty mouthfeel, light carbonation.  Wow, this was good, although I could see some age do it some good.

2010 edition.
  Pours a cloudy dark amber. Small head that fades to nothing quickly. Heavy malt, caramel, dark bread aroma. Flavor has notes of fruit, caramel, roast, and very noticable alcohol.
 It is a bit rough around the edges. If it mellows with age as the brewer claims, it will be much better in the future. Right now it is just okay.

Pours a deep amber orange color with a thin off-white foam head.  Has an aroma of dark fruit, grapes, and caramel, with hints of vanilla.  Has that sweet barley wine taste.  Creamy and syrupy.  Dry sweet finish.  The alcohol comes through but remains reasonably smooth for a BW.  Tasty.

4 12 oz. bottles all purchased from Grape & Gourmet at various times (2006-2009 vertical tasting).  Each appears muddy brown in color with a quickly fading khaki head.  The aroma is bourbon, booze, vanilla, caramel, brown sugar, and oak.  In my opinion the aroma is increasingly stronger in the older vintages.  The flavor is surprisingly fruity, cherry-like and raisin, but is certainly balanced with oak and vanilla.  The oak and vanilla are especially noticeable in the 2007 version.  The heat from the alcohol is quite obvious.  Each of these beers has held up remarkably well but the 2007 is the best overall.  The 2006 is the fruitiest, the 2008 the sweetest, and the 2009 definitely is the booziest.  Quite an interesting experiment with these beers that I have looked forward to as I have collected these.

Bottle at Øl & Mat 2010, Oslo. Aroma is heavy on the malt, but nicely balanced by a fruity (fig-like) acidity. Medium to full bodied, average carbonation. Low bitterness. Incredibly drinkakble considering the ABV, due to a top notch balance between maltiness and acidity.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2015 Got the 2008 vintage: at 12.5%.  Nice warmth.  Rather a big beer but avoids being too much. Easy to make a over the top big beer, but hard to know just when to lay off to add drink-ability. This succeeds. Serving: Bottle

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass. 2010 vintage.

Appearance: Pours a medium chocolate color with a slight ruby tint. The color is just a bit darker than iced tea. Basically no head at all, maybe 1/5 finger which dissipates almost immediately. No lacing.

Smell: Malt, dried fruit and alcohol are dominant with hints of caramel, dried nuts and chocolate.

Taste: Strong and sweet malt flavor up front then a distinct alcohol bite and slight fruitiness in the middle followed by flavors of dried nuts and fruits at the finish. Aftertaste is a mix of bitter, sweet and a hint of remaining alcohol.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a decent amount of carbonation. Distinct alcohol bite.

Drinkability: High drinkability for a beer of this ABV. This is a sipper so it must be judged as such. Just sit back, relax and savor this one.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. This would make a great winter warmer. For those not familiar with the style, I suggest checking it out. You wont regret it.

2010 vintage, drank from a tulip glass: The aroma is smoky oak on top. Hint of purple grape, deep and rich. The smoke on top is intense.

The appearance is as such: the head doesnt last at all. Glassy, ruby red and purple. No lace.

The flavor is a smoky burn on the middle of the tongue; intense, again. Smoky wood chips and embers. The smoke just floats in the mouth like a meat smoker. Burns the front of the tongue with alcohol and burning wood.

The palate is astringent, like a battery. Burns on the way down. Overall? God, the smoke is BRUTAL, but fits. Would probably age beautifully. Really intense for now. Cellar this S.O.B.

Very special, highly decadent and for me, tough to find.  This is the beer to  end an excellent meal or to start a conversation with someone who may not appreciate brews.  An fantastic depth of Christmas cake, rum soaked raisins and vanilla in the smell.  The alcohol is present at first whiff and stays throughout but is never intrusive.  Flavors of sweet mellow peppermint candy and vanilla sweetend butter meld together with a smokey charred alcoholic finish.  Supple, rich and slick is the body on this beauty leaving sugar smacked lips to savor.  Wow, always a treat.  Dont know what I wouldnt do for the brandy version.  This is excellence.  Thank You North Coast.  2009 12 oz.

12oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours deep brown with a thick, cream-colored head.  Aroma of dark fruits, bread/roasted malts, and some earthiness.  Flavor mainly of sweet malts, dark fruits, raisin followed by a nice alcohol, fruits, and a little bit of hops in the finish.  A very complex beer.  Really good, but could be a little thicker.

This years vintage from a snifter while I watch south park.  Pours dark amber or brown-semi hazy and almost no head.  nose of dried fruits, sweet malt, some vanilla, wood, and "c" type hops.  Taste is much the same; big flavor of esters, malt, wood, and warm alcohol vapor fill the nostrils. full bodied and evident carbonation in the mouthfeel.  The aroma is great and the taste could improve over time.  I will age some and sample again.

Poured from bottle. Nose is brown sugar, molasses, fig, and a faint herbal overtone. Pours a dark red-brown with a quick-dissipating head. Malt, boozy head, and caramel hits first, after which theres a winey bitterness. Intense.
Pours a nice dark amber.  Nearly no aroma. Taste is dusty with a strong alcohol finish. Feel like Im drinking a bottle of rubbing alcohol with a hidden malt finish. Not balanced and not smooth.

355ml bottle, vintage 2009, bb. Dec. 2019, cellared for some time after I brought it back home for Systembolaget in Linköping September last year. Offered some drinking enjoyment to the soccer match between Germany and Spain on TV. Poured a dense, off-white head with good duration atop of a deep, ruby coloured body. Rather subdued aroma of dark, dried fruits along with malts and herbal dryness. Vapour of alcohol, too. Dry, slightly roasted, malts in flavour plus dried fruits, like apricot, and with suggestion of liquorice. A real alcohol punch on the palate. Full bodied. Likable, but too much on the sweet side. The alcohol is also a bit disturbing. Should perhaps have left the bottle in the cellar for a longer time span (Tromsø, 07.07.2010).

Warming, 2007 bottle, each sip kind of feels like I took a shot... looks amazing, clear dark amber, excellent retention for a barleywine... sweet candy aroma, alcoholic... sweet flavor, not sticky, brandylike, this oak aged would be amazing... full bodied, long warming finish...

Bottled. A dark red brown with little head. Aroma is a wild nose of milk chocolate, big wood, caramel, those greater darker berry fruits, more dryed fruits like raisin and maybe dates, and I must repeat wood everywhere, with just beautiful aromatic touches of vanilla bean. Flavor is similar in an oily thicker body with sweet and bitter coming though the whole way. What a brew, what a day/or should I say, morning.

Bottle from the Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam. Ruby/brown pour with a beige head which dissipates swiftly. Very nice vinous sweet aromas of toffee, caramel, raisins and ripe plums. Flavours of caramel, plums, dates and raisins. Fierce alcohol burn. Rich, sweet throat warming finish. Very nice.
very good for what it is, im just not a big barleywine fan. too heavy and sugary for me.

A: The pour is a sort of muddy brownish red color with a short lived tan head that settles down to a thin ring.

S: A strong aroma of dark fruits, leather, toffee, and dark sugars. There is a mild alcoholic presence in the form of sherry, rum which works nicely with the plums and raisins.

T: There is a bitterness and dryness that wasnt quite expected. The leathery quality really shines through along with some dark/burnt sugars. Surprisingly, the fruits are somewhat subdued.

M: The body is full with a smooth carbonation. A bit sticky and chewy as well.

D: Not the best of the old ales that Ive come across. Perhaps I need to try this one at varying ages to see how it might differ.

12oz. Bottle. 2008 Vintage. Just breaking into my first of two four packs from 2008 and it does not disappoint.  Essentially a very traditional English style barleywine that is done exceptionally well. Pours a deep reddish mahogany color with almost no head.  Huge malty nose with aromas of candied sugar, dark fruit, toffee and caramel.  The flavor is malt dominated and has a bit of everything including rum cake, overly ripe plums, dates, caramel, brown sugar and a hint of raisin.  Hops are subtle and used nicely to give just enough bitter kick to balance out all the malt flavors.  Beautiful texture to this one that is slightly syrupy and viscous like every respectable barleywine should be.  Finish is slightly fizzy and faintly warming.  The 12.5% ABV is essentially imperceptible.  Simply put Old Stock is the chronic and a must for every beer cellar.

Such a great beer, I dont even know what to say about it. The flavors combine to almost taste like a portobello mushroom (Odd, but thats what I taste). A toffee taste dominates throughout in this expert barley wine. Just exceptional. My all time favorite beer thus far.
I have sampled this many times without a rating. Very complex nose of Plums, figs, candied sugar, and a hint of licorice. Flavors are similar. Chewy and peppery finish. Full bodied beer. Very nice.

On tap at San Diego Brewing Co.  Hazy rust-red with off-white head and lace.  Nose is sweet warm malt and sharp alcohol.  Taste is sweet and spicy with sharp and alcohol.  Definitely the strong sharp style barleywine.  Really good.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2011 
Rated May 20, 2010  2008 Bottle Pours a beautiful cloudy mahogany with a small, frothy, beige head. The aroma is huge!!! Lots of caramel with dark fruit, candied sugar, and a bit of anise. I cant believe how well hidden the alcohol is. The flavor is similar, very full and rich, yet mellow and well blended. This is an amazing barley wine. A little sweet on the finish. Soft, surprisingly light mouthfeel with slightly fizzy carbonation. Awesome!

Rated January 5, 2011  2009 bottle. Clear ruby-copper with a small to nil head. The aroma has dark fruit, caramel, and alcohol. The flavor is similar and well balanced, but much more boozy than the 08 vintage was which is surprising since it has a lower abv. Soft, smooth body with minimal carbonation but still pretty warm. Maybe another year of aging will mellow this out. I guess time will tell.

Bottle, 2008 vintage. Beautiful russet amber pour, with a slow-to-rise almond head. Mouth-watering aroma of hearty barley meal and warm toffee. Rich, silky, chewy palate with flavours of dates, toffee, the crust  of creme brulee, and orange brandy. No hint of the 12.5% ABV. Smooth, hearty, and immensely satisfying.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 2008 handbottle, turned into what I call "REALLY Old Stock Ale" by cellaring for over a year.  Pours a reddish brown with a thin, dense, but short-lived off-white head.  Aroma is a sweet mix of raisin bread, caramel, and maybe some hints of licorice.  Flavor follows this pattern, but the caramel feels thick, as if it were coating a candy apple.  Amazingly, this somehow isnt cloying.  The abundance of malt backbone and booze with the high ABV chews through the sugars and makes a very nice complex blend of flavors. Texture is syrupy from years in the bottle, but this is a darn good barleywine.
Pours to a nice caramel head that dissipates in about two minutes, leaving a beautiful deep cooper ale.  A nose of damp leaves and wood.  A smooth palate and lasting finish.  One of my favorite ales.
from notes....08 batch on tap at gman fort worth. pours a plumish brown smell is strawberries and plums and oak. taste is of white grape juice and hidden alcohol very intrestin to say the least

The Old Stock Ale from North Coast Brewing was one of the first old ales/Barleywines that I tasted back in my early beer geek days. Now each years release is one I look forward to from pretty much the start of the New Year. Along with drinking a few bottles fresh, I always make sure to stash a couple three away for aging. Truly, the Old Stock Ale will do just fine with an easy five or six years under her cap, when stored properly, of course. In the meantime, I am going to enjoy a fresh bottle of the 2009 release.


Old Stock Ale not only tastes great, it also looks great. I am always enamored by his deep polished mahogany hues matched by an equally coppery sheen to his head. A rich beast of a brew, his head never lingers long, choosing instead to decorate my glass with a tight copper necklace from start to finish. Swirls produce no lace, but Im not surprised. This is a sipping brew if there ever were one, and I am more than ready to take my sweet loving time with him. First, lets start with the nose; sweet, spiced, and boozy. The booze hits hard yet gentle in the back of my nose with each rapid sniff, while candy apples and freshly sliced red apples delight. There may have been no barrels involved in the brewing of this beer, but the wonderfully rich, spiced, sweet, and woody esters of aged rum are ever present along with fresh cinnamon sticks. Take the cinnamon sticks, add apples, blend, and tada! Spiced applesauce. Black grapes, canned nectarines, red licorice, maple and pecan praline all clamor for my attentions. As I revel in all his nose has to offer, the crisp snap of peach skins bring me back to reality just in time for my first quaff. Full, rich, heavy, and mouthcoating, just the way I like my Old Stock Ale. Instantly my cheeks are rosy, my chest aglow, and my breath spiced with cinnamon, rum, and wood. Candy apples crunch and stick to my teeth while the caramel coats my lips with each quaff. Pears, peaches, and apples are steeped in booze and rummy spices, their flavors melting atop my tongue in an orgy to shame the most decadent red light district. Slowly the top of my tongue begins to dry just a wee bit, the main culprit being an essence of boozed wood and brown spices. Red licorice sticks, my least favorite candy treat, greets me from the middle of his palate and I find that, just this once and only in this manner, do I enjoy that particular flavor profile. Treacle and caramelized pecans add their own sweet nuttiness. Each slow sup is a pleasant mix of all the above, and seeing as I have nowhere in particular to go, I set my pen down and savor the rest of our time together.


Each release of Old Stock Ale is a rebirth of a classic. Slowly but surely I am building an epic vertical of anywhere from five to ten years of Old Stock. Seeing as I only have 2008 and 2009, itll be a while before you read about that particular journey of mine. In the meantime, grab a couple 4packs, a snifter, a chair, and enjoy.

aroma is rigid backbone of heavy malted grain that leads to well developed toffee having been reduced to concrete heaviness and strength.  appearance is murky caramel with strong ring of foam that lingers but no legs and very low carb.  flavor is muted cocoa, smash of booze and eventual resulting esters from its potency: perhaps berry.  warmth comes on quickly.  heavy and delightful.

12 oz bottle. 2009 Vintage. Pours a dark caramel brown with medium foam head. Flowery, almost cherry hop aroma. Chocolate notes definitely apparent in this one, medium thick mouthy feel. Very rich in overall taste and texture. A nice warming alcohol finish which was not evident in the aroma. Good to great at a year old, I may buy another and let it condition for another year!!
Strong on the palate! Aroma is strong and roasty. Taste is chocolatey and strong. Tastes sweet like strong alcoholic beer.

Sweet candy caramel nose. Fantastic spice foundation! Clove, nutmeg and cinnamon. Pumpkin pie and banana bread all in one beer. Great toasted malts and just the right hint of hops. Sweet, but in an earthy satisfying way. Rich, earthy warming finish. What a beer!
smells of fresh molasses with looks like watered down coke.  Lacks lacing but the palate is good.  Nice balance.  Taste is amazing.  Alcohol is warming.  Wonderful finish of dessert like candy.
excellent tasting brew. poured nicely with good head. no after taste will try to buy this beer again.. really enjoyed it.

Its a reddish, mahogany, copper colored liquid with good lacing. Wonderful maple syrup mixed with brown sugar and malt. Its a beer with 12.5% abv and absolutely no alcohol odor. There are some fruit and floral flavors in there, as well. The high alcohol is warming and spicy. In addition to the flavors in the aroma, there are strong caramel and vinous notes.  Thick, mildly cloying.

2009 Sampled at Glunz Expo. Pours a dark reddish bronze. Nose is very nice with big malty notes, raisin, distant herbal hops. On taste, amazingly well balanced. the MO comes through well and is balanced impeccably by the spicy, slightly citrusy fuggles. Would definitely last a long time in a cellar. Excellent, makes me want to revisit good barleywines...

2009 Bottle reviewed in February 2010.

Pours with surprisingly decent carbonation and a modest crown atop a burnt orange liquid.  Aroma is strong boozy raisins and you can tell its going to be a monster.  The taste is a complex mesh of caramels, sweet raisins, occasionally even chocolate, but perhaps most dominant is a brown sugar note reminiscent of Southern Comfort.  Needs some aging to simmer down, but I think this beer is probably incredible with some time on it.

I was unimpressed by this.  Perhaps I just wasnt in the mood for a barleywine, but it seemed to be little more than an attempt to cram as much malt as possible into a bottle.  Dark brown, thick head.  Aromas of malt, malt, and more malt.  Bit of hops.  Maybe some fruit.  Taste is sweet, decently balanced with a bit of hop bitterness.  Syrupy mouthfeel.  Decent, generic American barleywine.  MIght benefit from aging; try older vintages (mine was only a year old).

12 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  Pours a hazy plum-amber color with a tiny beige head that dissipates quickly and leaves only a small ring on the inner edge of the glass.  Aroma of rich caramel malts, brown sugar, hops, pine resin, mixed fruits, wood, and floral notes.  Flavor of caramel malts, resin, berry fruits, tropical fruits, floral notes, vanilla, wood, citrus, hops, and alcohol.  Complex.  Bitter and boozy, with some balancing sweetness.  Sweet and alcoholic aftertaste.  Medium-full bodied, syrupy and smooth, with minimal carbonation.  Pretty solid barleywine; not the greatest, but good and effective.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2014 Was a long time ago so I took a 2014 that I just bought (saving one for later).
AR: figs, rasins, plums, vinos, 
AP: thick ruby fizzy fluid, stouthy créme brulee deminishing head
F: thick oily fluid, the rasins, figs and plums are young, vinos - materia, sweet, wee fizzy sticky carbonation, almond cake

Tjooohoo exploded in my face, 2009 edition that I stored for 1/2 a year!
Bottle, 2010-04-07, Göteborg
AP: dark syrup colored body, loads of carbonation, wee off whitehead totally deminishing, as mentioned above spilled a few drops - and its like glue
AR: toffee fudge, roasted malt
F: toffee chocolate fudge, roasted malt, vinos (porto), round flavors that will develop fine after some years (not this bottle :-)), touch of almond liqueur, dark syrup sweetness, oily consistenese, medium bitterness, Longing for an older one and on cask!

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2010 2007 edition, bottle @ Henrik, Bergen. This is a rather ordinary-looking barley wine; low carbonation, clear orange body. Nose is deep caramel malt and a bit of booze. Taste is toffee, cough syrup and grassy hop notes. Old Stock Ale is very bitter, from start to finish, which was a little too much for me as it accompanied by a underlaying current of hot, boozy spiciness. All in all it couldve been a bit smoother in my opinion, and I think the storage potential is high on this one. Didnt quite do it for me this time around, though.

pours a beautiful amber brown in color with plenty of visible carbonation. Smell is of caramel, malt, and dark fruits. The taste was strong of malt and caramel with the fruits in the background. The alcohol is well hidden at first but bites the more you drink. Great mouthfeel. Medium body with plenty of carbonation-but not too much. Very smooth.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-28-2007 19:34:48

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2010 2010 Vintage. Pours a clear, deep, brownish ruby with a thin beige head. Aroma: honey, sweet fruits, malt and bourbon. Taste: honey, fruit, malts, hops, bourbon, notes of spice. Long, warm alcohol finish. Soft carbonation. Overall a very good beer: smooth taste, nice body with depth. I plan on letting my other bottles age in the cellar a few years.

Had the 07 of this on tap at the Hard Liver fest in Seattle last weekend. Colour... ruby-amber with no head. Nose... honey and dried fruit. Palate... moderately sweet, hoppy, loads of clover honey, beeswax, toffee and a lengthy finish.

Bottle 2006 vintage, thanks Harry. Aroma is floral and grassy. Then, you get candied cherry, butterscotch and alcohol. Flavor is powerful but very well balanced, wow. I get some brown sugar, honey, spices (cinnamon) with a nice brandy finish.  Wow, so close from getting a 10. Medium body, very soft carbonation, syrupy mouthfeel; enjoyable palate. The best barleywine Ive had.
Excellent Aroma. Smells like dough and caramel.  Slight hint of alcohol on the finish.  Very warming.

North Coast Brewing Company--Old Stock Ale--12 oz. Bottle.

2004 Release.  11.40% ABV--36 IBUs.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Mild lace head.  Clear rich ruby color.  Malty fruity mild hop front.  Smooth creamy rich caramel black cherry malty body.  Clean hot EtOH mild hop end.  Smooth mild hop Barleywine.  Rich but too big for me.  Sampled 11/14/2004.

2005-6 Release.  11.40% ABV--36 IBUs.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Rich lacy head.  Mild sediment.  Cloudy bright rich dark amber color.  Creamy thick mild sweet rich caramel ester mellow fruit body.  Spicy hot EtOH balanced creamy end.  Rich hoppy spicy Old Ale.	  Sampled 7/26/2006.

2006 Release.  13.25% ABV--100 IBUs?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Old Ale.  4 @ $3.69 Each.  Mild lacy head.  Cloudy dark amber color.  Rich malty Cognac spicy floral fruit hop front.  Creamy thick sweet tangy toasted doughy caramel body.  Tangy hot Hop spice mild hot EtOH dry clean end.  Cognac Beer mellows with conditioning.  Sampled 7/15/2008.

2007 Release.  11.70% ABV--100 IBUs?  (4.0 / 5.0)  Old Ale.  4-Pack $12.99.  Light sediment.  Mild lace thin head.  Rich aromatic raisin fig plum hop front.  Rich spicy sweet malty black cherry fig caramel fruit body.  Hot spicy Hop EtOH cloying malt end.  To Much but tasty.  Sampled 6/27/2009.  Aging 3 Bottles.

2008 Release.  12.50%--36 IBUs.  Old Ale.  4-Pack $13.99.  Aging All 4.

2009 Release. 11.50%--36 IBUs.  Stock Ale	.  2 @ $3.99 Each.  Aging Both.

2010 Release.  11.70% ABV--36 IBUs.  2 @ $3.99 Each.
2008 12 OZ bottle . orange pour with a small tan head, warming taste with a bitter finish.

2010 Vintage / 12 oz bottle - Im not overly impressed with this well-rated ale.  It is a little too sweet, and has a certain bitter aftertaste that lingers in the mouth.  I remember trying last years ale and liking it, but not rating it.  Maybe Im being a little to harsh, but I cant justify a higher rating right now.

North Coast
Ole Stock Ale
Pours copper with a thin white had and no retention. Strong aroma of booze, malt and dark fruits. Some spiciness as well. Flavor is sublime, barley wine that had aged. Somewhat bourbony, with sweet maltiness and a diminished hop character. Tastes like it has already aged some even though it is a 2010 bottle. I want some to lay down for a few years. Good shit.
UPDATED: MAR 13, 2010 Smells of light sugars, alcohol, fruit.  Flavor is very similar to a candied apple.  sweet, fruity and a nice warming alcohol tinge toward the end.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2010 2009 Bottle. Appearance is a nut brown color with a thin layer of resinous head. Aroma is honey, caramel, dried figs and alcohol. Flavor begins with intense caramel and malt sweetness followed by vanilla, rum and candied dates. Mouthfeel is syrupy and full-bodied with low carbonation and a warm alcohol finish. It should definitely be sipped like a fine liqueur as the alcohol level is still a bit hot. Looking forward to trying a bottle thats been aged a few years.
Big and robust with flavor. Has flavors that has woody characters, vanilla notes, and barely notes. Enjoy slowly with a friend and some cheese.

11/29/2009 tasting 2009 -vs- 2004.

2009. clear pour... deep auburn brown with an orange hued tannish head. huge aggressive bubbles from the carbonation. 

aromas of spiciness, malt, over ripe plums,  a little dust, herbs, flowery hops and a bit of smoky wood. it is really crisp and spicy compared o the smooth richness of the 2004.

the palate lacks the sweetness of the 2004... yay! but also lacks the complexity... boo. flavors noted... plummy jammy goodness, nuts, cookie dough, smoky wood, a little peat-like earthiness, calcium, herbals, brown sugar and a touch of tartness on an otherwise smooth finish. alcohol is slight and pleasantly warming.

the body is medium... surprisingly. though it feels thinner than the 2004. it is crisp and prickly yet the carbonation is low. a slight chalkiness is noticed in the mouth feel. 7.5/4/7/4/16/3.85

2004 11.4% pours out milky, thick and sludgey... opaque rusty colored mix of auburn and cherry juice. teenie-tiny bubbles of carbonation. loads of yeasty gunk is left in the bottle. 

it smells really sweet and malty compared to the fresh version... lots of sherry oxidation, vanilla, brown sugar, dates, maple, sticky fig newton cookies and waffle batter. the oxidation reminds me of burgundy grand cru whites with 25+ years on them!

the flavor is seemingly sweeter... at least more malt forward than the 2004. ideally, it is too sweet but complexity makes up for it.... notes of brown sugar, chocolate chip cookies, golden raisin-like tartness, vanilla, wood, cinnamon and a bitter grain husk quality on the finish. it is spicy, prickly and tingly yet full bodied, thick and syrupy. it approaches cloying but never makes it there. it has a smooth texture with low carbonation and a chalky mouth feel. warmth from alcohol and spice is pleasant. 8.5/5/8/4/16/4.15
i like the oxidized aged notes of the 2004 but somehow it fuller in body and sweeter than the fresh version. now, mix the two=killer!

08 bottle tasted in 1/10. Pours very dark amber with a disappearing tan head. The aroma is caramel, toffee, pineapple, raisins, and chocolate. The flavor is heavy on maple syrup, molasses, raisins, and prunes. Very thick, syrupy body with a sweet and syrupy aftertaste. A little orange and pineapple too. Very tasty.
2008 Vintage on tap at Capones. Very nice beer. Complex malt taste. Not overly hopped. A smooth hearty barley wine.
