Sweet, ripened fruits roll by the palate, followed with sugar-coated bread. All of these flavors are punctuated by a zippy spiciness. The 11.4% alcohol is, at first, cumbersome on the palate, but eventually mellows to a relaxing hotness. 

Mouthfeel: Medium. Considerably lighter than I remember it being, although its alcohol, syrupiness, and colossal range of flavors help it to seem a bit hardier.

Drinkability: Such an excellent example of balance within a beer. Its all so very impressive. Drinkable? Definitely, but the alcohol can really shake you up, so take it easy, friends. Ill certainly be returning to the store to grab more to cellar.

2006 Vintage. Pours a clear light brown with a smallish, creamy, tan head. The aroma is heavy caramel malts, port, dates and a considerable alcohol note. Im not surprised to see that years ABV is @ 13.25%, but Im not complaining either. The mouthfeel is full-bodied, creamy and effervescent. The flavor is very sweet dark fruits, sugar plums, raisins and a port-like warm alcohol finish. Warm and inviting, this is a beer that can hold its own against a fine brandy or port.

bottle.  pours heady with a heavy mahogany hue.  thick aromas of milky caramel, melted butterscotch, and a little forest blend.  overall the aromas are pretty heavy.  onward to the palate.  it tastes heavy and syrup-esque, yet pleasantly smooth and hoppy.  the sweetness caught me off guard, but the hops and thicker malts counteract the maple syrup sweetness to produce a heavier beer. old wrinkly fruits are also present (raisins, prunes, etc.).  the bitterness hits towards the end, almost on the top of the throat.  its a little tight, and i think ill lay the other one down.  cheers!

Dan Journal #4.  2004 12oz bottle.  Hazy with a caramel hue.  Clinging off-white head.  Raisins and a whiskey burn in the nose.  Pruney and smooth.  Full bodied.  Then blam!  Bitter alcohol flavor.  Sherry woody burn.  Clinging sweet and sour finish.  Long taste evolution.
2005  12oz bottle.  Same hue, same head.  Lighter nose.  But the same whiskey burn.  Still sweet with caramel aromas, but shorter.  Alcohol burn is milder.  Still long and cloying but ebbed.  Hoppier and rougher.  Fresh is good, aged is better!

Clear caramel brown look with a small brown head. Very sweet fruity aroma of plums or prunes mixed with whiskey and sweetmalts. Extremly fullbodied and complex flavor with tons of alchohol, sweet caramel, sirup and an underlying chocolate bitterness. Warming sweet alchohol finish.

2007 Bottle... Poured a deep, red and purple tone. Thin off white head.  Floral aroma, flavors of sweet, barley malt, figs and fruit. Pretty strong, bitter finish. I have an extra bottle I hope to age for a couple of years.

Rated at the Pewaukee Tasting II 5/5/07.
Cloudy light brown, modest head.  Robust sweet malty aroma., very attractive, almost that of a good doppelbock but loaded with more extra-curricular stuff, pop, sizzle, hops, cherry, fruity.  
Flavor  Lots of malt-hop zip, very lively, a little carbonation sting, balanced.
Palate  Medium bodied

This thing kicked me in the face like a mule.  Pours a beautiful liquid caramel color, and even has that caramel lacing look to it.  Decent white head to go along with it.  Scents of candied sugar, caramel (which I guess you could call candied sugar), and alcohol.  I pondered over the option of aging this a couple of years because it could definitely handle it, but ultimately thought better of it and decided to just drink the damn thing.  The first drink almost put me in a coma.  The alcohol kick on this almost bloodied my lip, it smacked me so hard.  Wonderful caramel taste that leads in to the alcohol-based finish that was very pleasant and warming.  Great beer.
2005 bottle. Poured a dark red. This was a tongue slapper. Very strong but I love it with its bourbon taste.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2008 2008 bottle. Deep amber pour with thin head. Nose of strong caramel and sweetness. Taste is hot alcohol (of course...its young), sweet tannic malts, and turpentine. As it warms the flavors a more integrated, but obviously too young. Will hold the rest of the bottles for a while, but I had to try it fresh.
Current rating is this vintage.

2007 bottle. Bright garnet color. Aroma of caramel, sweet dark fruits and a little spice. Taste is a bit hot right now, with maple and floral notes. Nice hop finish. Needs a little time in the bottle to become a better beer. 
7/4/6/4/14=3.5
Clear reddish brown pour with a thick off white head. Fruit and malt in the aroma. Tasted complex with sweet fruits and caramels. Finished with a lasting alcohol and malt feel.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2013 Thank you Joe. Musky fruit aroma, grapes with alcohol. Very dark appearance with a reddish tint to it. Thin off white head. Slowly the beer takes on a different taste of liquorice and spice. Caramel and chocolate all together but showing them selves separately. For a strong ale I really enjoyed this one. Not overpowering and probably my favourite of this strength. 2008 - Looks great. Berries, spice. like a mutated port wine. Rich in flavour. Spiced. Reminds me of Christmas. Little smoky. Lovely warming ale. 2013- Amber colour with a fast disapating head. Fruit, malt whiskey aroma. Rich flavour of boozy trifle, fruit and malt. Quite delicious. Tangy spice finish. Syrup texture. Nice woth some cheese.

2007 bottled edition.  Dark amber color, not much head or lacing.  Has to be poured pretty vigorously to get any head on it.  Very strong, vinous, winey sort of brew.  The alcohol is very evident, lots of malt without much bitterness.  A good, strong beer, but not quite as much as Id hoped for.  Think it probably needs more aging.  Would like to try an older vintage.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2009 2005 Bottle. Poured a medium-dark brown with a slight reddish hue. Heavy, syrupy mouthfeel. Taste was of brandy, caramel candy, malt, some dark chocolate, plum, and raisin. Both a sweet and a bitter. A complex beer, much more to be savored on a cold winter night. Tuck er away in the cellar, and I can only imagine MORE complexity. $10 for a four pack of 12 oz. Probably worth double! Enjoy!!!
dark amber color with a sweet nose.  flavor is very complex with hints of fig and spice.  possibly a little immature and may benefit from a little storage.  a very enjoyable beer regardless
2006 bottling. Pours a deep ruby color, no head...Brown sugar, raisins, touch of sweet bread.  Nice carbonation, prevents a great brew from becoming cloying.
Bottle. Pours  mahogny red colour. Sweet caramel, roasty, dark fruit, alcoholic aroma. Very sweet, caramel, alcohol, dark fruit, smokish with liquorice, spiced flavour.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2010 Pours a syrupy thick but clear chestnut with a fast fading yellow fizzy head.  Rich aroma of caramel, toffee, hot alcohol, fermented fruits, oxidized earthy hops.   At over a year old its still too young, and way hot.   Flavor is lightly sweet and nutty, followed by dull alcohol and some cinnamon.  As it warms it gets a little richer, some hop bit and lots of candied barley.   Finishes hot.   I cant stress enough how this beer needs to age. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 

[8 / 5 / 9 / 4 / 18] (Vintage 2006 - rated 3/14/08) Intoxicating caramel, toffee, red berries, pepper and cinnamon aroma.  Pours caramel cloudy with a creamy tan head that fades into fine craters.  Lots of sweet malt and some dried fruits with a touch of alcohol.  Very warming and slightly chewy.  Some condensed-milk flavor.  Flavor expands and smoothes a bit into woody nuttiness.  Carbonation is just a tad fizzy.  Really impressive in depth and unique flavors.  Still have 2 06 bottles left for the next two years, and I love that none of them will taste exactly alike.  Fantastic.   [Hint: hold off the urge to drink this for at least 1 year 6 months) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .  . . . [2007 Bottle rated 10/24/08, wish I knew when they bottled this.... thinking July? That is when I remember seeing the new vintage showing up on shelves  -  8 / 5 / 8 / 4 / 17]  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . not sure where my 2008 bottle rating is.. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . [2009 bottle enjoyed 11.28.09] Pours a... well I cant see Im watching a movie in the dark... wow this smells ridiculously different, very fragrant, juicy, stinky wet carpet, citrus, pungent, light cat piss, not even close to what I remember, flavor is completely different as well, bright, hoppy, juicy, bright caramel, but watery, stinky, cooked vegetables, oh no no no,  what the hell is this?  6.4.6.3.14...??? Im at a loss for words... well at least I almost have a full case of the good vintages... this ... well I dont know what the hell this is... Im going to have a hard time choking this one down.  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . [2007 bottle rated 3.11.10] Pours a duller reddish dirt color with a weird fizzy thin soda pop head.  Aroma is fruity and nutty, nice sherry notes.  Flavor is sweet and fruity, yeasty, bitter, nutty, strong alcohol, thin, too fruity.  Body is in that in between stage, soft fizzy awkward carbonation and the body is starting to thin out...  Im thinking now the fresher 08 is the best so far
8.3.7.3.14 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[2008 bottle rated 12.31.10]  2008 is a nice year.  I remember enjoying this one fresh as well.  Aroma might be the best part, fantastic rich caramel and toffee, alcohol boosts it nicely, hint of piney hops remain, cotton candy, quite balanced aroma wise.  Flavor follows but not as sophisticated or polished as the aroma, some booze, bitterness, strong caramel, bit of cherry, soft cotton candy, powdered sugar, quite nice actually, very similar to Harvest or Hardys.  Nice job here.  8.4.8.4.16

I really cant believe this isnt rated higher by people.  I  love this brew.  Found a 4-pack of the 2005.  Taste is big and bready, caramel, dark fruits, some spice.  This is a sweet beer, but one of the best sweet beers I have ever had.  Absolutely love it.

2006 bottle out of a Brooklyn glass.  Dark amber clear color with a short lived head.  Smell: sweet fruits, bread, caramelized sugar.  Flavor is sweet, alcohol, fruits, with a spicy/alcoholic mouthfeel.  Id like to try an older bottle of this in the future.

12 oz bottle, 2007 vintage.  Pours a reddish brown with a fizzy off-white head that quickly diminishes to a light dusting and then completely disappears.

The aroma is bitter grains and some DMS at first with sharp caramel alcohol, fruits and sugary sweetness coming out.

The flavor is sweet candy-like sugar with some sharp bitter alcohol in the finish.  Some fruitiness comes out as it warms.  The mouthfeel is medium to full with soft carbonation.

Overall, a mediocre barley wine.  The alcohol and sweetness are pretty harsh and brash and it is not very complex.  Maybe this is better after sitting a while...it is pretty hot.
Okay, everyone likes this beer but with about 13% alcohol, I cant get past the high alcohol content.  The palate and flavor just does not do it for me!

Bottle. 200 version. Light yellow low but lasting creamy head. Clear dark red brown body. Aroma of burned barley malt with notes of plucs caramel and alcohol. Alcohol dominted flavor of coffe and caramel. pretty vineous. A good deal of caronation. Pleasant and long aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2008 2006 vinage in the bottle. foamy smooth yet somewhat winey. tastes of plum dark cherry and raisin or prune. slight straw component welcomed as the beer is uninspired for some of the legend. the alcohol is very well hidden. quite malty with little hop and a clean honey like sweetness with perhaps  a hint of vanilla. good mouthfeel of substantial volume and balanced alcohol.

The color was foggy, orange/amber.  The head was creamy, medium beige, and foamy.  The aroma was alcohol, fermented fruit, sweet, and had an earthiness/must about it.  The flavor was musty/earthy, alcohol, tart, and fruity.  The palate was med/thick bodied and nicely carbonated.  The finish was warm.

Got this in a trade from dirty_martini, although I think it technically gets distributed here I heard they were stopping. Anyway, pours a ruddy brown that shows its reddish hues with some light. The head is medium with an aggressive pour, tan and creamy. Nice. OH man, this aroma. Dense. Im gonna try and describe some of it. Its definitely sweet, slight alcohol, fruity, an aged character, slightly earthy, caramel, and definitely hints of awesome. The flavor is actually a step down as far as depth and complexity goes, but still great. Dry, fruity, same earthy character, caramel, alcohol (more with warmth). The palate feels like it should be a little thicker but again, its still good. Dry too. The finish is sweet and of course warms your entire body. I thoroughly enjoyed this brew. If this is a 3.9 Id love to try the higher rated BWs.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2007 2007 vintage. Deep reddish amber, large beige head. Roasted malts with notes of raisin and figs, some licorice, and piney hops. Medium bodied with a soft mouthfeel. Flavour starts off nicely sweet, but turns moderately bitter, and with a discrete alcohol touch. So much better than the 2006 vintage. Perhaps a touch of the 2006 roughness could improve it even further.

Bottle, 2004 version. Porto aroma with raisin. Malty with strong port-like flavors. Vinous and raisinny. Alcohol is noticeable, but fairly well hidden. Comparable with an old Chimay if it had less alcohol.
A big beer, that has a real boozy sweetness. I dont quite get what the appeal is with this brew. It is not as complex as many other barleys. Its good, but not really my style.

I reached for this beer to quench my thirst will eating popcorn and I almost spit this thing out.  However, I read the description and got hip to North Coasts intent and found myself enjoying this syrupy sweet licorice bitterbarleywine-like beer as I sipped my way to the bottom.

Brown sugar, dark fruit, toffee, molasses, bourbon and caramel nose. Very complex candy and fruit palate with mild fruit and nuts notes and a slight almost coconut note. Lingering vanilla forward finish.

A 2001 bottle of this shared by my friend David Noble was a very delectable treat.  An amber brown hue and small lustrous head was the precedent for a quite sweet brown sugary taster.  Prevalent alcohol aroma combined with earthy sweetness and sharp fruity edge made this beer a great once in a lifetime refreshment.

Bottle (2004 - 11,4%) at home - drinking it now. Unclear red/brown - light yellow head. Chokolate, raisins, dried fruits, caramel, toffee, high sweetness, pretty high hoppy, vineous, portwine, alcho-burn. A bit sharp finish !!

Bouteille de 12 oz, millesimée 06, dans une échange avec HogTownHarry. Bourgogne claire, mince collet beige. Arome de malte sucré et de fruits du vergé très mures, avec une présanse dalcool invitant. Goût de fruits sûrettes mures, un peu caramelisé et assez réchaufant.

Bottle, 2006 Mild malt aroma, not very hoppy. Pours a red copper color, with a decent tan head. Quite malty in taste, alcohol is very well hidden for a 13% Mild hops. Its quite nice for a barely wine it doesn;t have some of the rough edges often associated with the style. As always a very nice brew from a very nice brewery.
UPDATED: JUN 4, 2007 Vintage 2006. I cant believe that this beer is actually 13% alcohol. Well hidden behind the caramel and hint of butterscotch. Wasnt really bitter but more of a sweet beer.
Bottle (2006). Dark amber colour with a small yellow/beige head. Sweet alcoholic aroma with dark fruits. Complex flavour with fruits, candy & malt. Too strong.

personaly the best beer out there. Has an amazingly smooth but full and flavorfull taste. At first i was expecting a hoppier even bitter taste, but instead found a full bodied malty and creamy taste that almost fell off my tongue. It actually overwhelms your taste buds and then just stops. nothing like it and you will almost be let down that it isnt bitter or hoppy because you are always thinking this beer has to be harsh at 12%. incredible.

An amazing beer, feel of strong scents, strong flavors and great taste. The aroma is malty and caramelly and full of alcohol. So is the taste. Full of flavors, the alcohol taste finishes off each sip, overwhelming the other flavors, but not overwhelming itself. I have had the 2005 and 2006 vintages, and, the 2006 being stronger has a stronger alcohol taste. I look forward to sampling the 2007 vintage brew.

The aroma was malty with a strong biscuity and bready characteristic. The aroma contained molasses and deep dark caramel malts with a strong fruity presence. The nose found a light vinous quality to this vintage and some sherry. The beer poured murky amber brown with an extremely poor head which didnt stick around much past hello. The flavor was malty, deeply malty, with dark caramel, some cocoa and an excellent level of bittering to balance. The flavor was lightly fruity and contained dark fruits, raisins and prunes most notable. There was no particular hop to distinguish but they were certainly present to be enjoyed. The finish was dry with a bready and biscuit character with dark caramel lasting into the aftertaste and beyond. The body was full and slick on the palate with a very low level of carbonation. The alcohol was strong in the warming that occurred post consumption. A really great old ale. 12 ounce bottle. 2003 vintage.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: Clear brown, slightly hazy towards the end of the pour. Complex nose with malt flavours surrendering to brandy and caramel. Fade to hops at the finish, which is quite clean.

nice amber color, nose is LOTS of malt, and cognac. flavour is very malty. Very interesting barley wine, im used to more of a hop profile, hops seem to be lost in here. Very nice warmness from the alcoho, its present but not too much, very nice!

UPDATED: APR 10, 2007 2004 vintage. pours thick syrupy dark copper brown with a nice slowly disappearing khaki head. great  toffee aroma with a hint of raison and chocolate. sweet toffee raison flavor with a nice touch of chocolate and a spicy black pepper undertones that really shine on the finish. spicy caramel sweet finish that gets fairly dry near the end. full thick mouth feel. very nice barley wine. very smooth strong beer. reminds me a lot of a....uh not too much experience with this but a nice aged sherry....or even maybe port. would be very nice with dessert or cheese.   i cant wait to try some of the fresh batch so that i can compare....once the 2007 is available in the area i can finally do the 04-07 vertical. very nice....it makes me sad that there is no more in my glass...

Pours very deep ruby with a small to medium light tan head, oily on the glass.  Nose is creamy, buttery, and has an aroma of dark fruit and a slight bitter tang.  The flavor is initially quite sweet, seguing into a long, harsh, lasting bitterness.  Very oily and heavy mouthfeel.  I should have waited a year or so to drink this.
very strong nose dark brown color alcohol aroma and stron alchy burn in the throat drinakble though strong tast  not more to say a good strong lager grab on today i think i had 2006?

Bottle. 2006.  12 FL. OZ. Pours very brown with a hint of red and very little head that eventually disappears.  No lacing either.  Aromas of raisin and butterscotch.  Fairly full-bodied with very little carbonation. Flavor is smooth and sweet with a long finish.  Although you can tell its in there, this beer hides its 13.25% well.

2006 Bottle, 13.25% ABV.  Pours a cloudy mahagony with a fleeting head that dissipates to nothing.  Aromas of sweet sticky malts, caramels, toffee, butterscotch and earthy hops.  Similar flavors, nice mellow hop profile that intermixes well with the abundance of sweetness, but over the tops.  Creamy mouthfeel that really lingers during the finish.  A very nice beer that ages exceptionally.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: (2006 Bottle) Pours a reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma of alcohol and nutty maltiness. Taste is much of the same. Thick and syrupy, with hints of raisins and a mellow hoppiness in the aftertaste. Nice complexity, and a great beer.

"05 Vintage.  Alcohol, and lots of fruits in the aroma (raisins and melon).  Dark mohagany in color.  Full palate.  The taste is warm, malty, and bitter with a burning finish from the alcohol--definitely could use another year or two of age.

12oz bottle pours a dark ruby red with a small head that disappears almost immediately.  Aroma is strong sweetness, fruits, maple syrup. Smells thick.  Taste is the same though with maltiness and even some chocolate.  Nice balance.  A good example of the style.

2006 Bottle.  Strong sweet malty aroma with notes of dried fruit.  Thick billowing foam like head with a deep reddish brown color, a very attractive beer.  Thick creamy mouthfeel and sweet malt flavor with bits of cream cheese, figs, dates, and light citrus.  Definitely quite sweet.   Duration becomes more bitter as you wait, with a light alcoholic burn.  Very rich and tasty.

2007 Vintage.  Nice dark ruby color with decent clarity and a small, mostly diminishing, beige head.  Nose is sweet and fruity with dark fruits prominant (plums mostly) and a candy-like sweetness underneath with a light toasty note, whisps of alcohol, and faint hops.  Taste is still fruity with a plum or fig-like character and plenty of candy sweetness with a mild hop bitterness, but surprisingly minimal alcohol heat considering how young it is.  Palate is almost lively, medium-full, and lightly oily.  Finishes somewhat short and sweet but drying out some with notes of tobacco that linger.  Some good qualities in this one but still too sweet for my taste.  More hop presence would greatly help this one; malt forward BWs are just not my thing.

2006 edition via HogTown Harry (my dealer for all fine brews).  Pours a dark mahogany with minimal head. Smell is of dark fruits- taste follows along: figs, raisins, tobacco, coffee malt.  Hops are subdued on initial sips. I cant believe this stuff is 13%!!  Not boozy at all which is quite an accomplishment. It is a smooooth brew.  Hops show up more on the finish giving this beer a nice bitter rounding to it.  Its probably a good thing I only have one bottle of this, or it could spell trouble.

2002. This one held help nicely. Apple cider unfiiltered appearance. Caramel and fig with a slight hint of hop. Not as sweet as it once was- must have exhausted the yeast and begun to break down. This results in a dry and fairly clean finish. Glad I sat on it.

2005 edition. Pours an almost maroon red/brown/orange. No head, no lacing. Lots of good bite when sipped. Very fruity and packs a wallop. I taste grapes, raisins, candy, and whiskey. Quite good really.

Fairly new 2006 bottle. Clear copper color, medium head. Head disappears quickly, leaving spare lacing. Aroma of dark fruits, brown sugar and toffee. Tastes of toffee, raisins and alcohol. Heavy body. Alcoholic finish.
2004. Huge nose of brandy, alcohol, figs, and once it warms up grain and honey. Opaque. Mellow flavor of grains, some alcohol, very balanced and smoothe. Dry finish.
Slightly sour, crisp and bitter.  Rich mouth feel, smooth drinking.  Nutty with a detectable alcohol burn.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2007 2007 Vintage 2/25/2007- 12 oz bottle. A lot of soft grape and fig flavors with a heavy, lead-weighted maltbackbone that slides silky smooth into a mellow semiastringent hop finish. Alcohol was heavy on the nose but well hidden into body. Helluva drink.

2006 Vintage - 6/7/2007

Lots of Alcohol on the nose. Much like the 2007 edition with more currant and fig and maybe some apricot. It is noticably more mellow after a year of maturing. This was enough to convince me to cellar my 2007 remainders.

2005 vintage Aroma  8 Flavor 9 Appearance 4 Palate  4 Overall 18
12 oz. bottle opened 2/17/7 cellared about two years- color of murkey brown , with a small tan head - nose of licorice , caramel , raisins , beef broth , and roasted malt  taste of prunes , deep red fruit , port qualities , molasses , and care- body creamy smooth , and slight acidity  aftertaste of malts , and bitter sweet chocolate            

2006 vintage Aroma  8 Flavor 9 Appearance 4 Palate  4 Overall 18
12 oz. bottle 13.25% opened 2/17/7 cellared about one years - color of dark reddish brown , with a tan head - nose of  tannin , molasses , brown sugar , nutty , malty , and subtle red fruit  taste of molasses , caramel and butterscotch  body smooth , chewy , and low carbonation   aftertaste of caramel , and malts

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008 2006 bottle, probably 6months old now. pours dense mahonogy with good size off-white head. nose is full of plum/raisons. actually very reminisent of westy12. wow this version really smells like a trappist abt. flavor is much of the same, a very intense plum with alcohol warmth finishing. nose and flavor are a tad too sweet. the 2006 version is sorta like a barleywine crossed with an abt, and darn tasty at that, 7/4/7/4/16=3.8.  4/10/07, 2004 12oz bottle (aged 2-3 years). pours muddy copper with a slight glow to it and a nice tan head. nose has a really nice aged BW quality slightly oxidized combined with sweet caramel, berries, and mild chocolate. the nose very port like and wonderful. flavor is very malty, toasted nuts, maple syrup, still has some hop bitterness, and perhaps some slight fusel alcohols. finishes semi-sweet and warming. mouthfeel is medium, carbination low. alcohol doesnt bite. a few years has done this barleywine good. rating was increased 1 point for aroma and flavor, 8/4/8/4/16=4    2004 vintage, aged 3 years. pours muddy light brown with very thin white head around the rim. nose of tar, tobacco, alcohol, and some dark fruits. flavor has big tobacco aged malt notes, some sweet dark fruits, but then a big finish of some pretty hot alcohol. the alcohol isnt that harsh but its really warming and undeniable. this creates a lack of depth in the flavor dept. as it finishes. the body seems a bit thin or watery at times, but its an aged beer. carbonation seems oddly fizzy. perhaps this bottle didnt age well. 7/3/7/3/14=3.4 

1/17/07, 03-07 vertical 
2007, pours ruby-bronze with creamy tan head. nose is bready, maple syrup, nuts, alcohol. flavor of maple syrup, alcohol, yeasty, bready. alcohol coasts the mouth. pretty nice barleywine but needs age. 6/4/6/4/14=3.4. 
2006, pours dense ruby-brown with off white head. nose of maple syrup, cotton candy, dark fruits, nuts, sweet bread. flavor of maple syrup, nuts, toasted biscuit. full mouth feel. good body. this didnt quite hold up as it warmed but this has great aging potential. 7/4/8/5/15=3.9 
2005, pours hazy brown-amber with small tan head. nose of caramel, alcohol, cereal. flavor of maple syrup, yeasty, bready, dark fruits. thinest body of them all. this got better as it warmed but the aroma was never good. this seemed like an off vintage or perhaps bottle. 5/4/7/4/14=3.4. 
2004, pours ruby with tan head. nose of maple syrup, nuts, honey. flavor sweet alcohol, maple syrup, toffee, dark fruits, bread. alcohol warmth. good body. this was really nice. 8/4/8/4/15=3.9. 
2003, pours murky brown with tan head. nose of maple syrup, grains, slight vegetable, tobacco. flavor of dark fruits, maple syrup, caramel, bready. really smooth, a nice level (low) of oxidation.  8/3/8/5/16=4.0 
Final thoughts: The 2007 was the hardest to drink as this is a beer that clearly needs age on it. The 2006 was much improved since its release and starting to develop its aged character, this one could be the best batch yet in a few years. The 2005 was really the odd one, perhaps a bad bottle. We were all surprised the 03-05 werent more oxidized. 2003 was the winner but I cant see it getting much better, perhaps it could last another year although it wouldnt be too oxidized it just might drop off and start to fall apart. damn wish we had an 02 here.

2004 (bottle)poured into a tulip.  pours dark cloudy amber with tan head, quick to dissipate, not too high.  strong aroma a fig and grapes.  taste is of grape and raisins with the alchohol present in the aftertaste.  alchohol was present in the finish.  I like North Coast Brewery, so an aged limited release I was very excited to try, I got my hands on this 2004 vintage, and honostly it was not that great.  a little twangy, or sour.  i have to say i was dissapointed, I just did not like it that much.

Finally scored a bottle of the 2006 vintage.  Poured a red to brown with medium off-white foamy head.  Nose is rich malts, woody pine, and fruits.  Smooth mouthfeel for so much alcohol which is well masked.  Flavor includes chocolate. Nice slightly sweet finish.  Would love to get some more and lay it down for a year or two.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2007 strong alchohol aroma 2004. euuhhghhh.. hard to describe the flavor, alright not bad, tastes pretty good in my opinion not the greatest brew ive ever had but shit ill drink it... north coast old stock baby!! UGHH!!
2004 @ toronado barley wine festival:  warm socks, grapes & wine aroma & flavory. strong wine flavor, malts and light cherry notes.

2006 @ 13.25% -  Pours rich bronze with a fizzy soapy tan head.  The aroma has lots of caramel and toffee like malt that is very thick and rich.  Quite musty with some abv warmth.  There is also a light amount of pine / woody hops.  Medium / thick body with a moderate amount of sharp carbonation that is between soft and sharp.  The flavor starts with lots of thick malt like in the aroma, some abv warmth, but for the actual content is is not bad at all.  The finish has some spice and a kick to it.  This is a good barleywine, but certainly doesnt blow me away.  It continues to get sweeter further down the glass.   2005 @ 11.4% -  The malt is must mustier with less hops as well.  There is not much carbonation to speak of at all and has more alcohol burn even through there is less in the beer and it is a year older.  Not nearly as lush or rich as 2006 and has considerable more bite.  The rating is on the 2006 version only.

2002 vintage.  Cloudy reddish brown in color with very thin head that dissapates quickly.  Aroma is malty sweet with a hint of toffee and just a slight mustiness.  Rich and malty with lots of alcohol.  Sharp bitterness that gives a radish-like flavor (thats a first, never had that before!) just a little bit of roastiness in the finish. Alcohol the predominant flavor, and also thins the body.  The radish thing is just weird though.

12 oz bottle 2006, reddish orange brew with light tan, small foamy head. Aroma is sweet caramel, notes of cherry and honey. Almost a cream soda aroma. Deep bitterness, a bit astringent, malty caramel flavor. Alcohol burn is foremost in the palate. Very warming. My 2006 bottle indicates 11.6%

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2008 Another re-rate...I just tried a fresh 2008 version, 12.5%. Poured into a snifter, dark, rich mahogany, very thin off-white head. Nose is not as strong as previous versions: an array of dark fruits, most notably raisins and plums, strongly malted. Taste is surprisingly mild for such a young barleywine: the fruit flavors are even more evident here, with hints of a brash port wine. Palate is smooth. Love to try another 2008 in a few years.

Vintage 2004 bottle. Smells SEXY! Fig, brandy, malt, alcohol, honey, Pine and something halfway between almond and hazelnut. Deep amber hue, with almost 0 head except a perfect ring that clings tenaciously to the glass. The taste is exactly the ame as the smell and that is a wonderful thing. It made my cigarette afterward taste better. Full bodied and warm and creamy and happy and satisfying! I really needed all of those "ands". Its that good!
2005. Nose is rummy and sweetly hot. Flavour follows suit with a roast crescendo.  Bitterness balances well with the malt.

THOUGHTS: Hides alcohol well. Reminds me a little of Sam Adams Triple Bock. Not really what I was expecting, but still a great beer. I really dont understnd why this gets such high marks and Sam Adam Triple Bock doesnt when there are a lot of similarities. I could never understand how the Triple bock was a barley wine, since it was so much different than the others Ive tried, but the Old Stock was the missing link between the SA Triple Bock and other barley wines. This would probably be even better with some aging.
TECHNICAL: 2006 bottle. Poured a medium to dark brown with a small, almost soapy, off-white head that fully diminished. The aroma was heavy to almost harsh caramel malt along with chocolate syrup, soy sauce, sweet candy, light alcohol and underlying vinegar. The initial flavor was heavily sweet, with the finish flavor was heavy to harsh sweetness, light to moderate bitterness and just a tad salty. Caramel and chocolate syrup were throughout. The body was medium to full and syrupy with fizzy carbonation and a lightly alcoholic finish.
Had the 05 vintage.Lots of malt in the aroma.Pours a very deep copper with a large tan head.Big malt and alcohol stand out in the flavor.Full mouthfeel with a big malt and alcohol finish.
A great lovely barley goodnight brew that can last for enjoyment for many sippers in a long hour. Mahogny look and sweetmalty flavor with notes of smooth oaky cognac/port. Just Magnifique!!
12 oz bottle, 2006 vintage. On the bottle the alcohol % is 11.6% vice 13.25%. Pours copper color with minimal brown head. Sweet malty aroma. taste of malt and alcohol burn.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2007 This beer is complicated; it is very bourbon-y with wonderful wood and bourbon-y sweet flavor.  It is not particularly suited to my taste (I wouldnt call it delicious), yet I can still acknowledge that this is a very good beer!

Appearance is a sparkling, beautiful red color with a somewhat abundnant head that is very durable.  Aroma is very bourbon-y and slightly sweet.  Taste is also very bourbon-y, but without the over-sweetness or alcohol astringency that is associated with bourbon-barrel aged beer.  It is great for those who like bourbon, but bourbon-barrel-aging is too much for (thats me!).  Mouthfeel is rather smooth, and for all that bourbon flavor, this beer is rather drinkable.

12 oz bottle.  2004 Vintage.  I bought a 4 pack of this brew in the summer of 05 and had it a few times when I really didnt know what a BW was.  I saved this bottle, and after talking to some ratebeerians on the forum I thought why not crack it open it might be the right time.  The beer pours a dark reddish mahogany with a tan head that quickly has become a wide wing with an island of foam that looks sort of like a mallet from the perspective of looking at it from below.  The scent is rich dried fruit, sweet raisins.  The scent is quite potent.    The taste is thick rich and vinious, it warms the throat while also burning a bit more than Id like.  The aroma comes through in the taste but I cant but my finger on the notes.  The alchol is certainly there but it is not in the forefront it has mellowed nicely over time.  This beer could have likely matured more over time but then again, I wanted to drink it now and so I did.  Thanks North Coast.
UPDATED: OCT 31, 2007 Bottle.  Aroma of malt, sugar, and alcohol.  It actually smelled and tasted like vodka.  Peppery aftertaste.  Not enjoyable.

12oz bottle.  2006.  Aroma:  dark fruits (raisins), Caramel, sweet malt, bread, alcohol, and a slight berry aroma.  Appearance:  Dark coppery red in color and clear.  Light tan head was full and frothy with decent retention for a high abv beer.  Nice lacing.  Flavor:  Lots of malty sweetness up front with notes of brown sugar and caramel.  Toasted nuts, raisins, bread.  Alcohol is present throughout and gets a bit hot at times.  Sweetness lingers into the finish.  Palate:    Full bodied with a slight slickness.  Medium carbonation.  Alcohol warming over entire mouth.  Overall:  This one is very good right now, but I think will be even better in a couple of years.

12oz bottle, 2005 vintage.  Pours a hazy, rust-brown appearance; fluffy, yellowish-tan head with good retention and lacing.  Becomes progressively more aromatic in the glass, showing candy sugar, dried red fruits, and plenty of alcohol.  Full, chewy mouthfeel: maple syrup and nougat; well-incorporated citrus and piney hops; warming, layered, and well-balanced.  Lengthy, brown sugar and citrus hop finish.

This hearty snifter jewel is all about palate. Its mouthfeel is perhaps best described as erotic (sensual, tactile, warming)...and a long, slow bottle will leave you basking in the afterglow. This Old Stock is sweet, but classy. Its more complex than most brews with this much marzipan-molasses-desert honey-cotton candy character...though, of course, its not something you ponder over (like an Islay single malt). Its just a voluptuous treat! (The 2006 is cellaring very well.)

Dark, red mahogany. The aroma is vinous with notes of dark fruits, raisin, caramel and cake. The mouthfeel is oily. The flavour is wonderful with notes of chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, bread/cookie, fruit (raisin, plum) and its vinous. What a nice beer!!!

vintage 2003- thanks to dad---pours brown and ruby its a deep red, the head dispersed quickly but seems very carbonated. smells sweet cherries, strawberries and alcohol like cognac almost. tastes smooth with strong berry overtones and alcohol warming going all the way down the throat.  caramel sugar there are other components i cant put my finger on. either way it is quite good.

2006, 13.25% ABV

For a new guy this beer almost put me on my ass. Also this was very drinkable for a 13% beer. The smell "nose" was ok, could be better. This was probably the third beer i tried since expanding my horizons and i just think it weakened all other beers. Yeah, I said it.

Pours to a thick amber.  Serious, thick aroma that, while not of any overriding aroma, tends towards chocolate and strawberry twizzler. Roasted malts are definititely present as are hints of winter spices  nutmeg and perhaps a bit of cinnamon perhaps.  This is an intense experience that has more of a feel of scotch than beer and has an ABV to match.  While Im enjoying this particular bottle at a fairly chilled temp, I have to wonder how it would taste warm  thats how much it recalls scotch for me.  Pretty amazing beer and one that I would love to try again.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2009 Rerate.  A much different experience than the last time.  On tap at PP Carlsbad.  Color was a glowing amber.  Aroma of caramel, fruit, cocoa and sweet malt.  Flavor had a lot of doughy and caramel notes; some cocoa.  Mildly hopped.  Overall it was sweet and doughy.  Very nice.  

Poured a deep amber/copper.  Medium to small head.  Aroma was sweet, malt, and raisin; alcohol very present.  Taste is of roasted malt, miminal sweetness, fruit, pepper, alcohol; slight burning on the throat.

2006 bottle - why does this not have more than one listing?  Clear deep reddish copper colored pour.  Foamy light tan quick diminishing head.  This is a great looking beer.  Aroma is almost wine-like  sweet candy, plums, and raisins.  Smooth and slick palate.  Slightly thick and a bit more carbonated than I expected.  Flavor is sweet fruit and alcohol  slightly hot.  This will certainly get better with time.

2006 bottle.  Dark brown/red color, didnt pour much head and it dissipated quickly.  No lacing.  Aroma is of roasted malt, caramel, alcohol.  Taste is of roasted heavy malt, plums, tangy sweet alcohol finish.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2008 Sampled 2004-2007, rating the 04. The 04, has a amazing hints of caramel, and alcohol. It also has your typical barleywine style taste, without a lot of hops. Finished with a smooth masking of alcohol matched with the spices, caramel, and other malts.

Vintage 08. Pours dark brown with no head. Aroma is booze. Tastes of caramel, figs, and more booze. Palate seems a little thin and boozy. Not as impressed as earlier vintages. Total score for this one is 3.5.

2006 vintage. The four pack has been growing on me. At first it did not compute as a Barley Wine but since tasting a Raison D Extra and an Avery The Beast it does rate well in the category of "sweet fortified strong ales." If youre looking for something sweet, strong and mellow, this ranks high. If youre looking for a classic Barley Wine, look elsewhere.

2003 vintage...

Pours a nice brown with tones of ruby where it catches the light. Briefly topped by a quarter inch of tan foam, then it reduces to a ring and a thin filmy clump of bubbles. Nice aroma of plum, caramel, cherry, and fig.

Drier malt than I expected (and remembered), but very tasty – toffee and toasted malt and lots of ‘em. Also peach pit, toasted almond, and a trace of hop bitterness. Driy finish with alcohol and mild spice in the aftertaste. Medium full body, ample carbonation.

Courtesy Solan.  Pours a rich hazy amber, very light white head.  Get alot of cheese in the smells, dont ask me what kind, I dont know the names.  Maybe a "funky swiss."  Also get some, syrupy malts and a little sweetness.  Definitely get it in the taste as well.  This one kind of hangs out in the back of the mouth.  A mellow sweetness, with heavy malts as well.  This is the 06 version and you can definitely get a little higher sense of the alcohol since it was increased.  Id like to try this one in a year.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 2006 version. Red, sweet and flavorful. Goes down easily, like a lambic but without the strong alcohol taste. Pretty good.

Sample from distributor, 2005 bottle.
Wow, any description does it no justice.  Enjoy this with a meal, alcohol will overwhelm an empty palate.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2007 WOW!! 2006 bottle from drewbeerme. Amber/burgundy color with small head. Caramel aroma and flavor with some smooth spices  showing. Malty, rich ,and sweet. Some alcohol in the finish. Excellent beer, I MUST get a case!!

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2009 Sampled two vintages from bottles at the Rivers Bend Barleywine/Old Ale Tasting on 1/18/2007...
2005 Vintage:  Pours a ruby caramel color with a yellowish head.  The aroma is alcohol and pale/amber and caramel malt.  The sweet flavor has lots of caramel as well with a very smooth alcohol finish.  Medium+ body.  Creamy and smooth on the palate.  11.4% ABV.

2006 Vintage:  Pours a clear dark amber color with a foamy, light brown head.  Roasted malt aroma.  Weak bourbon-like alcohol flavor with some caramel.  The alchol becomes more astringent in the finish as the 13.25% ABV kicks in.  Still very smooth and easy to drink for the high content!  

Having the chance to try two vintages of the same beer side by side is a fun, interesting, and memorable experience.  Its amazing how different the same recipe turns out after some aging and from year to year!  The North Coast Old Stock Ale is a great beer that seems to be great to drink young as well as aged!
Rating:  7  4  8  4  16 = 3.9

2003 Vintage
5/21/2008:  North Coast Old Stock Ale 2003 has an opaque dark amber brown color with some golden highlights.  There is no head, but there is still some active carbonation.  The aroma is deeply malty with rich and creamy caramel and, lightly roasted malt, and a tinge of whisky-like alcohol.  The flavor is also intensely malty and quite sweet.  It has a nice balance of smooth, rich and creamy caramel, dark raisins, sweet dates, caramelized fruits, syrupy white grapes, and warming whisky alcohol and cigar-like tobacco and deep, aged apricot flavor that adds to the experience.  The alcohol really isnt overpowering or out of place in any way.  This beer has a full body and is smooth smooth is a good creaminess that coats the palate and mouth nicely.  This vintage is really good right now and will continue to be so for several more years to come at least...
12 fl. oz. bottle (Alc./Vol. 11.4%) from Brock Landers via trade.  Thanks John!  Rating:  8 4  8  4  17 = 4.1

Bottle - 2006. I am confused off the bat, the bottle states 11.6%.  Oh well, time to get crackin! Pours a dark reddish-brown with a nice off-white head on top. Aroma is caramel, sweet fruit, toffee, and alcohol. Flavor is full of sweet fruit, caramel, and plums. The alcohol is not completely masked but it certainly doesnt take away from the beer. The alcohol greats a nice firey taste. I wouldnt mind trying some older vintages to see how it ages.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2008 2006 Vintage bottle -07. Pours a beautiful, dark reddish brown. Short-lived brown head. Dark and clear, with carbonation visible just under the head. The aroma is fruity-sweet with strong alcohol notes, some plums and caramel. In the mouth its almost chewy, but more from its complexity than from its thickness. Sweet and strong, with lots of flavors that linger on the palate.

2004 Vintage -07. Two years did a fantastic job on the beer. Heavy malt nose, with subdued alcohol and a wonderful sweetness. Honey, banana, caramel, figs, almonds. Pours cloudy dark amber with zero head except for a ring around its body which doesnt lace, but instead drops down intact with a tilt of the glass. Exceedingly creamy mouthfeel. Thick and chewy, substantial. Sweetness sits perfect and smoothness allows it to do so without becoming offensive. Flavor is soft sweetness and alcohol. Slight bitterness in the aftertaste, but not dry. Caramel opening, folds into sweet alcohol, into almonds with a slight tinge of hops at the finish.

A real strong ale: 11,4 abv. Dark amber and a bit unclear. Has a yellow-reddish head, big for a start but not very lasting. Aroma of sweet laqurice, and some smoke, nice. Oily palate. Flavor is fatty and somehow sweet, laqurice again?

(Bottle, vintage 2006) Reddish brown colour with small, brief, pale brown head. Huge, slightly roasted, nose with toffee, caramel, herbs and chocolate. Malty, fiery taste with lots of toffee, fudge, chocolate, dark rye bread, herbs, dried fruit and hints of coffee and soy sauce. Sweet, fiery, vinous finish with a warming alcohol bite. A nice puff of hops balances the sweetness nicely. Very tasty, very warming, very nice beer.

Very sweet aroma,malt and alcohol . Amber red color light brown head. Very thick palate almost chewy. Taste matches the aroma. Very sweet, lots of malt and alcohol reminds me more of a dopple bock then a barly wine. A very nice beer. Ill have to try this vintage again in a year or two and see how it ages.
2005 bottle. Strong and smooth. Reddish amber in color, small white head. Dark fruit in the nose and on the palate. Gentle English hops make it a nice, round beer. Excellent.

12 oz bottle from Total Wine, 2006 version.  This is my first barley wine, so Im not sure what to expect with this one checking in at 13.25%.  Pours a murky copper amber color with a this white head.  Aroma is sweet and hoppy.  Flavor is sweet and full of fruit with a touch of bite on the end.  Alcohol is very well masked on the end.  This will get you drunk.
big plummy, brown bread aroma, with some wood smoke & pine. glides through the mouth. flavor too sweet, a bit like sherry. very smooth and skillful.

Pours deep dark ruby/brown with a nice creamy tan head. Very fruity sweet aromas, with notes of caramel, alcohol, and a hint of hops. Flavor encompasses all of the aroma and more. Dark fruit, cognac, caramel, alcohol, chocolate, and some nice bitterness on the finish. Palate is full, a little alcoholic astringency, nice lingering hops, and a bit of sweetness. Hopefully get to try this again with a year or so in it.
Nice deep brown color. Aroma is that of cognac. Lots of caramel in the flavor. Slightly syrupy, which detracts just a bit overall.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2009 2004 Bottle, dark amber red pour into the glass, few bubbles around the edges, malty sweet, lots of caramel, light hop flowers fragrance, chocolate, toffee, touch of earthiness in the nose, sweet malt taste with a little hop bite, little bit of brandy, caramel, port wine, some alcohol warming in the throat and nose, the hop bite lingers some after each sip.

(2006) Very dark orange with thin tan foam.  Mostly malt and caramel aroma.  Sweet fruits, malts, caramels, brown sugar taste with a heavy-medium syrupy body and slightly bitter finish.  Very complex and tasty, but a bit too sweet and syrupy.

2003 Bottle. Pours a very dark auburn with no head. Off white lacing. Nose of heavy sweet malts, dark fruits, alcohol, and a little citric hops. Flavor is heavy is brown sugar malts, sherry, definite alcohol, molasses, and light hops. Why is this called an old ale but is listed as a barleywine. I still dont understand the difference between the two. This is good, but a bit heavy in flavor and body.  Syrupy mouthfeel. Let it warm and was a little smoother. A nice brew.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a medium head. Aroma and flavour of alcohol, caramel and fruits.

2005 vintage.  I enjoyed this one for almost an hour.  A beautiful color to this one with no foam on top.  A malty aroma with tons of other sweetnesses and dried fruits.  Finishes dry with some slight bitterness to it.  As it warms, it is less heavy.  Highly Enjoyable.

[12oz 2006 Bottle]
Deep amber color with a nice head.  This was a deep barley wine with a rich flavor loved the fruitnes tot his brew and the finish was very sweet.  Great Barley Wine.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2008 <<RE-RATE 9/3/07>> 12 oz bottle. 2006 on label.  Pour is orange, brown and rust. Hazy pour with a nice 2 inch tan head. Leaves a bit of lacing on the glass. Aroma of burnt caramel sugar, and some slight metallic oxidation. Taste has some brown sugariness, orange peel and more of the wet cardboard oxidation. Palate was bit thinner than I had remembered. I think i waited a bit to long on this. 4,7,5,3,12 = 3.1 I will leave the original rating.

<<ORIGINAL RATING 12/22/06>>2006 Bottle.  Deep auburn pour.  Nice whitish-tan head that goes away, but a bit slower than most barley wines.  Caramel, touch of sweetness, nice full body.  Overall good barley wine.  7,4,7,4,16 = 3.8

This weekend I did a 3 year vertical of this. 02,03,04 all were very nice. This beer ages very well, the 2002 started having a bit of oxidation, but nothing that was too distracting. All beers being 2+ years old had a great balance with no alcohol being apparent. Its amazing how smooth this beer gets as it ages. While it doesnt start out with the hops that beers like Bigfoot have, it still ages to a great malt character. The hops really die out, but that leaves you with a great malt flavor that picks up sherry notes, plum, caramel, and fig. The 2002 had a very nice fig flavor in the start finishing with a bit more of a sherry flavor. The 2003 had a bit more fruitiness, more plum and caramel and a bit of molasses. The 2004 had more hops so it gained a bit more hop balance. I realy recommend aging these, they did really well, even at 4 years old there was very little oxidation, the carbonation was still all there,  and the flavors were brilliant. I will continue to purchase these every year and save them for a few before openning.

2006 bottle.  Deep copper pour with a small tan head which fades quickly.  Thick pungent aroma of caramel maltiness, prunes, figs and brandy.  Rich malts and dark fruit flavor kicking in first.  Flavor then fades to a sharp hop bite and hot alcohol.  Medium to full body with a fair amount of carbonation and a strong alcohol burn.  This one definitely needs to sit for a few years.
Dark copper. No head. Alcohol nose. Burnt caramel, brown sugar and molasses flavours.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2008 12 oz bottle via liquid Solutions. 2005 vintage...Pours a dark reddish brown with a large tan head. Subtle nose of toasted grains, caramel, vanilla. Taste is of molasses, caramel, toffee and plums with an alcohol finish that is good and not too hot. Awesome beer but more like an Old ale than a barleywine. World class stuff in either case....drinkable and tastey
***************new rating************old rating was 7/4/9/4/18***********
12 oz 2008cbottle via Liquid SOL. Pours a semi-clear copper with an average size beige head. Nose is toffee and candy with some fruitiness. Taste is very malty, lots of caramel and biscuity. A bit of candy which i assume is from the yeast, as well as a little spiciness...cinnamon and ginger. Finish is a little hot and the earthy hops are generous, cellaring would help. Body is medium. Carbonation just right. A good beer, that will be better with age.
****************new rating********2008 bottle rating was 7/3/8/4/17=3.9****************
12 oz 2003 bottle via Bridgeview. 5 years old. Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Nose is oxidized, alcoholic, candyish. Taste is burnt caramel, toasty, biscuity, plus, raisins, bourban, oak. Body is full, carbonation medium.

Heavy alcohol taste.  My first sip, I told my wife I really liked this beer.  My last sip I wasnt having the same reaction.  The alcohol is definately present.  It is a complex beer.  I had the 2005 edition.  I will try it again.

2006 bottle; pours a beautiful clear amber with a slight deep tan head that dissipates very quickly; no lacing.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, toasted malt.  Taste follows aroma nicely, adding a warm alcohol finish and a touch of vanilla.  A bit sweet and youthful as expected, but I couldnt resist giving this a go; definitely has the potential for mellowing well; I look forward to a rerate after giving it some time in the cellar...

Pours a deep hazy amber/bronze with fading tan head. Thick aroma of spicy toffeeish malts. Slight chocolatey touch, resiny hint, and strong alcohol touch. Sweet caramel body with strong surfaced alcohol, which hurts the throat. Slightly chocolatey and caramel notes, slight zesty peppery alcohol bite, light citrus (tangerine) hint, a resiny hop touch and a long roasty dry alcohol burn finish. Too much alcohol which masks the other flavors. It would be great with less alcohol flavor.
Too sweet! No hop flavor, and even alcohol taste is hidden by sweetness. I can tell that this is a quality brew crammed with expensive ingredients---but I wouldnt buy again.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2008 In the bottle at my 2006 Barleywine tasting. This was the 2004 vintage. Pours dark amber with a thin vaporous head. Huge alcohol nose. Some caramel and chocolate to the nose, but mostly alcohol. A semi-sweet malt taste is hidden behind a burning sensation all down your gullet. Very astringent. Has a harsh palate. Slight black cherry taste, prunes and brown sugar. Bitter hop residual finish. update 6/2008: 2008 vintage. reddish amber with a thin white head. nose is fruity and alcohol. has the aroma of paint thinner. lots of heat. burns all the way down. oranges, chocolates, figs, this is a very strong beer. the alcohol is too unbalanced right now and should be put away for a while.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2008 Bottle, 2004 (Im the 667 rater, bad luck to the fella before me).  Murky brown color with a very thin off white head.  Farily complex aroma: alcohol, caramel malts, vanilla, oak, pepper, spices, anise, faint hops.  Flavor is not as pleasant as the aroma, I was hoping for more hops.  Still, decent, malts, bitter almond, peppery and spicy again, alcohol and bitter on the finish.  Finish is strangely bitter, more like the pith of an orange than that pleasant bitterness you get from hops.  Mouthfeel is a bit oily, but carbonation is good.  This beer isnt bad, but it falls off steeply in comparison to the aroma.  I can definitely taste, and feel, the alcohol.  Worth having, but not more than once........  Rerate - had some 2005 on tap (3 years old) - this beer holds up really well over time.  Becomes really chocolatey and full.  Very nice.

Pouring into the pilsner is a beautiful reddish colored ale, creating a really nice head.  It smells very malty and upon the 1st tase, a slight taste of licorice hits the back of your throat.  A very good and smooth ale

A very good, very well-rounded brew! Poured a cloudy ruddy orangish color with just a wisp of white head across the top. Nose of fermented sweet fruits, nuts and caramel. Wine-like and sweet that could become over powering were it mot for the balancing bitter that rounds the drink out nicely. Hints of warm alcohol in the finish. Very good.

May get another and let it age a year or two to see how it is.

Bottled 2006 edition. Pours a clear red-tinged dark amber with a fading tan head. The aroma is nutty, fruity, vinous. Medium body with fine carbonation. The taste is sweet and wine-like, with dried fruit and nuts. A bit of bitterness and plenty of warmth on the finish. I can see where this beer would benefit from some aging.

2004 bottle.  Poured a murky orange/brown with a quickly diminishing head.  Small spots of lacing. Aroma of pungent fortified wine (sherry, port), lots of alcohol, prune, currant, molasses and candied citrus peel.  Sweet syrupy malt flavor, with some dried fruit and woody hops.  Some alcohol warmth and smokiness on the finish.  Has a great after-dinner or dessert character and is a nice holiday cold weather warmer.  Im not sure if its even at its full potential after just two years of aging.

Im gonig to givve it a 3.6 bcause it had so mch alchol. It was really strong. Had 3, 12 ounce bottles. It tastes good but definately like alchohol and hops. I am going to try buying some more and letting it sit for a while.

12oz 2005.  very nice pour with almost no head and a deep red color.  excellent first sip (cellar temp.) smell is maple syrup and spice, this tastes like a perfect winter warmer... the pour and aroma made me think barley wine, but there seems to be more going on here... the alcohol is not hidden and it works well with the chilled sweet flavors (raspberry and sugar) and the warming bitter spices (hint of hops)...  it was yummy today, and I know that the other 12oz bottle I have will be tasty with some age

2006 bottle. Pours a mahogany color with fat off-white head. Aroma of over ripe fruit, toffee and nuts. Taste is big and complex as many flavors dance around.  I can detect raisins, almonds, malt, brown sugar and caramel. This is nicely balanced brew with a definate alcohol kick to it. The alcohol is delicately intertwined in all of flavors so the the beer finishes easy and smooth. Nice!

2004 bottle, consumed 2006.  Pours dark reddish brown w/ok head. Tried one too cold and another room temp.  Too much alcohol for my taste, which made it hard to taste the flavor, but what there was was good.

malty, complex maple-y alcohol aroma.  pours thick, but not black. viscous enough for the alcohol to coat the glass.  flavors of figs, almonds, maple syrup.  slight noble hop bitterness, but overshadowed by sweetness and alcohol.  complex and delicious, almost more like a young brandy or liqueur than even the average barleywine, but the strong malt flavor on the back of the palate brings it back into beer territory.  unique and delicious.  even more interesting as it warms up.  truely a beer to be savored and enjoyed slowly.

2005 bottle/2006 tap. Did a vertical here
2005: pours wiht a brown color and a nice off white head. Aromas are of
caramel, molasses, maybe even some maple syrup.
The flavors are dominated by caramel, malts, raisins and almonds. The alchols i well in the background but come through at the finish.
2006: clearly has aging potential. The flavors are more dominated by alcohol and the other nuances are hidden a bit. I am sure it will be as good as the 1005 with a bit of aging.
2006: 6/4/6/4/14/3.4

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2009 Bought @ Jakes bar and bistro. adding to a past post, drinkin a bottle from 2007 and it is, oh so good!! now back to original post... This beer is sssooo different from last year!?! Last year it became a wonderful beer after 2 months, this year this is like a thurobread horse, right out of the gate this beer is ready! the nose is somewhat elusive giving some sort of honeydew melon meets maple sugar thing, that leads into a real treat! The mouthfeel gets fizzy when held in the mouth for too long, but over-all has a nice carbonation. The flavor stays the course of the nose, some sort of melon meets maple syrup with some sort of spice, but in a GREAT way! 13.25% I just cant see (until it hits me upside the head!). All in all this beer rocks! Just drink in moderation!!

Syrupy thick ruby red pour...carbonated small white head.  This aroma reminds me so much of Thomas Hardy barelywine.  The taste is quite different  though.  This 2006 tastes soooo fresh.  Bitter hoppy, dark sweet malts, warming alcohol...  The complexity is not there yet, I guess.  This should develope into a knock out...time will tell.

Pours an amberish copper color, very light almost no head. Strong aroma, alcohol, malts, and fruit. Flavor was strong and malty, with hints of the fruit in there as well, maybe a bit too strong for me, but not too bad overall.

2006. New bottle. too cold. Pours with no head. 13.5%?? Word. Ok, its warmed up a bit. I am watching the Suns beath the Clippers, drinking this new old stock, and enjoying myself immensely. Smells of dark fruits, green apple, alcohol, redwood. More dark fruits and malt in the mouth. Alcohol is very prominent. Very slight bitterness. I should have saved this one. This beer will age very well. Cant wait to try it in 2010.

Poured to a very carbonated hazy reddish-brown color, with minimal off-white head that lingers a while, then fades to no lacing. Very strong aroma of malt, dark fruit and alcohol, wiith taste more of the same. As beer warms, the alcohol (13.25%) becomes much more dominant. The palate is smooth and warming at first, but again is overcome by the high alcohol content. This would make a great winter warmer.

2004 bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark brown with some orange highlights.  Aroma is wonderful on this, better than I remember from trying before.  Smells very much like grapes, with caramel and brown sugar.  Clearly beer, but very winelike.  Very sweet taste, but in a careless sugary fashion.  This is incredibly nice and smooth, yet strong, with toffee, butterscotch and vinuous notes going down.  According to my girlfriend (with an excellent sense of smell), this beer has some sort of "Christmas bread" flavor to it.  I felt like I can taste my Grandmas basement in this beer somehow.  Its as if the term "cellaring" became more literal than intended.  Thick full mouthfeel, very low carbonation.  A beer that veils as many different flavors as it flaunts.  I think 2 years time did wonders to this beer, as it certainly emphasizes the "wine" in "barley wine."

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2012 2005 bottle: Poured a nice dark brown with a thin but firm tan head.  Deep roasty nose.  Big time flavors here that made me wish Id saved this bottle ... Ill probably go get another and cellar it.  This is big and roasty, sharp and tangy.  Hint of coffee, bitter chocolate.  Superior, stellar brew.

2007 bottle: Ruby-garnet-tinged brown pour with a thin top.  The aroma is very strong, full of roasted malt, and a sweet alcohol-laden air.  This drinks with a gigantic character  if it were human, everyone would turn and look when he entered the room.  Warm and toasty, theres an added hint of hazelnut and baking chocolate.  Excellent strong ale, worthy of its lofty ratings. 

2012 Bottle, caged and corked.  Consistent with my previous experiences, only in a bigger bottle.  Only one beer tonight.
Very dark pour with little head. Smell of toasted malt and hops. Nice flavor of malt,coffee,hops and bitter sweet choclate. Very thick beer on the mouth. Nice drinker when cold outside.
Bottle, a great winter warmer.  Have a half case (2005) aging to compare with 2006 vintage.  A classic, beer grasps you, rich with all kinds of flavors, sip and enjoy!
Got this from Bierkraft. 2004 bottle. Aroma of bread, cereal, toast, and dough. An amber, cloudy body full of particles. tan foamy head. Amazing flavor. Very heavy and rich beer. Sip this one slowly.
Moleasses on the nose..pepsi-colored...alcohol covered very well...finish leaves tiny bubbles in da mouth...:o

Bottle 2006.  I dont remember the previous vintages being this complex.  A very good beer.  Brown sugar and maple syrup in the nose and on the tongue.  A very strong, English-style barley wine.  Much like an amped-up version of Old Nick.  Really good.

what a delight

many differnt flavors in this one. and the aroma is to die for

Botlle . 2005 11.4%
Foggy ,hazzy amber with medium creamy fine tan top.
Fine,solid rich malty aroma. Good quality alcohol. Hints of buble gum and plums.
This potent ale have woody,malty charcter strongly accented by medium dry alcohol. Vineus. Its hard to be balanced at this potency but its that I wish for.
Dark redish brown with a short lived tan head. Malty with alcohol sweetness. Full bodied with a long, smooth and warming aftertaste.Some bitterness.

Beautiful dark brown color with a tan head.  A sweet aroma with some alcohol and hops.  A sweet malt flavor that has some rum/alcohol flavor that finishes with a some hop bitterness.  Not like most barley wines I have had.  Good though

2005 vintage. The aroma on this beer sold me on its merits before it even got 1/2 way to my mouth. Strong and warm, with very low phenolics for a beer this young. Good carbonation as well that brings the hop bittering and aroma out as it bubbles. I am going to try this vintage again in a year or two to see how it goes.
Wow, this beer smells like heven.  Oh man, thats a really good beer.  There is so much going on in this beer it makes my head spin.  No more writing about it, Im just gonna drink it.

This North Coast product is full of malty aroma.  It is a very cool looking beer being dark brown with a light colored foam.  First taste says malt and it also says alcohol!  The abv is listed as over 13%!  Underneath the malt is a light hoppy flavor and perhaps some barley under that.  Toffee and dark fruit can also be found.  This is a smooth drinking beer and the light aftertaste is sweet and pleasant.  It also tends to change moment by moment and cascades in waves. Late in the glass the malt flavor has subsided and the fruit is out front.   Last night I had North Coasts Old Rasputin and now this one.  Are all of their beers this good?!  I am trying to find a fault with Old Stock Ale but am having no success.  Well, if left unattended the cold bottle will leave a ring on my wood furniture.
Deep amber with thin white head. Cane sugar, fruit and sweet malt. Soft and smooth with nice balance.

picked up a 4pk. of the new 06 old stock and was pleased with the new packaging colors. the nice warm sunflower/british kakai catches the eye. second item of note- this year the abv weighs in at a nigh staggering 13.25 %. was this perhaps once a part of the avery demons of ale series? so, here we go. poured it into a nice, frosty, straight from the freezer mug...and if you are still taking me seriuosly than congratulations, you have exposed yourself as a beer geek fraud. goblet-style all the way on this tasty motha. so, rich, malty, deep aroma, capped with slight licorice character. body was a wonderful deep tawny hue with very slight creeping effervecense. flavours of obvious malt sweetness, deep pit fruits, vanilla dancing on the perimeter, finishing smoothly and with wisps of molasses. mmm. what i think is the stand-out quality of this offering is the incredible balance- the alcohol is extremely well hidden to the point of near aninimity for such a strong beer while the rest of the experience flows with the grace of a ballet dancer (like one of those human greyhounds would ever disrespect their underdeveloped frames with something this decadent). cheers again to the masters at north coast.

tap at the brewpub - Pours a murky reddish brown with a thin head.  The aroma is very malty with some alcohol.  The flavor is also very malty with a toffee note, some alcohol buried under that sweetness, and dark fruit notes.  It has a long, dry finish.  Nicely done, North Coast.

12 oz. bottle 2006 version
Aroma: Very malty nose with sugars and alcohol beneath
Appearance: Muddy red brown with a nice head of medium sized tan bubbles and minor lacing
Flavor: Caramel and chocolate malts are pronounced with an alcohol bite
Palate: Malty and dry.  The best thing about this beer though is it is not as dry as you would expect with a 13.25% content.  I did a double take when I read it on the label as I expected an elevated number but not that high!
Overall: Well done on a finely crafted brew.  I enjoyed it much and would like to try it again.  I find it very interesting that some people are saying it was clear red when the one I had was very murky which others have stated too.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2016 First ratingInitial Rating Date: 9/14/2006 5:40:09 PM - UPDATED 9/26/2008
Bottle on RBESG 20062006 bottle. Clear brown color, tan head. Sweet malty a bit alcohol scent. Sweet raissin and some alcohol taste. Medium bitterness, soft but big mouth feel. Warming alcohol feeling.7/4/8/3/13=3.5
Second rating, 2006 vintage:Somewhat shady brown color, tan head. Lots of alcohol in the scent, sweet malt as well. Spicy bitter malty taste. Smooth milky mouthfeel. Sharp bitterness, some hartburn feeling.5/3/5/3/10=2.6Rerate355 ml bottle from Systembolaget, thanks to deft!On September 26, 20082008 vintageBB Aug 2010Clear dark reddish copper color, medium tan head. Fruity, smooth, sweet scent, some red berries and a bit of alcohol. SWeet, phenolic, spicy, dry, malty, caramel taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Dry lingering malty aftertaste.7/4/7/4/14=3.6RerateVertical tasting first half of 2012, never entered my notes until now.Sampled side by side vintages: 2011 vs 2010 vs 2009 vs 2007 vs 20062011: Clear dark red color, small tan head. Malty, alcohol, some smoke scent. Sweet, malty, salty, alcohol taste. Smooth mouthfeel, alcohol aftertaste. Low bitterness.7/3/7/4/15=3.62010: Clear dark red color, small tan head. Sweet, malty, alcohol scent. Malty, sweet, alcohol taste. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/3/7/3/14=3.42009: Clear dark red color, small tan head. Sweet, sassafras, minty scent. Sweet, cream, malty taste. Medium smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness.8/3/8/4/15=3.82007: Clear dark red color, small tan head. Alcohol, chemical scent. Sweet, malty, sugary, grainy taste. Smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness.6/3/8/4/15=3.62006: Clear very dark brown color, small to very small tan head. Sweet, fruity, alcohol scent. Alcohol, solvents, cream, malty taste. Smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/3/8/4/15=3.7Rerate12 fl oz bottle thanks to Ingo! Sampled on December 22, 2012. Vintage 2011.Hazy brown color, yellow head. Sweet, malty, citrus scent. Sweet, raisin, figs, alcohol taste. Spritzy mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Warming alcohol.I would probably like it better if aged some more, a bit young still.7/3/7/2/13=3.2RerateBottle at Bishops Arms Örebro on May 25, 2013.Didnt take notes since I knew I had rated this over and over, this was the 2010 vintage.Wonderful aged scent and taste. Alcohol still coming through, but holds up nice and was a very nice finish to this evening.8/4/8/3/26=3.9RerateBottle thanks to Ingo! On January 8, 2016.Vintage 2010, 11,7% ABV.Hazy brown color, teal head. Sweet, malty, tobacco flower, marzipan, alcohol scent. Malty, fudge, alcohol, bitter taste. Malty, alcohol, bitter aftertaste. Warming gut feeling. Smoothish mouthfeel, medium to medium high btterness.9/3/8/4/17=4.1

UPDATED: APR 3, 2007 Bottled (2006, 13.25 %). Lovely ruby reddish colour mixed with a bit of copper. Small beige head. Aroma of alcohol, caramel and sweet malts. A bit glueish also. Flavour is plum, biting alcohol and malts. Some roast and caramel in aftertaste. Too strong alcohol in it, otherwise good. 7 3 6 3 13
Bottled (11.4 % 2001 vintage, drank March 2007 @Oliver Twist, Stockholm). Hazy dark rubyish brown colour, small beige head. Aroma is oak, plum, mild roast, wineous and slightly vanillaish. Flavour is wood, plum, dark fruits, dark sugar and slight vanillaish notes in Finish. This one has aged very well! 8 4 8 4 16.

Bottled vintage 2006.
Clear dark ruby red, steady small brown head. Toffeish, caramelly, dark fruits, burnt malts in the nose. Soft, liquerish palate. Toffee, roasted malts, some licorice. Brandy-like warming alcohol in the aftertaste.

Pours a cloudy brown with a three fingered tan head.  Aroma bears notes of hops, malt, dark fruit, and alcohol.  Full bodied with a strong malty complexity with a nice hoppish balance and smooth finish.

(2004 11.3%). Reddish brown with beige mostly deminishing head. In the nose it bears promis of lots of malt, hops, copper and alcohol. Some cask wood and dust is also detected. In the flavour these promises are fulfilled and a little salty note and some acid follows them up. The finish is dry and foremost lasting. Great beer!

Pours a dark brown.  Head is minimal, carbonation rises from bottom of the glass and scatters across the surface in small clusters.  Slightly sweet with flavors of mild fruits and a surprisingly mild alcohol flavor for the high content.  Delicious and a joy to sip.

Pours deep red with a small white head.  Aroma is caramel, dark fruits, piny hops, alcohol.  Flavor is smooth, with dark fruits, a bit of buttery tones, lots of pine in the finish, alcohol.  Alcohol flavor and aroma are a bit too big for my liking.  Finish is nice and long.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008 8/30/2006  2006 bottle pours caramel with no head.  Beautiful aromas of alcohol and dark fruit.  A nice thick mouthfeel that is incredibly smooth for a barley wine.  Dark fruits, toffee, and brown sugar and alcohol flavors are balanced.  I cant wait a couple of years to see how it will be. 8/3/8/4/17 = 4.0

03 - 07 vertical on 1/18/2008 thanks to a combined effort with drewbeerme and xnoxhatex.  
07 - Clear orange brown with a soapy beige head.  Caramels, toffee, alcohol, cherries, red fruit, yeast, and bread in the nose.  Alcohol heat is the first thing I notice.  Toffee, anise, tar, bread, and maple syrup.  The alcohol has a certain pineyness to it that Ive noticed in fresh hot beers.  Much more yeasty and alchy than the others.  The alcohol is too much and the yeast character is very strange.   7/4/6/3/14 = 3.4  
06 Pours a clear slightly hazed orange brown with no head.  This one is slightly darker than the others.  More toffee malts, aged cherries, red fruit aromas.  This one is sweeter than most of the others.  Alcohol has subsided rather quickly.  Toffee cherries, maple syrup, caramel, bread and alcohol are balanced rather well.  Nice creamy full body.  Becomes a little overly sweet as it warms.  But still one of the nicer vintages. 8/3/8/4/16 = 3.9

05 Pours a slightly hazed orange brown with a soapy beige head that has a greenish tint to it.  Nose is abundant but not as good.  Caramels, toffee, and a lot more alcohol than its stronger younger 06.  Light flavors and light body.  Caramels, toffee, anise, alcohol, maple sweetness.  Not as good.  My least favorite vintage. 6/4/7/3/13 = 3.3  
04 Pours a slightly murky orange brown with a a ring of a beige head.  Abundant toffee, rich cherries and ripe fruits.  Toffee, caramels, fruit, slightly harsh with the alcohol, tar, anise, oak, and earthiness. Body feels thinner.  But a good vintage.  8/3/8/3/16 = 3.8

03 Pours a murky orange brown with a wispy off white head.  Aged malts in the nose.  Toffee cherries, maple, tobacco, dark fruits.  Full creamy body even at almost 5 years.  Caramels, toffee, dark fruit, anise, earthy.  Slight vegetal notes.  Rich and flavorful.  Really nice.  This one was my favorite.  8/3/8/4/17 = 4.0
2004 bottle.  Pours brown with no discernable head.  Tastes and smells of figs, raisins, sugar, some alcohol.

[2006 bottle] Dark redish brown with a low firm head. Sweet toffee aroma with fumes of alcohol. More sweet toffe shows up in the flavour, theres notes of black currant as well.  The taste of alcohol is a little bit too dominant but Im sure a good cellar could take care of that. I dont have a cellar :o(

Bottle @ Plan B, Copenhagen. Pretty young bottle I guess. Aroma of dark fruits, sweet malts and some hops/barley. Lovely. Slightly hazy, dark brown coloured with no head.Initially sweet and very fruity. Toffee, sugar, dark malts, some spicy tones too. Some alcohol in the finish. Quite well balanced and enjoyable.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2011 2003 bottle @ 11.4%. It has been cellaring for a while. Served in a Duvel tulip just a few minutes out of the fridge. Color is deep, dark red, bordering on brown. Small khaki colored head. Plenty of lacing and foam bubbles along the side of the glass. The aroma is strong and of dark fruits (figs, prunes), brown sugar, vanilla, cream, some herbal notes as well. The mouthfeel is full and expanding. The initial taste is vanila ice cream, brown sugar, overripe dark fruits the midtaste is all of that, in addition there is some bitterness, alcohol, and an almost oaky flavor present. The finish is warming and lingering, with a nice aftertase. Not sure what this is like new, but it is awfully tasty after 3 years in the bottle. At this age, it is English in style. 8/4/8/4/17 4.1  
2 bottle tasting, 2003 bottle @ 11.4% & 2008 bottle @ 12.5%
Older bottle is 8 years old, younger is the 3 years old, just like my prior rating. More overall pleasant oxidation and strong, dark fruit character in the older version. Color is dark red and similar between the two beers, both have small, wispy heads, the older is smaller. The older version is spicy black pepper, dried dates and prunes, some toffee and dark caramel, tobacco and old wood. The younger beer has rich flavors as well, with dark caramel and raisins with some warming alcohol and a bit more substantial mouthfeel. The 08 seemingly could use a little more time in the bottle, while the 03 is drinking beautifully right now and with less than ideal cellaring temps over these past 8 years. Id probably score the newer beer a bit less than the 4.1 I gave its 03 brother back in 06, but the 03 at 8 years is a little better than at 3 years, score increases a bit.

Bottle conditioned. Courtesy of Jacob Lövenlund. Deep chestnut red, thin but persistent off white head and moderate condition. Sweet and malty barley wine aromas with hints of peppery hop resin and citrusy orange notes. Soft and sticky weet in the mouth with warming alcohol, underlying oakiness, some roasted barley bitterness and a touch of smoke. Long sticky finish with sweet malt, burnt toffee, roasted nuts, bitter hoppiness and a lingering alcoholic warmth.

35,5 cl bottle. (2004) Reddish dark brown colour with a weak head. Aroma of chocolate, alcohol, heavy hops and caramel. Nice tasty flavour of caramel, malt, chocolate, alcohol and ends up quite nitter. A nice big beer.
Very good barley wine, on par with Sierra Nevada Bigfoot Ale, except more potent.  Very rich caramel presence, almost like brandy.  2005 bottle.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2006 2003 Bottle. Wow, what a beer. Poured a reddish brown, but not translucent. Lots of spices, citrus, oak, and caramel in both the aroma and the taste. Alcohol is present and warming. This beer seems to have aged nicely and is probably at its peak.

2005 bottle: Let it be known Im not the biggest fan of the style. Enter the cloudy line where brandy and beer meet. Great looking beer, dark red, with tiny little bubbles underneath a tannish head. Simple smell of moldy brown sugar. Taste is very sweet and syrupy. Sugar dates, faint roasted malt, little bitter hops all topped off with a ton of brown sugar. Too sweet.
